story:
« Et si rien de tout cela n’était réel »

Comment créer son identité propre par rapport aux normes inculquées par la société ? Comment accepter nos idées inavouées? Jusqu’où nous mèneront-elles ? Tout n’est qu’une question de choix. Sarah en a payé le prix fort de sa vie, elle a été emportée dans les méandres de sa pensée. Une fois que l’on est dans le tourbillon, comment voir le monde d’un regard nouveau et beau ? C’est ainsi que Santana Susnja, à 28 ans signe sa première création, le premier  volet d’un triptyque dédié au réveil des consciences. Un hommage à Sarah Kane, bien ficelé et d’un nouveau genre. Hologramme, vidéo, théâtre, danse et surtout musique live avec le musicien Louis Ramanitra, tout est là pour nous perdre dans une autre réalité, ou peut-être une réalité tellement proche que l’on ne veut pas la voir. C’est une pièce qui se veut sans carcan et sans étiquette. Une irréalité palpable à la façon de Tarkovski. Une performance où l’artiste se met à nue pour défendre ce qu’elle a dire. A voir et à revoir au Théâtre des Italiens à 17h tous les jours du festival. (relâche les lundis 14 et 21 juillet)

" And if nothing was real "

How to create our appropriate identity with regard to the standards inculcated by the society? How to accept our unconfessed ideas? To where they will lead us? Everything is only a question of choice. Sarah paid the full price of her life, she was taken in the meanders of her thought. When we are in the whirlwind, how to see the world of a new and beautiful look? This is the way Santana Susnja, in 28 years old sign her first creation, the first shutter of a triptych dedicated to the awakening of the consciousnesses. A tribute to Sarah Kane, tied up well and of a new kind. Hologram, video, theater, dance and especially live music with the musician Louis Ramanitra, everything is there to lose us in another reality, or maybe so close reality than we do not want to see it. It is the play which aims to be without yoke and without label. A tangible irreality like Tarkovski. A performance where the artist puts herself in naked to defend what she has to say. To see and to see again in the Theater of the Italians at 5 pm every day of the festival. (Relax on Mondays, 14 and July 21st)



Voilà ma toute première création, et j'ai besoin de votre aide pour la finaliser et surtout payer toutes les personnes qui travaillent pour le bon déroulement du spectacle.

Le festival d'Avignon est le plus gros festival de théâtre en France et très couteux, je vous donne un petit aperçu de ce que nous payons;

- Le théâtre en co-réalisation c'est à dire qu'il prendra 50% de nos recettes en plus de la location : 2500 euros

- Le logement : 3600 euros

- L’impression des affiche et des flyers : 700 euros

- La communication (pub et autres) : 1750 euros

- La camion pour emmener tout le matériel, la scénographie etc.: 2000 euros

- Les salaires de toute l'équipe : 7500 euros

sans compter tous les billets de train pour les répètes etc.

Here is my very first creation, and I need your help to finalize it and especially pay all the people who work for the good progress of the show.

The festival of Avignon is the biggest drama festival in France and very expensive, I give you a small overview of what we pay;

- The theater in co-realization that is it will take 50 % of our receipts besides the rent: 2500 euros

- The accommodation: 3600 euros

- The printing of posts and flyers: 700 euros

- The communication (ad, and others): 1750 euros

- Truck to take all the equipment, the scenography etc.: 2000 euros

- The salaries of all the team: 7500 euros

Without counting all the train tickets for rehearsals etc.


C'est mon premier projet et je suis ma propre productrice, je n'ai aucune aide, c'est pour cela que je vous sollicite. C'est un projet ambitieux, et j'ai la chance d'être soutenue par l'entreprise IVS technologies (The Voice, la FIFA, Le festival de Cannes etc.) qui réalise nos hologrammes. Le directeur croit en mon projet, êtes vous prêt, vous aussi à y croire?

Ce spectacle quoique personnel, car je l'ai composé de A à Z (l’écriture, le mise en scène, la scénographie) a un rayonnement collectif. Je ne suis pas seule, j'ai une équipe merveilleuse qui m'accompagne :

Le musicien qui fera de la musique live sur le projet : Louis Ramanitra AKA Goodjiu

Le regard extérieur qui m'empêche d'être perdue : Sylvain Martin

Le chef opérateur qui fait toutes les images projetées pendant le spectacle et la captation : Arthur Imbert

Le créateur lumière qui fera une ambiance lumineuse pour le spectacle : Laurent Girard

Et de nombreuses personnes qui m'ont aidé à tout faire : Karine Burckel, Damien Venzi, Jean-Marc Manzi, Maritoni Reyes, Jonathan Tresfield, Nathalie Guilmard, Thibault Aveline, Sarah Cottereau, Franck Ferreira, Olivier Maldonada, Gus, Rozenn Djonkovitch, Julien Naccache ...

Les lieux qui nous ont accueilli pour les répétitions : Le Morozoff à Marseille, et le Théâtre de Gennevilliers (Centre Dramatique National)

It is my first project and I am my own producer, I have no help, that's why I request you. It is an ambitious project, and I am lucky enough to be supported by the company IVS technologies (The Voice, FIFA, Cannes film festival etc.) which realizes our holograms. The director believes in my project, are you loan, you too to believe in it?

This show although staff, because I composed it from A to Z (the writing, staged, the scenography) has a collective brilliance. I am not alone, I have a wonderful team which accompanies me:

The musician who will make some live music on the project: Louis Ramanitra AKA Goodjiu

The outside look which prevents me from being lost: Sylvain Martin

The chief cameraman who makes all the images thrown during the show and the captation: Arthur Imbert

The creator light which will make a bright atmosphere for the show:  Laurent Girard

And of numerous people who helped me to make everything: Karine Burckel, Damien Venzi, Jean-Marc Manzi, Maritoni Reyes, Jonathan Tresfield, Nathalie Guilmard, Thibault Aveline, Sarah Cottereau, Franck Ferreira, Olivier Maldonada, Gus, Rozenn Djonkovitch, Julien Naccache ...

The places which welcomed us for the repetitions(rehearsals): Morozoff in Marseille, and the Theater of Gennevilliers ( National Arts center for theater )

Le théâtre et l'art en général existe pour pousser à la réflexion, et donner une autre vision de ce que nous vivons.

Dans ce projet nous nous battons tous les jours pour qu'il soit mené à bien, les problèmes affluent mais " il n'y a pas de problème, que des solutions".

Ensemble nous pouvons changer le monde et croire à quelque chose de beau, à une union entre les êtres.

Je vous demande de nous aider, une petite contribution ou une plus grande à vous de choisir et si vous ne pouvez pas, partager le à vos amis, à votre famille, chaque contribution pécuniaire ou non est importante pour nous, car cela nous apporte un soutien.

Je vous remercie par avance pour tout ce que vous allez faire, vous pouvez aller voir notre page facebook :

https://www.facebook.com/nevroseetsarahcanent

Vous trouverez des photos, plus d'explications, des vidéos, et notre progression pendant le festival.

The theater and the art generally exists to push on second thought, and give another vision of what we live.

In this project we fight every day so that it is brought to a successful conclusion, problems stream but 'there is no problem, only solutions".

Together we can change the world and believe in something beautiful, in an union between beings.

I ask you to help us, small contribution or bigger one to you to choose and if you cannot, to share to your friends, to your family, every contribution pecuniary or not is important for us, because it brings us a support.

Thank you in advance for all that you go to make, you can visit our page Facebook :

https://www.facebook.com/nevroseetsarahcanent

You will find photos, more explanations, videos, and our progress during the festival.

story:
The Story

My name is Michael Jahlil; and I am a storyteller. Since I was a child, stories have been my connection to the world. A story can change a heart, a mind, and especially a spirit. I became an actor because I understood that stories are our reflection on the world around us. That song you heard or that film you watched that shifted something inside of you. I come now to bring you my story...

I have written a cabaret piece called, "Who Is Like God?". It is a live memoir. A story about Love. Not just any Love; Unconditional Love. I feel like all of my life I had been on a search to find Love like that but it continued to elude me. I weave song and story together to recall this life long search: from my turbulent childhood, to the present day. The show will be supported by a four piece band and three fantastic backup singers. It will be the first step into writing a full theatrical play based on my life events, but this workshop is crucial for that to come to fruition.

What We Need & What You Get

The missing ingredient in all of this is you. You are the entity that can make this piece happen. This workshop has been a labor of love for almost a year now and all it needs is a stage and an audience. If you donate to this campaign, you will be helping to pay for the musicians, the absolutely necessary rehearsal space, and printing costs for music and invitations. We aren't asking for much but we do need the above amount to move forward with the project. There are a wide number of perks included with donation. From social media appreciation posts, to actually coming to experience the workshop live! If you aren't in a position to donate, please feel free to just send positivity  our way. 

    The Impact

    Monumental change is in such abundance all around us. Now is the time for this project. Now is the time for us to tell our stories, whatever they may be. The more we relate to one another, the more we can appreciate one another. Stories are our connection to the spirit and that spirit knows no race, sexuality, gender or any other boxes and limits we have created for ourselves. Donating to this campaign will be your step into the direction of CHANGE.   


      Other Ways You Can Help

      Spread the word!!! Share this page on your social media websites and get our story out there. If you live in the NYC area, please come out to the show on September 4th, 2014 at The Duplex on 61 Christopher Street. The show begins at 6:30pm. 

      Thank you for taking the time to visit and read about our campaign.

      Tell your Story!!!!

story:
Short Summary

Hello! My name is Tony Garcia. I am one of a group of seven University of South Dakota students that were selected to be a part of an event called The New York City Senior Showcase. What is this you ask? It is an opportunity for a select group of senior theatre majors to connect with industry professionals. We have the chance to attend workshops, network with professionals in theatre, and audition in front of agents to help us jump start our careers in theatre. In the past several USD students who have attended this event received callbacks, interviews with agents, and some even were offered jobs. This is a huge opportunity for us, but it does not come without a cost. 

What We Need 

Traveling in a large group to New York is not cheap. This is where we need your help! The total cost for traveling to New York and attending the showcase comes to $1200 dollars per student. Earlier this year our group applied for a research grant through the University of South Dakota and we were awarded about half of our total costs. However, being students, $600 dollars a person is hard to come up with. 
All the money we raise goes directly to us! it is deposited directly into the University of South Dakota's Theatre Department account and then is distributed evenly to the seven of us. Our department keeps none of the money, nor does the school. 
Any amount of money you are willing to contribute to us is immensely helpful, and we are grateful for your help. 

The Impact

As I mentioned earlier, several USD students who attended the NYC Showcase had great things sparked in their careers. Every student who has attended has received a callback with an agent. A few students earned representation from professional agents. One student, Cody Strand, had his Broadway career sparked through this event and went on to star in both the Broadway and touring productions of The Book of Mormon. As you can see this has the potential to help out our careers, and we have a very talented group this year. We have a wonderful mix of Acting and Musical Theatre Majors, who have starred in many of the productions at USD over the past 4 years. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Once again all 7 of us cannot express how much we appreciate your support to get us to New York. Every penny counts! Thank you for supporting us, but more importantly thank you for supporting theatre in general. Keep the arts alive!

Check out our Twitter @USDNYCShowcase and watch us in action our department's YouTube page: Department of Theatre University of South Dakota

Even if you aren't able to donate to our group, help get the word out there about us! Share our IndieGoGo page on your Facebook, Twitter, Instragram, Everywhere! Talk about us on twitter at #USDNYCShowcase.

story:
Short Summary

Hello! My name is Emmanuel and I am a tap dancer from San Diego. I began studying tap dance in college and fell in love with it. It is one of those things that is part of my soul. 

I am campaigning through Indiegogo so that I can attend the Los Angeles Tap Festival in August. By doing so, I will be able to continue fostering my love for tap dance and pass it onto the students that I teach. 

By contributing to this campaign, you will not just be sending a tap dancer to a random tap dance festival. You will be keeping the rich and decadent American art-form alive. 

What We Need & What You Get

Prior to the tap festival, I will need to buy a new pair of tap shoes. The shoes that I plan on buying are called Capezio K360's--a high quality, professional style tap shoe. They are fashioned out of a men's oxford and cost $300. After purchasing the shoes, I would have to take them to a cobbler who would stretch the shoes, build the shoes up, and then add the taps. That would cost about $100 dollars. 

Once buying the shoes, I'd sign up for the tap festival. There are four packages and I will be buying the package called Tap Enthusiast which is $150. It includes one class per day, one history class per day, and access to all the events. 

In addition to the package, I would like to buy a $35 ticket to the faculty concert that's held at the end of the week. Finally, there is a $25 non-refundable registration fee. The total would come to $210. 

The rest of the money would be used for gas :)

Other Ways You Can Help

I completely understand if you'd like to help but, don't have the finances. The best way that you can help is by sharing the post using Indiegogo sharing tools. Thanks!

story:
Nurture - Develop - Create

Since 2008, Fierce Backbone has provided a weekly community for writers, actors and directors to develop new stories for the stage. Your gift will help support our 2016 season of new work:

  • Steppin' Out by Jeremy Kehoe
  • Frederick Douglass - Unexpected by Stephen Blackburn
  • Gorgeous by Beth Polsky
  • 2016 Hollywood Fringe (projects currently in development)
  • Additional projects coming in the 2016 pipeline: The Choice of the Rose by Mona Deutsch Miller, Smut by Dylan Wallace, Defenders by Cailin Harrison, plus new plays from all our Fierce playwrights 

Fierce is currently home to several award-winning artists. Our members pay modest monthly dues to cover our overhead costs. Every dollar we raise in this campaign goes directly toward our 2016 public presentations of new work for the stage. And we are a 501(c)3 non-profit... so your gift is fully tax deductible. 

What We Need

We have dozens of new plays from our 20 playwrights that are ready for different levels of performance, from limited-run workshops to full productions. We've been smart with our money in 2015 and we've received both Los Angeles city and county support grants. But we need your help to raise the additional $10K we'll need for our 2016 slate of projects:

  • 25% goes for project materials (props, costumes, sets)
  • 35% goes for space rental (performance and rehearsal space)
  • 40% pays ARTISTS (actors, playwrights, directors, designers)

The Impact of Fierce Backbone

Fierce has developed multiple award-winning plays with some Fierce plays performed around the country and as far away as the United Kingdom and Australia. None of this was possible without the generosity of Backbone supporters from all walks of life who, we often find, are also FIERCE!

Check out some Fierce Facts we're pretty excited about...

  • Our weekly workshop has been running since January 2008 and is open to the public. Over 400 workshops have met to develop new plays in 8 years.
  • In an industry dominated by men, Fierce Lady playwrights account for over 50% of our active writing membership.
  • Fierce believes our world is a diverse place that should be reflected on stage and behind the scenes. We provide an artistic home for several artists of color and members of the LGBT community.
  • Fierce has no pre-determined aesthetic or "type" of play. We develop and produce the work our artists are writing about.
  • Fierce focuses the majority of our resources on the development process. Workshops and readings don't offer much in the way of box office returns, but they help make the leap from good play to GREAT. And we think that's FIERCE!

Connect with us!

Please connect with us in the social sphere. We'd love to meet you!

  • Follow us on Facebook.
  • Follow us on Twitter.
  • Throw us a Fierce bone...please share this campaign!

The Fierce Mission Statement

We are a collaborative organization committed to writing, developing and producing new dramatic works. We endeavor to provide opportunities where the skills and artistry of our membership can flourish.

Steppin' Out by Jeremy Kehoe 
Frederick Douglass - Unexpected by Stephen Blackburn 
Gorgeous by Beth Polsky
2016 Hollywood Fringe (projects currently in development)
Additional projects coming in the 2016 pipeline: The Choice of the Rose by Mona Deutsch Miller, Smut by Dylan Wallace, Defenders by Cailin Harrison, plus new plays from all our Fierce playwrights   Fierce is currently home to several award-winning artists. Our members pay modest monthly dues to cover our overhead costs. Every dollar we raise in this campaign goes directly toward our 2016 public presentations of new work for the stage. And we are a 501(c)3 non-profit... so your gift is fully tax deductible.    What We Need We have dozens of new plays from our 20 playwrights that are ready for different levels of performance, from limited-run workshops to full productions. story:
Specifically Jewish, Universally Human

As one of nine student-run theatre boards at Northwestern University, the Jewish Theatre Ensemble aspires to challenge common perceptions and generate conversations relating to issues that fall within the resonance of the Jewish experience through artistic media with particular relevance to the Northwestern community.

Now in our 21st season, JTE has produced over 50 plays and musicals containing explicit and implicit Jewish themes.  We never pin down precisely what "Jewish Theatre" is, but instead constantly grapple with what it can be. We hope that with each of our shows we can begin a dialogue around the intersection of faith, morality, identity, and art.

JTE has a particularly exciting and ambitious season lined up for the 2015-2016 school year: from an intimate play about sexual identity and relationships, to a flashy musical that will transport audiences back to the 1920s, to a laugh-out-loud comedy about self-discovery, to an exploration of the Syrian-Jewish community in Brooklyn and what happens when our eyes are opened to cultures other than our own. In order to do all of these productions justice by holding ourselves to a high standard of production quality, we need funds, which is why we are asking for your support!

Your donation will contribute to:

  • Production elements of our Mainstage shows
    • Sets, lights, costumes, etc to name a few
  • Overall capital improvements
    • New power tools, microphone parts, platforms
  • Special programming and outreach opportunities that engage with our mission
    • Previous events include a Q&A with a Holocaust refugee and partnerships with Jewish after school programs
  • Publicity endeavors to spread our reach beyond Northwestern's theatre community

We greatly appreciate all of your support and look forward to seeing many of you at our productions this year and beyond! If you have any questions about this campaign or JTE's season and work in general, please check out our website at NUJTE.com or email JulieBusch@u.northwestern.edu.

Thank you!

JTE's 2015-2016 Season

Cock by Mike Bartlett

Produced by Nicole Bauke

Directed by Joan Sergay


The Drowsy Chaperone Music & Lyrics by Lisa Lambert & Greg Morrison, Book by Bob Martin & Don McKellar

Produced by Bailey Sutton & Andrew Restieri

Directed by Emma Wahl


Wonder of the World by David Lindsay-Abaire

Produced by Heather Strauss

Directed by Weston Jacoby


Stunning by David Adjmi

Produced by Meryl Crock

Directed by Jenna Levin


Executive Board 2015-2016

  • Artistic Director, Co-Chair: Russell Kahn
  • Business Manager: Tess Musky-Goldwyn
  • Design and Technical Supervisors: Matt Kresch, Sarah Muller
  • Development Director, Co-Chair: Julie Busch
  • Directing Chair: Aaron Simon Gross
  • Freshmen Board Apprentices: Jonathan Gelb, Adam Yates
  • Outreach Directors: Hannah Merens, Jenna Levin
  • Parliamentarian: Emily Fishkin
  • Production Supervisor: Chris Paul
  • Associate Production Supervisor: Brandon Nadig
  • Publicity Directors: Lily Goldstein, Weston Jacoby
  • Special Projects Chairs: Kelsey Spencer, Max Beer
  • Stage Management Chair: Michael Herwitz

story:
Elephant Room Productions brings the audience into a room to interact with a metaphorical elephant, a topic the vast majority of the world refuses to talk about, to engage and personalize the issue and ultimately become a part of a discourse that will continue well beyond our walls.

ERP is committed to:

  • Speaking on the unspeakable by exploring the societal issues and topical events throughout the world that are difficult to face
  • Taking the collaborative nature of theatre beyond the stage to the orchestra, to the mezzanine, to the front door and beyond: to involve the audience in the play, and make them feel like they are a part of it, so they are not merely spectators, but active players
  • Connecting with the deep and raw behavior of human beings, using art to both examine the psyche and to trigger the synapses that affect the audience on a personal level
  • Fostering new works, using collaboration to develop new plays while maintaining the authenticity of the playwright’s voice
  • Mobilizing the stage, to not only bring the world into our art, but take our work into the world as a multi-city spanning company

About Beautiful American Soldier

Two sisters, unexpectedly lost along a quiet roadside in war-torn Iraq, find a friend in a man peddling junk. Back in America, a veteran of the war in Iraq discovers that he has much more in common with a homeless man than he wants to believe. Beautiful American Soldier rides the never ending ripple effects of war as shattered hearts, half a world away from each other, must find a way to deal with the consequences of war.

About the Playwright

Dano Madden is a playwright and director. He is a three-time finalist for the National New Play Network’s annual showcase of new plays. Dano’s plays have been produced and/or received development by Actors Theatre of Louisville, The Source Festival, The Artful Conspirators, World At Large Theatre, Seattle Repertory Theatre, The National New Play Network, Mile Square Theatre, Burnt Studio Productions, Northwest Playwrights Alliance, Idaho Theatre for Youth, Kitchen Theatre Company, Rutgers University, The University of Tulsa, Bloomsburg University, Lark Play Development Center, Seven Devils Playwrights Conference, Boise Contemporary Theater and Boston Theatre Works, among others. He is a four time Heideman Award finalist. He was the winner of the Kennedy Center’s 2007 National Student Playwriting Award and a finalist for the National New Play Network’s 2010 Smith Prize. Published works include: In the Sawtooths and Drop (Samuel French, Inc.), Beautiful American Soldier and Ella (Best American Short Plays 2005-2006 & 2009-2010), The Save (Playscripts, Inc.), The Soft Sand and Survival (Northwest Playwrights Alliance), The Raccoon and Leaving IKEA (Indie Theater Now) and monologues in The Best Men’s Stage Monologues and Scenes 2010 (Smith & Kraus) and Exceptional Monologues 2 (Samuel French, Inc.) In 2007, Dano was named one of “50 Playwrights to Watch” by The Dramatist magazine. His directing credits include: Whitman’s Brooklyn (The Artful Conspirators), Sister Mary Ignatius Explains It All For You (Actors Theatre of Louisville) and Backstory (Actors Theatre of Louisville, 24th Humana Festival). Dano was the 2008-2009 National New Play Network playwright-in-residence at Interact Theatre Company in Philadelphia. He received his BA from Boise State University and his MFA from Rutgers University. He is an adjunct professor of playwriting at NYU. Dano lives in Hoboken, New Jersey with his wife, Lauren, and their cat Beth.

What We Need & What You Get

Money, money, money. We need it and here's how we will be spending it:

  • $1000 for our actors, playwright, director, stage manager and everyone else involved in the reading. We understand that everyone might be taking time away from their busy lives. We want to be sure that everyone knows just how much they are appreciated and what better way to do that then by being paid?
  • $300 for our space to rehearse and perform.
  • $100 for Travel. We have to make sure we can get around.
  • $100 for Food. Our team has got to eat.
  • $100 for our Beer. 
  • $100 for Refreshments. We care about the people that come to support us. What better way then to bring food!
  • $50 for Printing and other expenses. Scripts are kind of important when performing a reading.
But wait, for all you math wizards out there thinking, "that doesn't add up to $2000", here's what will happen to rest of the funds.
  • A portion will go back to us so that we can have some funds to start up our future projects.
  • The rest we have decided will be donated to the VA. This is just one of the ways that we will be giving back with this project.

The Impact

Beautiful American Soldier is a play that covers a topic that deserves to be discussed more, Post Traumatic Stress Disorder. Statistics show that 70% of people in the United States have suffered from a traumatic event. An estimated 8% of people in the United States suffer from PTSD at any given time. We believe that this number is too high. We believe that by beginning the conversation, we can raise awareness and make sure that people who are suffering from this illness can get the help that they need, near and far.


Risks & Challenges

This will be our third workshop reading and we learn more and more about how everything needs to be handled. However, we will still always have challenges. Our biggest challenge is finding and funding the actors that will appropriately fill the roles. It is a very diverse cast and we need to be sure that each role is filled perfectly.

Our other challenge, as always, is being sure that we receive as much funding as possible. But with the kind help of all of you, we know that it is going to happen!


Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone will be able to contribute and that is perfectly fine! You can help us by sharing this page, by telling your friends, family, loved ones or even strangers on the street! Send your words of encouragement, we always like to hear them!

Elephant Room Productions is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Elephant Room Productions must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. The value of perks range from $1-58. Any contribution above that amount is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
WHAT IS THIS?!

Hello noice sleuths! Welcome to the crowd-fundraising page of Bloody Bloody Jessica Fletcher--a loving send-up of all things Angela Lansbury and Murder, She Wrote.  This original musical comedy is a one and half hour hilarious murder mystery all centered on that fictional Maine town we grew to love over 12 hit seasons--plus with a few exciting twists!  We're hoping to raise enough funds to produce a high quality two week staged reading of the show in New York City.  Please enjoy these highlights from our sold out concert at 54 Below: 

WHO ARE YOU?!

  • Kevin Zak (Creator/Book Writer) is a Lucille Lortel nominated actor and writer originally from Buffalo, NY.  He's most notoriously known for portraying Ken Starr in Clinton The Musical and was the closing company's Buffalo Bill in Silence! The Musical.  Kevin is a massive Angela Lansbury fan and Murder, She Wrote expert. @Kevinjzak
  • Phillip Taratula (Book Writer) is an NYC based actor and a fan favorite on the hit webseries, The Outs.   Recently he's performed at the Humana Festival, Huntington, Williamstown Theatre Festival, W.H.A.T., Portland Stage,  and the O’Neill Playwrights Conference. @ptaratula
  •  Josh Lamon (Book Writer, Additional Music/lyrics) is a Broadway favorite having performed most recently as the mayor of Punxsutawny in Groundhog Day.  Other Broadway and NYC credits include Finding Neverland, Elf, Hair, A New Brain, Little Me, Little Miss Sunshine, and Wicked. @josh.lamon
  • Keith Varney (Music and lyrics) has written Book, Music and Lyrics in various combinations for I GOT FIRED (NYMF, DIMF - Best American Musical), ELWAY: THE MUSICAL, THE OTHER SEX, JOSHUA: THE MUSICAL, PIE EATER & SCOOBY DOOSICAL. He has also written songs for Submissions Only,Hot Mess in Manhattan, See You Lighter, My Mother is a Sex Therapist & Dystopia Gardens. @keithvarney

WHAT DO YOU NEED!?

Ok, we're asking for $20,000.  A lot goes into creating theatre.  And here's where all that money goes:

  • Actors--professionals to portray all the citizens of Cabot Cove!
  • Creative Team--We need a director, choreographer, music director, and some designers to help bring this workshop to life!
  • Printed Materials
  • Rehearsal Space
  • Performance Venue
  • Musicians
  • Mic and Sound Rental
  • Stage Manager
  • General Manager

WHAT IF YOU DON'T REACH YOUR GOAL?!

That's ok!  We will put on the best possible presentations with the money that is funded.  We are determined to bring this show to life and we promise you that you won't want to miss out on the action.

HOW ELSE CAN I HELP?!

If you aren't able to donate--please help us spread the word by sharing on your social media pages!  Word of mouth truly helps with brand new musicals.

story:
Ballet Neo

Is ready to launch...

We Need a Little More Help to Get to the Stage!

 

What is Ballet Neo?

Ballet Neo, New York City's innovative neo classical ballet company, infuses classical ballet with contemporary emotional themes. Kate Thomas, as Artistic Director & Choreographer, brings a raw honesty & decorated dance background to the company’s programming (Click Here for bio). Our 2013 program will consist of two very different slants on drama. Thomas’ Appalachian Suites is a ballet inspired by the Monongah West Virginia Mining disaster. The work Measurement & Caution is an unexpected, deeply sensual exploration of the inherent loneliness of human intimacy. These works stir imaginations & redefine perceptions of the ballet as theater, enticing new audiences to discover the art form. Keep visiting this campaign page for new perks, event updates & artist information.

 

Make A Direct Cultural Impact With Your Support

Right now you have an opportunity to truly contribute to the vitality of the American dance scene & here's why.

  1. U.S. funding for the arts is universally contracting. Ballet Neo needs your help to continue presenting during this tenuous time.
  2. Your support will allow us to pay our artists a living wage.
  3. Your contribution will provide a proven, meaningful, international platform for our creative team, both on stage & behind the scenes.

The 2013/14 program is expected to attract a direct audience of 5,000 as well as an international audience via strategic media coverage. The possibilities are endless with your help.

 

What Is Required

Ballet Neo is pleased to announce an award from the Harkness Foundation for Dance. This award only partially funds our program. We're raising funds to pay for: 

  • Venue Fees ($4000)
  • Artist Fees ($4000)
  • Publicity ($2000)

TOTAL: $10,000

Our goal is large, yes, but so is our vision. We absolutely need your help to see this project through. With your support, Ballet Neo will continue to challenge performance traditions, breaking new ground in ballet and theater. Please make a donation today!

 

What You Get

  • A very public thank you via social media
  • Your name or company listed on balletneo.net
  • Ballet Neo swag
  • Tickets to exclusive V.I.P. events
  • & More

See the boxes to the right for details!

 

Give in 4 Easy Steps

  • Choose which perks you want from the menu to the right. 
  • Click the "Contribute Now" button.
  • Make your donation on a fully secure webpage
  • Feel really good about yourself.

NOTE: you can give any amount you wish. The totals listed are the minimum to receive each perk

 

You're Important & Sharing is Caring

Make some noise about this new fundraising campaign! Recruit people by simply using the sharing tools below.

               

 

Contact Us With Any Questions

Ballet Neo is produced by B.Muse Inc. B.Muse Inc., founded by Kate Thomas in 2003, is a not for profit organization that provides dance programs, lecture demonstrations & performances to schools in Harlem, the South Bronx & Upper Manhattan. B.Muse Inc. has received support from the New York State Council for the Arts, The Harkness Foundation for Dance, Newman’s Own Foundation, California First Foundation, Citibank & others.

To contact Kate Thomas, please email balletneocompany@gmail.com

 

With your support & enthusiasm we’ll reach our goal & we thank you for it!
story_txt:
Ballet Neo
Is ready to launch...
We Need a Little More Help to Get to the Stage! 
 
What is Ballet Neo?
Ballet Neo, New York City's innovative neo classical ballet company, infuses classical ballet with contemporary emotional themes. Kate Thomas, as Artistic Director & Choreographer, brings a raw honesty & decorated dance background to the company’s programming (Click Here for bio). Our 2013 program will consist of two very different slants on drama. Thomas’ Appalachian Suites is a ballet inspired by the Monongah West Virginia Mining disaster. The work Measurement & Caution is an unexpected, deeply sensual exploration of the inherent loneliness of human intimacy. These works stir imaginations & redefine perceptions of the ballet as theater, enticing new audiences to discover the art form. Keep visiting this campaign page for new perks, event updates & artist information. 
 
Make A Direct Cultural Impact With Your Support
Right now you have an opportunity to truly contribute to the vitality of the American dance scene & here's why.


U.S. funding for the arts is universally contracting. Ballet Neo needs your help to continue presenting during this tenuous time.
Your support will allow us to pay our artists a living wage.
Your contribution will provide a proven, meaningful, international platform for our creative team, both on stage & behind the scenes.
The 2013/14 program is expected to attract a direct audience of 5,000 as well as an international audience via strategic media coverage. The possibilities are endless with your help.
 
What Is Required
Ballet Neo is pleased to announce an award from the Harkness Foundation for Dance. This award only partially funds our program. We're raising funds to pay for:  

Venue Fees ($4000)
Artist Fees ($4000)
Publicity ($2000)
TOTAL: $10,000
Our goal is large, yes, but so is our vision. We absolutely need your help to see this project through. With your support, Ballet Neo will continue to challenge performance traditions, breaking new ground in ballet and theater. Please make a donation today!
 
What You Get

A very public thank you via social media
Your name or company listed on balletneo.net


Ballet Neo swag
Tickets to exclusive V.I.P. events
& More
See the boxes to the right for details!
 
Give in 4 Easy Steps

Choose which perks you want from the menu to the right. 
Click the "Contribute Now" button.
Make your donation on a fully secure webpage
Feel really good about yourself.
NOTE: you can give any amount you wish. The totals listed are the minimum to receive each perk
 
You're Important & Sharing is Caring
Make some noise about this new fundraising campaign! Recruit people by simply using the sharing tools below.
                 
 
Contact Us With Any Questions 
Ballet Neo is produced by B.Muse Inc. B.Muse Inc., founded by Kate Thomas in 2003, is a not for profit organization that provides dance programs, lecture demonstrations & performances to schools in Harlem, the South Bronx & Upper Manhattan. B.Muse Inc. has received support from the New York State Council for the Arts, The Harkness Foundation for Dance, Newman’s Own Foundation, California First Foundation, Citibank & others.
To contact Kate Thomas, please email balletneocompany@gmail.com
 
With your support & enthusiasm we’ll reach our goal & we thank you for it!

story:
What are we doing?

During a four-week period between August-November, we will be researching and developing a dance theater piece about childhood, based on memories from both the choreographers and the performers involved.

This research will be taking place at Leeds City College and Yorkshire Dance. Involved in the project are Olivia Calder, Kit King, Thomas McKeon, Carlos Oliveira (dancers); Rod Dixon (artistic mentor); James Peters (music producer) and Callum Holt (artistic producer).


Our main goals within this project are to shed light on how important our childhood is in the development of who we become and to express the fundamental role that our environment plays in this process.

Our project will include an open rehearsal for the general public and a final sharing for a small group of specialists from both our area of research and from the artistic industry in general, to get insight and in-depth feedback on the piece and the research done.

Why are we doing it?

Through our work, we want to express how we dealt with our own fears and unresolved scars and we want to encourage reflection on the topic of childhood and identity as we believe it is what happens to us as children that shapes who we are as adults.

What will we use the money for?

As part of the project, we need to raise £750 to enable us to pay for the studio space we will be hiring from Yorkshire Dance (which is, thankfully, being heavily subsidised), and will allow us to support our artists through providing them with financial assistance towards travel and living costs.

What's after this project?

After this initial phase of the project, we hope to take the piece to theatres in the Yorkshire region, aiming for it to be put in their Spring/Summer 2018 programmes.
We also plan on engaging with local communities by using the research from this project to create educational dance and theatre workshops/projects.

Thank you for taking the time to read our campaign.
Any contribution will be hugely appreciated. 

Sara, Nuno, Callum, and the rest of the team

story:
Why Contribute to The Production of The Chairs?

I am Lilith Mesidor, and am a senior Theatre and Performance major at Purchase College. For my final project, I have decided to act in The Chairs by Eugene Ionesco, and can’t do it without you!

A married couple prepares to share their meaning of life while they scurry around waiting for their guests to arrive, in what Ionesco described as a “tragic farce”.  Yet, the guests are not as responsive as they expect…

The Significance

This is a new twist on a play that is rarely performed by young actors. This production will bring one of Ionesco’s lesser-known works to life to at Purchase College, and perhaps revive an appreciation for an often-misunderstood genre of theatre. The Chairs will be the everlasting stamp on my college career, and will prove that I am capable of handling challenges put before me, despite its difficult language, physicality, and mental state necessary for success. The definition of the meaning of life and existentialism resonates more with age. For those of us who will be stepping out into all walks of life at the end of this year, I hope to charge that question by giving it more direction.

Why Is This So Important?

As my senior project, this show is a culmination of everything I have gained in my undergraduate career. This is vital to my continued growth down a path of artistry that is often overlooked. By supporting this project, you are standing behind a community of artists coming together to follow their passion. You are also the reason why this production will even go up. I don’t want to put up a ‘student’ production. I want to put up a professional one. We will always support those who support us. Even if you are not able to donate, please spread the word! Posting this link anywhere helpsJ Every dollar makes us that much closer.

Breakdown of Contributions

Rights: $225

Construction of the set: $400

Paint, decorative materials: $150

Advertising: $75

20% for unanticipated costs: $150


Ensemble

Lilith Mesidor

Alex Crowell

Creative Team

Director: Gabriel Vasquez

Stage Manager: Jane DiBartolo

Lighting Designer: Alan Craft

Dramaturg: Brett Solomon

Scenic Designer: Ken Lindgren

When: December 4th -7th, 2013 at 7:30PM

Location: The Underground in The Performing Arts Center at Purchase College

story:
Versión en Castellano a continuación / Scroll down for Spanish version 

Dear one!

I need your help to participate in a significant and unique experience.

My name is Nuria, I am a woman, a daughter and a young independent artist. But most of all I am a curious being, a creative soul and a creature whose interest in learning and expanding her consciousness goes beyond imagination.

This summer I want to attend Nancy Stark Smith and Mike Vargas dance event in Poland. A 10 days unique opportunity to explore Contact Improvisation dance, Contemplation and Composition.

Are you perhaps wondering what is Contact Improvisation? Or maybe who is Nancy Stark Smith and Mike Vargas? Or simply who am I?

Let me tell you about it!!!

First things first, let me introduce myself.

About me.

I was born in Spain but my roots are also connected to South America by having an Argentinian mother.

I moved to London, UK when I was 18 and came back to Spain after a while to reconsider my life. I am now developing my self and getting ready to move abroad once again to carry on with my work and studies.

I started dancing 3 years ago, when a life event offered me the possibility to start all over again and reconstruct myself. And that's when Contact Improvisation came to place.

Since an early age I've been curious about human behaviour and movement.

Artist Daniel Lepkoff translates into words my attraction to this practice by stating the following:

"In Contact Improvisation I can gather information through my physical senses directly from my environment, using my own powers of observation I can shift my perspective, have new perceptions and free myself from my own conventional/ habitual ways of seeing."

In my opinion, having the attention on physicality reduces the intention of doing and increases the action of being.

By committing to this practice I encounter the possibility to empower myself and rely on my physical intelligence and to allow my mind to be questioned every time I move. Dance allows me to reconnect with the body's innate ability to move that we all have, and that it's most of the time repressed by social conditioning.

About the practice.

Contact Improvisation dates 1972 and is “an open-ended exploration of the kinaesthetic possibilities of bodies moving through contact. Sometimes wild and athletic, sometimes quiet and meditative, it is a form open to all bodies and enquiring minds.” (definition by Ray Chung)

If you want to know more about this dance technique you can explore this wonderful website: https://contactquarterly.com/

Why this campaign?

I need your help to keep exploring this dance form!

At the moment Contact Improvisation is my core study as a dancer.

I am following a two years programme in Madrid: http://www.espaciofci.com/

In order to keep deepening in this practice I would also like to attend an intensive workshop going on this summer with practitioners Nancy Stark Smith and Mike Vargas who come all the way from the States to Poland to share their dance improvisation work using Contact Improvisation as a base.

This includes Contact Improvisation technique and practice, improvisation scores, listening practice, compositional awareness, contemplative practice, jamming, and observing.

The workshop is called “States of grace” which they describe as what can happen when all the balls are in the air at once.

Through dancing, listening, and watching, we will study physical and energetic changes of state, natural composition, presence, and relationship—in groups, solo, in and out of contact, in silence and with live music.

“Knowing, not knowing. Doing, not doing. Making choices. Humanity.”

This experience will help me to get closer to my dream: to introduce Contact Improvisation in different social contexts, such as environments with young people suffering from behavioural problems.

For me, human behaviour has a big impact on the environment. Therefore it is my wish to contribute to humanity by helping young people to know themselves better and interact with the world in a healthy way.

If you resonate with this longing to change the world by creating small changes in education and social inclusion this is your chance to create a big impact on someone's life!

The best way to contribute is by making a financial contribution!

My target for this campaign is 1000€.

Your contribution would help me to pay for some essential expenses of this experience:

625€ destined to cover the fee of the intensive workshop and 275€ for travel costs. The rest of the money raised will help cover the fee taken by Indiegogo.

More information about me and my practice.

I am a dancer and creator. My investigations walk towards authentic movement. From Gaga technique to Contact Improvisation I explore dance, consciousness and expressiveness, using movement as my language and means to share and reinvent myself. I have also been trained in Contemporary dance, Butoh and Russian Systema.

Significant practitioners that have influenced my practice are Cristiane Boullosa, Bruno Caverna, Robert Poyton, Katie Duck and Jess Curtis.

During my time in London I studied at the University of the Arts, London College of Communication and this increased my interest on entrepreneurship. It was back in Spain that I started my very own projects: a research laboratory, an online platform to promote intensive workshops, my own choreographic work and collaborations with different artistic disciplines (Filmmaking and Photography).

You can find more information and visual material on https://urcelaynuria.tumblr.com/

About the teachers.

 

Nancy Stark Smith.

She first trained as an athlete and gymnast, leading her to study and perform modern and postmodern dance. She danced in the first performances of contact improvisation in 1972 with Steve Paxton and others and has since been central to its development as dancer, teacher, performer, writer/publisher, and organiser. She has traveled extensively throughout the world teaching and performing contact and other improvised dance work. In 1975, Nancy co-founded Contact Quarterly, an international dance journal, which she continues to co-edit and produce along with other dance literature. Her work is featured in several books and films, and she has been developing the Underscore, a long-form dance improvisation structure, since 1990. She lives in western Massachusetts.

www.nancystarksmith.com

Mike Vargas.

He began studying music in 1959. He started specialising in music for dance in 1978. He works as a freelance composer across the USA and internationally performing, teaching, recording, and improvising. For the past 16 years, he has been working around the world with Nancy Stark Smith. He teaches on the faculty of the Smith College dance department. He has released 9 CDs of his music.

www.mikevargas.net

Thank you from my heart for collaborating with this campaign, I will always be grateful for your help!

Nuria.

............................................................

Versión en Castellano

Hola!

Necesito tu ayuda para participar en una experiencia única y significativa!

Mi nombre es Nuria, soy mujer, hija y artista joven e independiente. Pero sobre todo soy un ser curioso, un alma creativa  y una criatura cuyo interés por aprender y expandir su conciencia va más allá de la imaginación.

Este verano quiero participar en el evento de danza de Nancy Stark Smith y Mike Vargas en Polonia. Una oportunidad única para explorar la danza Contact Improvisación, la Composición y la Improvisación

¿Quizás te preguntes qué es el Contact Improvisación o quiénes son Nancy Stark Smith y Mike Vargas, o simplemente quién soy yo?

Dejame contarte todo esto!

Antes de todo, voy a presentarme:

Sobre mi.

Nací en España pero mis raíces están también conectadas con Sudamérica al tener una madre argentina.

Me mudé a Londres, Reino Unido cuando tenía 18 años y volví a España después de un tiempo a reconsiderar mi vida. Estoy ahora desarrollándome y preparándome para viajar de nuevo y continuar con mi trabajo y estudios.

Empecé a bailar hace 3 años, cuando una situación determinada en mi vida me ofreció la oportunidad de comenzar de nuevo y reconstruirme, Y ahí fue cuando el Contact Improvisación apareció en escena.

Desde una temprana edad me dio curiosidad la conducta humana y el movimiento.

El artista Daniel Lepkoff traduce en palabras de alguna manera mi atracción a esta práctica cuando dice lo siguiente:

"En el Contact Improvisación puedo recoger información de mi entorno a través de mis sentidos físicos, usando mis propios poderes de observación puedo cambiar mi perspectiva, tener nuevas percepciones y liberarme de mis propias formas de mirar convencionales/habituales."

En mi opinión, tener la atención en la fisicalidad reduce la intención de hacer e incrementa la acción de ser.

Al comprometerme con esta práctica encuentro la posibilidad de empoderarme y confiar en mi inteligencia corporal permitiendo a mi mente ser cuestionada cada vez que me muevo. La danza me permite reconectar con la habilidad innata del cuerpo de moverse, que todos tenemos, pero que muchas veces está reprimida por el condicionamiento social.

Sobre la práctica.

El Contact Improvisación aparece en 1972 y es "una exploración con final abierto sobre las posibilidades kinestésicas de cuerpos moviendose a través del contacto. A veces salvaje y atletico, otas silenciosos y meditativos, es una forma abierta a todos los cuerpos y mentes curiosas." (definición de Ray Chung)

Si quieres saber más sobre esta técnica de danza puedes explorar esta maravillosa web: https://contactquarterly.com/

¿​Por qué esta campaña?

Necesito tu ayuda para seguir explorando esta forma de danza!

Ahora mismo el Contact Improvisación es la base de mi formación como bailarina.

Sigo un programa de dos años en Madrid: http://www.espaciofci.com/

Para seguir profundizando en esta práctica me gustaría también participar de un taller intensivo con los profesionales Nancy Stark Smith y Mike Vargas quienes vendrán desde Estados Unidos a Polonia para compartir su trabajo de danza e improvisación usando el Contact Improvisación como base.

Esto incluye técnica y práctica de Contact Improvisación, partituras de improvisación, práctica en la escucha, conciencia compositiva, práctica contemplativa, jamming y observación.

El taller se llama "Estados de Gracia" lo que describen como lo que puede ocurrir cuando todas las bolas son tiradas en el aire de una.

A través de bailar, escuchar, observar, estudiaremos los cambios de estado físico y energético, la composición natural, presencia y relaciones- en grupos, solos, dentro y fuera de contacto, en silencio y con música en vivo.

"Saber, no saber. Hacer, no hacer. Tomar decisiones. Humanidad"

Esta experiencia me ayudará a acercarme a mi sueño: introducir el Contact Improvisación en diferentes contextos sociales, tales como entornos con gente joven sufriendo de problemas conductuales.

Para mi la conducta del ser humano tiene una gran repercusión en el entorno que nos rodea por lo que deseo colaborar con la humanidad ayudando a jóvenes a conocerse a si mismos y relacionarse con el mundo de una forma sana.

Si resuenas con el anhelo de querer cambiar el mundo con pequeños cambios en la educación y la inclusión social, esta es tu oportunidad de crear un gran impacto en la vida de alguien!

La mejor forma de ayudar es hacer una contribución económica.

Mi objetivo de esta campaña es 1000€.

Tu contribución me ayudará a pagar los gastos esenciales de esta experiencia:

625€ están destinados a cubrir la plaza del taller y 275€ para los gastos de viaje. El resto de dinero recaudado ayudará a cubrir los intereses que se lleva Indiegogo.

Más información sobre mi y mi práctica:

Soy bailarina y creadora. Mis investigaciones caminan hacia la búsqueda del movimiento auténtico. Desde la técnica Gaga al Contact Improvisación exploro la danza, la conciencia y la expresividad, usando el movimiento como mi lenguaje y medio para reinventarme y compartirme. He entrenado en Danza Contemporánea, Butoh y Systema Ruso.

Profesionales significativos que han influenciado mi práctica son Cristiane Boullosa, Bruno Caverna, Robert Poyton, Katie Duck y Jess Curtis.

Durante el tiempo que vivi en Londres estudié en la Universidad de las Artes, en la London College of Communication y esto incrementó mi interés por el emprendimiento. Una vez en España comencé a apostar por mis propios proyectos: un laboratorio de investigación, un espacio online para promocionar talleres intensivos, mi propio trabajo coreográfico y colaboraciones con diferentes disciplinas artísticas (Video y Fotografía).

Puedes encontrar más información y material visual en https://urcelaynuria.tumblr.com/

Sobre los profesores.

Nancy Stark Smith.

Primero entrenó como atleta y gimnasta llevándole a estudiar y bailar danza moderna y postmoderna. Bailó en las primeras performances de Contact Improvisación en 1972 con Steve Paxton y otros y ha desde entonces sido central en su desarrollo como bailarina, profesora, performer, escritora/editora y organizadora. Ha viajado extensamente a través del mundo enseñando y bailando Contact y otros trabajos de improvisación. En 1975, Nancy co-creo y co-editó Contact Quaterly, una revista internacional de danza, la cual continua co-editando y produciendo junto con otra literatura de danza. Su trabajo aparece en varios libros y películas y ha estado desarrollando el Underscore, una estructura de danza e improvisación, desde 1990. Actualmente vive en el oeste de Massachusetts.

www.nancystarksmith.com

Mike Vargas.

Comenzó a estudiar música en 1959. Empezó a especializarse en música para danza en 1978. Trabaja como compositor independiente a lo largo de Estados Unidos e internacionalmente actuando, enseñando, grabando e improvisando. En los últimos 16 años ha estado trabajando alrededor del mundo con Nancy Stark Smith. Enseña en el departamente de danza de la facultad del Smith College. Ha lanzado 9 CDs de su música.

www.mikevargas.net

 

Muchísimas gracias de corazón a todas las personas que apoyen de alguna manera esta campaña!

Eternamente agradecida,

Nuria.

She has traveled extensively throughout the world teaching and performing contact and other improvised dance work. In 1975, Nancy co-founded Contact Quarterly, an international dance journal, which she continues to co-edit and produce along with other dance literature. Her work is featured in several books and films, and she has been developing the Underscore, a long-form dance improvisation structure, since 1990. She lives in western Massachusetts.
www.nancystarksmith.com

Mike Vargas.
He began studying music in 1959. He started specialising in music for dance in 1978. He works as a freelance composer across the USA and internationally performing, teaching, recording, and improvising. For the past 16 years, he has been working around the world with Nancy Stark Smith. He teaches on the faculty of the Smith College dance department. He has released 9 CDs of his music.
www.mikevargas.net
Thank you from my heart for collaborating with this campaign, I will always be grateful for your help!
Nuria.
............................................................
Versión en Castellano
Hola!
Necesito tu ayuda para participar en una experiencia única y significativa!
Mi nombre es Nuria, soy mujer, hija y artista joven e independiente. Pero sobre todo soy un ser curioso, un alma creativa  y una criatura cuyo interés por aprender y expandir su conciencia va más allá de la imaginación.
Este verano quiero participar en el evento de danza de Nancy Stark Smith y Mike Vargas en Polonia. Una oportunidad única para explorar la danza Contact Improvisación, la Composición y la Improvisación
¿Quizás te preguntes qué es el Contact Improvisación o quiénes son Nancy Stark Smith y Mike Vargas, o simplemente quién soy yo?
Dejame contarte todo esto!
Antes de todo, voy a presentarme:

Sobre mi.
Nací en España pero mis raíces están también conectadas con Sudamérica al tener una madre argentina.
Me mudé a Londres, Reino Unido cuando tenía 18 años y volví a España después de un tiempo a reconsiderar mi vida. Estoy ahora desarrollándome y preparándome para viajar de nuevo y continuar con mi trabajo y estudios.
Empecé a bailar hace 3 años, cuando una situación determinada en mi vida me ofreció la oportunidad de comenzar de nuevo y reconstruirme, Y ahí fue cuando el Contact Improvisación apareció en escena.
Desde una temprana edad me dio curiosidad la conducta humana y el movimiento.
El artista Daniel Lepkoff traduce en palabras de alguna manera mi atracción a esta práctica cuando dice lo siguiente:
"En el Contact Improvisación puedo recoger información de mi entorno a través de mis sentidos físicos, usando mis propios poderes de observación puedo cambiar mi perspectiva, tener nuevas percepciones y liberarme de mis propias formas de mirar convencionales/habituales."
En mi opinión, tener la atención en la fisicalidad reduce la intención de hacer e incrementa la acción de ser.
Al comprometerme con esta práctica encuentro la posibilidad de empoderarme y confiar en mi inteligencia corporal permitiendo a mi mente ser cuestionada cada vez que me muevo. La danza me permite reconectar con la habilidad innata del cuerpo de moverse, que todos tenemos, pero que muchas veces está reprimida por el condicionamiento social.
Sobre la práctica.
El Contact Improvisación aparece en 1972 y es "una exploración con final abierto sobre las posibilidades kinestésicas de cuerpos moviendose a través del contacto. A veces salvaje y atletico, otas silenciosos y meditativos, es una forma abierta a todos los cuerpos y mentes curiosas." (definición de Ray Chung)
Si quieres saber más sobre esta técnica de danza puedes explorar esta maravillosa web: https://contactquarterly.com/

¿​Por qué esta campaña?
Necesito tu ayuda para seguir explorando esta forma de danza!
Ahora mismo el Contact Improvisación es la base de mi formación como bailarina.
Sigo un programa de dos años en Madrid: http://www.espaciofci.com/
Para seguir profundizando en esta práctica me gustaría también participar de un taller intensivo con los profesionales Nancy Stark Smith y Mike Vargas quienes vendrán desde Estados Unidos a Polonia para compartir su trabajo de danza e improvisación usando el Contact Improvisación como base.
Esto incluye técnica y práctica de Contact Improvisación, partituras de improvisación, práctica en la escucha, conciencia compositiva, práctica contemplativa, jamming y observación.
El taller se llama "Estados de Gracia" lo que describen como lo que puede ocurrir cuando todas las bolas son tiradas en el aire de una.
A través de bailar, escuchar, observar, estudiaremos los cambios de estado físico y energético, la composición natural, presencia y relaciones- en grupos, solos, dentro y fuera de contacto, en silencio y con música en vivo.
"Saber, no saber. Hacer, no hacer. Tomar decisiones. Humanidad"
Esta experiencia me ayudará a acercarme a mi sueño: introducir el Contact Improvisación en diferentes contextos sociales, tales como entornos con gente joven sufriendo de problemas conductuales.
Para mi la conducta del ser humano tiene una gran repercusión en el entorno que nos rodea por lo que deseo colaborar con la humanidad ayudando a jóvenes a conocerse a si mismos y relacionarse con el mundo de una forma sana.
Si resuenas con el anhelo de querer cambiar el mundo con pequeños cambios en la educación y la inclusión social, esta es tu oportunidad de crear un gran impacto en la vida de alguien!
La mejor forma de ayudar es hacer una contribución económica.
Mi objetivo de esta campaña es 1000€.
Tu contribución me ayudará a pagar los gastos esenciales de esta experiencia:
625€ están destinados a cubrir la plaza del taller y 275€ para los gastos de viaje. El resto de dinero recaudado ayudará a cubrir los intereses que se lleva Indiegogo.

Más información sobre mi y mi práctica:
Soy bailarina y creadora. Mis investigaciones caminan hacia la búsqueda del movimiento auténtico. Desde la técnica Gaga al Contact Improvisación exploro la danza, la conciencia y la expresividad, usando el movimiento como mi lenguaje y medio para reinventarme y compartirme. He entrenado en Danza Contemporánea, Butoh y Systema Ruso.
Profesionales significativos que han influenciado mi práctica son Cristiane Boullosa, Bruno Caverna, Robert Poyton, Katie Duck y Jess Curtis.
Durante el tiempo que vivi en Londres estudié en la Universidad de las Artes, en la London College of Communication y esto incrementó mi interés por el emprendimiento. Una vez en España comencé a apostar por mis propios proyectos: un laboratorio de investigación, un espacio online para promocionar talleres intensivos, mi propio trabajo coreográfico y colaboraciones con diferentes disciplinas artísticas (Video y Fotografía).
Puedes encontrar más información y material visual en https://urcelaynuria.tumblr.com/
Sobre los profesores.

Nancy Stark Smith.
Primero entrenó como atleta y gimnasta llevándole a estudiar y bailar danza moderna y postmoderna. Bailó en las primeras performances de Contact Improvisación en 1972 con Steve Paxton y otros y ha desde entonces sido central en su desarrollo como bailarina, profesora, performer, escritora/editora y organizadora. Ha viajado extensamente a través del mundo enseñando y bailando Contact y otros trabajos de improvisación. En 1975, Nancy co-creo y co-editó Contact Quaterly, una revista internacional de danza, la cual continua co-editando y produciendo junto con otra literatura de danza. Su trabajo aparece en varios libros y películas y ha estado desarrollando el Underscore, una estructura de danza e improvisación, desde 1990. Actualmente vive en el oeste de Massachusetts.
www.nancystarksmith.com

Mike Vargas.
Comenzó a estudiar música en 1959. Empezó a especializarse en música para danza en 1978. Trabaja como compositor independiente a lo largo de Estados Unidos e internacionalmente actuando, enseñando, grabando e improvisando. En los últimos 16 años ha estado trabajando alrededor del mundo con Nancy Stark Smith. Enseña en el departamente de danza de la facultad del Smith College. Ha lanzado 9 CDs de su música.
www.mikevargas.net
 
Muchísimas gracias de corazón a todas las personas que apoyen de alguna manera esta campaña!
Eternamente agradecida,
Nuria.

story:
A comedic take on contemporary parenting Motherload is created collectively by theatre artists Sasa Brown, Emelia Symington Fedy, Jody Kay Marklew, Sonja Bennett and Juno Rinaldi.

Placing a dark lens on a new generation of moms we are taking our candid conversations from playgrounds into the public format. Using the strength of simple storytelling we talk pointedly about postpartum depression, shameful personal regressions and the hilarity that goes along with joining the world’s biggest club.

Premiering at The Cultch in January 2015 this show has the potential for great success. The snag is- BC Arts Council and The City of Vancouver don’t fund new collectives. Because our funding opportunities are severly limited across Canada we have to rely on donor and sponsorship support. 

That means you!

Creation begins December 9th 2013.

While we are all committed to working for free for the first two week creation period we do need to raise money to pay for childcare for our 8 children and a rehearsal space. 

*We need to raise $4900 by December 1st 2013 or this project will not move into phase 2 of creation. 

We need your help!

 Playing on the edge of bittersweet, the show is never too dark to bare, and there is just enough light to see that we are not alone. Through sharing our metamorphisis into motherhood we hope to lighten the collective load.  

Please pass us on! Through facebook, email, twitter and word-of-mouth, you can help us reach our goal.

 This is a show for everyone. Possibly because it’s hilarious and charged with real life stories and stakes but most likely it’s because we all have a mother.

We will work for free but we need someone to watch the kids!

 We are asking, relying and hoping that you will help us carry Motherload into a successful future.

Help us pay for nannies so we can make a show!

Love the Motherload team,

Sasa, Emelia, Juno, Jody-Kay, Sonja and (Max, Arthur, Scout, Everett, Jake, Jack, Jade and newborn August)

story:
Short Summary

My name is Erin Wotherspoon. I am a George Brown Theatre school graduate and an aspiring writer. I have been involved in the arts most of my life and continue too pursue this dream in spite of constant financial uncertainty and crippling student debts. A theatre school colleague and myself have just finished writing what will be our first full-length play. This campaign I've created is to raise money so we can afford a venue for our show. We hope to raise enough money so we can afford to rent the venue for more than one night allowing our show to reach a wider audience. 

What We Need

Our aim is around $1000 give or take more or less. Regardless of how little or much money we get we will be going through with the project, as we believe in the quality of the script. It is simple, if we don't make much money we will probably end up doing the play in a coffee shop, with no lights, no sound, or any kind of props. If we do reach our goal or exceed it we will be able too pick a venue more suitable for theatrics and luxuriate in props and costumes and maybe even a sound cue or two.

The Impact

"In a world of lies, roommates Deb & Nico set sail for the truth." An artist is in (or should be in) a constant pursuit of truth, while the rest of the world has cashed in for security and financial stability, the artist can be over-looked as childish or flat out failures in societies like ours where money is next too godliness. But without the truth, our sense of humanity & often humour can become lost. THE TRUTH HURTS but it doesn't always have too, donate ANYTHING and you will be enabling our dream of truthful expression. Thank you so much.

Other Ways You Can Help

JUST SPREAD THE WORD, THAT SIMPLE.

story:
Our Journey


It all started in John Lacy’s acting class/workshop…

When young upstart Freddy Giorlando and seasoned veteran Kevin McCorkle were paired up to do a scene together in class from Arthur Miller’s DEATH OF A SALESMAN, the chemistry was immediately palpable.  As they continued to work together on the scene, they began to feel a calling to do something more, something bigger.  

After putting the scene up, Kevin offhandedly said, “We should do this show.” Freddy responded by getting in touch with The Miller Estate (he had been a volunteer in Rebecca Miller’s NYU Film class eight years ago.) Freddy secured the rights for a limited run in Los Angeles for the month of April in 2019.  Thus, they began the journey to mount the full production of this great American classic. Be careful what you wish for!

Kevin McCorkle is a seasoned veteran actor, as well as a cancer survivor.  While working on the scene with Freddy, he realized DEATH OF A SALESMAN mirrors many of his personal life experiences, including his close brush with death and the arc of nearly every actor’s career path. Enter Willy Loman.

Freddy is a single dad from New York, trying to make it here in the City of Angels.  His goal is to provide the best possible life for his family.  DEATH OF A SALESMAN is an important step towards his Hollywood dreams. Enter Biff Loman.

These inspired artists began to reach out to their friends to help bring their vision to fruition. First, acclaimed actress Jules Bruff signed on to play Willy’s wife, Linda Loman, and help produce.  Courtney King jumped on as a producer, and Joey Langella welcomed the role of social media coordinator.  And then, they were fortunately able to lock down award-winning director Bjorn Johnson to helm the show.  We’ll keep you posted as new actors and crew members come on board.

The show is set to open on April 5th at the SECRET ROSE THEATRE in North Hollywood.  We have a long way to go in order to bring DEATH OF A SALESMAN to life. Our team, aided by your support, hopes to resurrect both a renewed love and following of classic theatre right here in the City of Angles.

What We Need & What You Get

 

Let’s break it down.  We’re actors with a dream!  We intend on bringing you, our audience, the best possible show!  That being said, we plan on being prudent with the funds we raise.  With the help of your generous donations, we will be able to…

• Hire an exceptional stage manager . . . (an awesome stage manager is essential to any successful production).

• Costume our characters . . . (costumes are a pivotal part of the story).

• Arrange for the best possible light design.

• Lock in the historic Secret Rose Theatre to house our show and bring the story to life.

In addition to producing the play, we intend to create a documentary of our journey as an independent group of artists mounting a show in Los Angeles, to share with other artists around the world.

 

The Impact

 

This production of DEATH OF A SALESMAN will be the first in our series of classic theatre pieces. Our goal is to expose a whole new audience and generation to the titans of theatre history.

Our documentary will give us the opportunity to share our journey with other independent theatre groups looking to mount their own shows without the aid of an established theatre company.  
 

Challenges

 

Mounting any show has its challenges.  We are committed to working as a team to overcome them.  Whatever you contribute, whether it’s funds, social media support, or time- you are helping us bring this wonderful story to life.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

We understand that not everyone is able to contribute financially, we are always open and deeply grateful to volunteers who are willing to lend their time or services to us.  Drop us a line via email TheProcess360@gmail.com, Instagram @theprocess360, or Facebook @The Process 360, if you’re interested in supporting our team as a volunteer.

Thank you for taking the time to read about our campaign.  We hope to see you on opening night or any other performance during the run!!

story:
Les Sapphides

A hauntingly sensual duet, elegant and eerie, Les Sapphides is a contemporary lesbian vampire ballet. Incorporating confessional poetry, film, and sensory delights, Les Sapphides is dance theater in the disturbingly visceral vein. Support emerging choreographers and performing artists in New Orleans!  

  • Nov. 20-24 9pm & Nov. 22-23 10pm at Divine Yoga Center  
  • Choreographed by Rachel Clark 
  • Performed by Tricia Anderson and Delia Constantino

My name is Rachel Clark, and I am a dancer/choreographer in New Orleans. I graduated summa cum laude from Tulane University with a BFA in dance, where I choreographed several pieces including my honors thesis, Falling to Recover. Les Sapphides is my first full-length piece, and I am thrilled to premiere it at the Fringe Festival this month! But I need your help. 

The Nitty Gritty

$500 covers:

  • $250 Application Fee to Perform at the Fringe Festival
  • $100 to Pay the Performers and Crew
  • $50 Costumes and Props
  • $50 Set, Lighting, and Sound
  • $50 Promotional Materials

The Impact

With your help, Les Sapphides will be a high-calibre, professional production. 

  • Performers and crew members will be paid. They have put so many hours into making Les Sapphides possible. I would love to reward them for all of their hard work.
  • By supporting Les Sapphides you support queer individuals, queer narratives, and queer communities
  • You support emerging artists, the Fringe Festival, and New Orleans 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Invite your contacts to contribute to Les Sapphides
  • Share fundraising ideas

Thank you so much for your support. We rely on patrons like you
