story:
***UPDATE***

We have been overwhelmed by the generosity of our donors and the momentum of this campaign.  We are thrilled to have reached our preliminary online goal so soon.  The entire budget for LAKE WATER is over $18,000.  Our online campaign will only cover a fraction of this.  We would love to continue raising as much money as we can until the online campaign ends on August 15.  This will increase our ability to market and advertise the play and provide much needed resources for our amazing design team. Thank you for spreading the word and helping bring LAKE WATER to the stage!


Who We Are

Hey! It's Troy Deutsch. I'm excited to talk to you about my new play LAKE WATER. I have assembled a team of amazingly talented and passionate collaborators, including my director Daniel Talbott, producer Amanda Feldman, and a group of indie theater rockstar designers... truly my dream team.  We are so happy to be bringing LAKE WATER to IRT Theater in the West Village this fall. 

Our Story


The video above is footage of my hometown:  New Prague, Minnesota, a small rural Czech and German farming community on the outskirts of Minneapolis. It is a beautiful, peaceful town, but i found the experience of growing up there to be, at times, terribly lonely and isolating, as it is for many teenagers who feel "different" or are questioning their sexuality, as I once was.   

On a visit home a few years ago, I found a poem my little sister Greta had written for a high school writing assignment about all of the young people committing suicide or dying in accidents in our town with one stoplight.  My sister doesn't claim to be a writer, but her poem impacted me deeply:


Are we being haunted?

Is there a burden on our small town?

Why are there so many deaths of all these innocent people?

Are there hidden predicaments?

Or are we under a curse?  Or spell?  Or jinx?  Or plague?

Is there something eerie about New Prague that makes young people surrender?

Why are we wiping away all of our tears?

When will this horror expire?


Tears filled my eyes.  I was numb.  I was grateful to my sister for her poem, for giving voice to something that had been swirling inside my head for years.  Then she told me about a few of the local teen suicides that had occurred since I left town.  These stories, compounded by my sister’s poem, and my own experience of growing up isolated and questioning my sexuality, inspired me to finally start writing the play.

LAKE WATER follows two small town high school seniors, Iris and James, who become estranged after their best friend suddenly commits suicide. Then one “crapping pathetic Friday night,” James calls Iris in distress, and she meets him at the lake.  Out on a dock, surrounded by green water, the two friends untangle the painful events of their past and struggle to face the limits of their lives.  LAKE WATER is a two-person 80-minute play with one set and no intermission. Full of humor and hope, the play sheds some light on an all-too-common small town American tragedy. 


The Impact

LAKE WATER is a deeply personal play for me.  And with the rash of teen suicides in the news, especially amongst isolated LGBT youth, the story of LAKE WATER feels particularly timely and urgently needed. We hope to bring this play not only to regular theatergoers, but to reach the LGBT youth who might benefit most from this story.  We plan on reaching out to PFLAG and local LGBT youth groups in an effort to start a dialogue, to give voice to the voiceless, and, ultimately, bring about healing.

What We Need & What You Get

Thanks to a number of generous foundations we have already raised more than half of the money we need to produce the play. Your donation will help pay for the set, the theatre rental, our press agent and numerous other expenses associated with producing a world premiere production in NYC. In exchange for your donation, we're offering a number of thank you gifts... My mom sure can't wait to share her Minnesotan recipes with ya!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to your donation, we can use your help to spread the word. So please mention us on facebook, tweet about us, and let your friends know about LAKE WATER.  And if you know someone who you think might benefit from seeing a story like this on stage, please bring them to the play.  LAKE WATER will tell them to hang on, and that it does, indeed, get better.

 

We thank you in advance for your generosity. 

See you at the theater in September!
story_txt:
***UPDATE***
We have been overwhelmed by the generosity of our donors and the momentum of this campaign.  We are thrilled to have reached our preliminary online goal so soon.  The entire budget for LAKE WATER is over $18,000.  Our online campaign will only cover a fraction of this.  We would love to continue raising as much money as we can until the online campaign ends on August 15.  This will increase our ability to market and advertise the play and provide much needed resources for our amazing design team. Thank you for spreading the word and helping bring LAKE WATER to the stage!

Who We Are
Hey! It's Troy Deutsch.
I'm excited to talk to you about my new play LAKE WATER. I have
assembled a team of amazingly talented and passionate collaborators,
including my director Daniel Talbott, producer Amanda Feldman, and a group of
indie theater rockstar designers... truly my dream team.  We are so happy
to be bringing LAKE WATER to IRT Theater in the West Village this fall. 
Our Story

The video above is
footage of my hometown:  New Prague, Minnesota, a small rural Czech and
German farming community on the outskirts of Minneapolis. It is a beautiful,
peaceful town, but i found the experience of growing up there to be, at times,
terribly lonely and isolating, as it is for many teenagers who feel
"different" or are questioning their sexuality, as I once was.   
On a visit home a few
years ago, I found a poem my little sister Greta had written for a high school
writing assignment about all of the young people committing suicide or
dying in accidents in our town with one stoplight.  My sister doesn't claim
to be a writer, but her poem impacted me deeply:

Are we being haunted?
Is there a burden on
our small town?
Why are there so many
deaths of all these innocent people?
Are there hidden
predicaments?
Or are we under a
curse?  Or spell?  Or jinx?  Or plague?
Is there something
eerie about New Prague that makes young people surrender?
Why are we wiping away
all of our tears?
When will this horror
expire?

Tears filled my eyes.
 I was numb.  I was grateful to my sister for her poem, for giving
voice to something that had been swirling inside my head for years.  Then
she told me about a few of the local teen suicides that had occurred since I
left town.  These stories, compounded by my sister’s poem, and my own
experience of growing up isolated and questioning my sexuality, inspired me to
finally start writing the play.
LAKE WATER follows two small town high school seniors, Iris and
James, who become estranged after their best friend suddenly commits suicide.
Then one “crapping pathetic Friday night,” James calls Iris in distress, and
she meets him at the lake.  Out on a dock, surrounded by green water, the
two friends untangle the painful events of their past and struggle to face the
limits of their lives.  LAKE WATER is a two-person 80-minute play
with one set and no intermission. Full of humor and hope, the play sheds
some light on an all-too-common small town American tragedy. 

The Impact
LAKE WATER is a deeply personal play for me.  And with
the rash of teen suicides in the news, especially amongst isolated LGBT youth,
the story of LAKE WATER feels particularly timely and urgently
needed. We hope to bring this play not only to regular theatergoers, but
to reach the LGBT youth who might benefit most from this story.  We plan on
reaching out to PFLAG and local LGBT youth groups in an effort to start a
dialogue, to give voice to the voiceless, and, ultimately, bring about healing.
What We Need & What
You Get
Thanks to a number of
generous foundations we have already raised more than half of the money we need
to produce the play. Your donation will help pay for the set, the theatre rental, our press agent and numerous other
expenses associated with producing a world premiere production in NYC. In
exchange for your donation, we're offering a number of thank you gifts... My
mom sure can't wait to share her Minnesotan recipes with ya!
 
Other Ways You Can Help
In addition to your
donation, we can use your help to spread the word. So please mention us on
facebook, tweet about us, and let your friends know about LAKE WATER.
 And if you know someone who you think might benefit from seeing a story
like this on stage, please bring them to the play.  LAKE WATER will
tell them to hang on, and that it does, indeed, get better.
 
We thank you in advance
for your generosity. 
See you at the theater in
September!

story:
Who We Are

Music on Stage is a community of performers, musicians, artisans, designers and volunteers dedicated to the preservation and development of community theatre. We are proud to provide a live orchestra to support the volunteer cast and crew for our musical theatre performances at our home at Cutting Hall, in Palatine, Illinois.

A strongly committed, hard-working, volunteer Board has managed the affairs of Music on Stage since its inception. These talented individuals are young, old, men women, teachers, office managers, artists and lawyers -- a true microcosm of the community. Some Board members regularly perform on stage; most choose to be involved only behind the scenes.

Cutting Hall, a facility of the Palatine Park District, has been home to Music on Stage productions since 1979. The air conditioned 441-seat theatre boasts a spacious 36-foot proscenium stage and floor-level orchestra pit.

Music on Stage has provided the northwest suburbs of Chicago with quality community theatre for over 50 years! We have done so as a 501(c) nonprofit corporation.

The Show

The Pajama Game is a musical based on the novel 71/2 Cents, written by Richard Bissell, which was made into a movie directed by Richard Abbott. A workplace romance between Babe Williams, the leader of the union grievance committee and Sid Sorkin, the new superintendent is complicated by a workers' strike at the Sleep-Tite Pajama Factory. The beautiful score, written by Richard Adler and Jerry Ross, includes Steam Heat, Hey There and Hernando's Hideaway, which have become musical theatre repertoire standards.

(Source: MTI - www.MTIShows.com)

The Vision; Risks and Challenges

Funds pledged would help to pay for advertising and costume needs for our production of the Pajama Game. In a tough economy, and with limited budgets, our production team has become very creative in cutting production costs while still providing a professional grade show. One area that continues to provide a challenge is advertising costs. As a community theatre company with a community theatre budget, our biggest challenge has been to afford the advertising we desperately need to let theatregoers know about our show. Outside of word-of-mouth, putting up posters in the community and sharing links on social media links, all other advertising costs money, be it newspaper, radio or television.

Your help would allow our advertising reach expand to neighboring communities as well as to Chicago-based communities for a three-week run, plus preview.

In addition, while this show has a smaller cast, it has a daunting costume requirement, with multiple costume changes for each cast member throughout the show. Your help would help defray the costs of costuming a cast of twenty.

Our experienced, dedicated and creative director and production team will ensure that every pledge is properly allocated. With your help, we can see this production achieve its highest potential and allow this classic comedy, with its talented cast and crew, garner the exposure it deserves!

Should we be fortunate to meet our goal, we encourage additional pledges ti enhance other areas of the production. We have the talent and commitment of our cast and crew of volunteers...the final component of meeting our budgeting needs can be met with the generous support of people who enjoy live theatre -- people like you!

Rewards

Music on Stage would be very appreciative and grateful for every pledge. As a 501(c) nonprofit corporation, your pledge would be tax deductible commensurate with the reward tier and as allowable by law. Please review the specific reward tiers provided as our thanks to you.

We thank you for your generosity and support.

story:
This fall, our theatre company is embarking on our most exciting and ambitious project to date, “Hotel Suite” and we need to Raise $5,500 in order to secure a performance venue.

“Hotel Suite” is an exciting, ground breaking, immersive and site specific 21-day theatrical event featuring the work of 8 directors, 8 playwrights, 20 actors and an immensely talented design and support team.  This project includes the celebrated works of Sam Shepherd and the first Off-Off Broadway production of Bug by Tracy Letts, along with 6 brand new one act plays.   Our show will run for 3 weeks between October 4th and November 18th, 2012. 

The fourth wall will be broken and the audience will step inside the “hotel room” filled with stories and experiences.  These traditional plays have never been performed in this way and we look forward to sharing a different way of storytelling.  Audience and characters will collide during the course of each show’s performance, allowing viewers to be a part of the story.

Thinking about this concept for several years, our Artistic Director, Akia, feels we finally have the right combination of talent, history and circumstance to make this project a reality.  After several attempts over the past few years to obtain rights to Tracy Letts play, Bug, Rising Sun Performance Company will be the first Off-Off Broadway company to present this play in NYC since its original Off Broadway run! 

So, all of the pieces have fallen into place - an amazing group of directors, playwrights, actors and collaborators.  THIS IS the team to make this project happen, BUT WE NEED YOUR HELP to get there!  We are looking for a raw loft space, hotel suite, connecting hotel rooms or a large hotel room that could hold an intimate performance for 10-20 people at a time. We have several exciting leads but we need to be able to pay for the space in order to move forward. 

Here is where you get to be a part of the show! With each donation a “virtual” new room is added to our “Hotel Suite” with your name on it. You decide which room you want to help us  build!

See the sidebar for the AWESOME PERKS starting with just a $10 DONATION!

The most important element besides the cool perks, is the impact of having your money support local independent theatre in a very real way.  You could be a part of an exciting theatrical event and a leader in supporting art on a grassroots level.

Rising Sun Performance Company is a vital part of the Off-Off Broadway landscape; being one of the longest running ensemble companies at our producing level in NYC.  Established in 2001, we are a small but prolific non-profit theatre company, having produced over 50 productions and events both locally and nationally. Check out our website www.risinsunnyc.com for more information about us.

We bring to this project our long history of collaboration, existing audience, established reputation, enthusiastic energy and exciting quality work.  We feel confident that when we hit our IndieGoGo Campaign Goal, this production will be our best yet!  BUT it’s still A LONG WAY off from happening.  If we don’t reach our goal, we will have to postpone the production.   PLEASE HELP OUR ARTISTS BRING THEIR WORK TO LIFE!

$5,000 is just the first step, and that will only cover our performance venue.

What we have in place:
Brilliant Playwrights
Killer Designers
Top Notch Directors
Breathtaking Actors
and 3 great spaces to rehearse in (THANKS TO THE FIELD, HORSE TRADE & SPACE ON WHITE!)

What we need:
$5,000 for our venue to perform
$1,800 for Royalty Rights for Fool for Love & Bug
$2,000 to Pay our Designers & Stage Managers
$1,500 for our Set, Props & Costumes
$1,500 for additional rehearsal space
$1,000 for sound, lighting & visual technology

Be a part of our collective history and give “Hotel Suite” a home! Donate today!

THANK YOU FOR READING OUR CAMPAIGN!  THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

The Rising Sun Performance Company:

Ensemble: Akia Squitieri, Amanda Berry, Andrea Cordaro, Ashleigh Herndon,Bonnie Jean Warren, Carl Fengler, Christina G. Mullikin, Derek W. S. Shore,Elizabeth Burke, Haley Selmon, Jason LeMaster, Joe Beaudin, Kate Foster, Kelley Evans,Mia Y. Anderson, Michael Aguirre, Michael Burns, Michael Mraz, Ryan Dursek, Samantha Cooper, Samantha DeSimone, Sarah Norris, Stephon Pettway & Tiffini Minatel

Interns: Margaret Kissinger, Nancee Moes, Andrew Freeburg, Louisa Pough,  Khadijjah Mote & Debra Schaeffer

Guest Artists & Extended Family: Tim Errickson, Tim Butterfield, EJ Assi, Haddon McKinney, Jak Prince, Linda L. Rand,  Alexandra Petri, Angela C. Hall, Mark Cornell, Emily Duncan, Matt Hanf & John Davenport

story:
Set in present-day Berlin and 1980s Divided Berlin, AGENCY investigates the relationship between the communist vs. post-Wall generation while exploring, intimacy in lonely human-beings, and the walls we build around ourselves.

It is with great pleasure that Yell Rebel presents Eva Barrie’s Agency.

 

Why support Agency?

If you've been following our #KeepContemporary series on Twitter (@YellRebelTO) you may have noticed we've been showcasing directors/companies who support new works. Why? Because that's what keeps Toronto moving forward! They allow our multi-cultural audiences to feel represented. Agency does just that. 

Canada is a nation of immigrants, so why doesn’t our theatre reflect this? We live in a globalised world. Events that happen far away effect us either directly or, in the case of Agency, indirectly, through inherited trauma.  Our citizens stories don’t always begin on Canadian soil, so let’s celebrate what makes this country unique, by hearing all of our stories! 

Get in on the ground floor of a World Premiere! Agency has never gone to production, but, in 2015, it was selected by Halifax’s DaPoPo Theatre for a staged reading in their National Live-In Series and appeared alongside works from Sharon Pollock and Guillermo Verdecchia. One audience member commented, "being a child of the Cold War, born in an Eastern Bloc country with parents who defected, I was impressed with the emotional truth of this play. In particular, the complexity of relationships with informants who are also friends is true. The research is impeccable."

 

We Need Your Help To Bring Agency to Life!

Thanks to generous funding from the Canada Council for the Arts and the Ontario Arts Council, we are able to put our initial funding towards what matters most to us: our artists. With our grant money, we have been able to secure honorariums for all our artists.

However, we’ve still got a ways to go! We are busily working to raise $5000 to cover necessities like insurance fees (to keep everyone safe), marketing costs (to make sure we have an audience to perform to) and equipment rental (so our Lighting/Sound Designers don’t have to sit to the side of the stage and explain what they WOULD HAVE done if we could afford their gadgets).

The $3000 raised in this campaign will be dedicated to:

Paying the rental fee for our performance venue, the hub of innovative Canadian theatre: The Theatre Centre ($2400).

Making our set sparkle! We have a stellar team of designers with us, and Set/Costume Designer Karyn McCallum can’t do her magic without a wee bit of green. Help us help Karyn!

Every penny we make after the $5000 will go straight into the artist’s pockets. So, we’d like to introduce….

 

The Artists

Megan Watson (Director)

Megan is a director/theatre creator from Ottawa who makes Toronto her home. She just completed a season at The Grand Theatre in London, Ontario as the Apprentice Artistic Director/Artistic Associate where she assisted on main-stage productions, worked with local playwrights and directed a production of Julius Caesar with the spring High School Project. She holds an MFA in directing from the University of Alberta and a BFA in acting from Ryerson University. Select directing credits include: Extremophiles (Architect Theatre) Far Away  (PreShow Playlist), Crookback -a solo adaptation of Richard III (Beacon Theatre / touring), When the Rain Stops Falling, Much Ado About Nothing, Hear and Now (University of Alberta) The Queer Bathroom Stories (Buddies in Bad Times Theatre), Derailed (AMY Projects), As Is and Bent (Theatre Engine). Megan has also had the pleasure of assistant directing for some of Canada’s top directors including Eda Holmes, Richard Greenblatt, Micheline Chevrier and Susan Ferley. Upcoming projects: She will be returning to The Grand for a second season under new Artistic Director Dennis Garnhum.

Eva Barrie (Playwright, playing Hannah)

Originally from Okotoks, Alberta, Eva is a Toronto-based director, actor and creator and has created art in Germany, India, Italy, Poland, Canada and the United States. She is a graduate of Ryerson University’s Performance Acting Program and has trained with Anne Bogart’s SITI Company in Saratoga Springs, NY and New York City, NY. Recent Acting Credits include: Ben Affleck, Matt & Ben (Fancy Bits Theatre), Chris, Be Our Ally (Sheatre), Tilly, Melancholy Play (The Empty Room Collective), Brutus, Julius Caesar (Spur-of-the-Moment Shakespeare), The Bundle (Sheep No Wool), Lady Macbeth, Macbeth (Ale House Theatre), Lady Mortimer, König Heinrich der Vierte (Shakespeare im Park Berlin). Upcoming: Snow Queen at Theatre New Brunswick.

Eva’s writing has been supported by Tarragon Theatre, Theatre Gargantua, Shakespeare in the Ruff, DaPoPo Theatre, the Toronto Arts Council, the Ontario Arts Council and the Canada Council for the Arts.   

Earl Pastko (playing Thomas)

Earl was born and raised in Chicago where he began his theatrical career, coming to Toronto in 1983 to work with Steven Rumbelow (Triple ActionTheatre) and returning in 1985 permanently. He has worked extensively in theatre and with noted directors Ken McDougall, Paul Bettis, Alexander Hausvater, Morris Panych, Sky Gilbert, Brian Quirt, Vikki Anderson and Alan Dilworth. He has received a DORA nomination for his performance in LA RONDE and a JESSIE Ensemble nomination for THE ENDS OF THE EARTH. Earl has also worked extensively in Film & Television - notably as Satan in Bruce McDonald's Highway 61, as Harley Otis in Atom Egoyan's The Sweet Hereafter, as the artist in Jeremy Podeswa's Eclipse, and the Hotel Detective in David Weaver's Century Hotel. He has also worked with Eugene Levy (Sodbusters), George A. Romero (The Land of the Dead) and Roger Christian (Masterminds & Battlefield Earth). Among his many TV credits are appearances in Street Legal, Poltergeist, Stargate, Lexx, Murdoch Mysteries, Orphan Black and Hemlock Grove.

Ben Sanders (playing Peter)

Ben Sanders is a Toronto-based actor. He has performed at the Shaw Festival for seven seasons, appearing in 14 productions, including The Intelligent Homosexual’s Guide to Capitalism and Socialism with the Key to the Scriptures, The Sea, Major Barbara, Cabaret, Our Betters, French without Tears, Misalliance, Serious Money, and four world premieres: Michel Marc Bouchard’s The Divine: A Play for Sarah Bernhardt, Peter Hinton and Allen Cole’s musical version of Alice in Wonderland, Lisa Codrington’s adaptation of The Adventures of the Black Girl in Her Search for God, and Michael Healey’s reimagining of On the Rocks. He also performed with The Grand Theatre (A Christmas Carol, Dry Streak, Playwright’s Cabaret) and with Toronto’s Praxis Theatre (Objections to Sex and Violence, Tim Buck 2). In 2015, he was named one of NOW Magazine’s Top 10 Theatre Artists of the year, and the MyTheatre Awards Performer of the Year. He trained at Ryerson University. Up next, Ben will be back at the Grand Theatre in The Lion in Winter.

Thomas Morgan Jones (Dramaturge)

Thomas is an award winning director, playwright, movement coach, dramaturg, and teacher. For over 15 years he has created theatre nationally and internationally with companies and schools that include: The Stratford Festival, Theatre Direct, Theatre Passe Muraille, The Charlottetown Festival, Carousel Players, Cia Enviezada (Brazil), NTS, Sheridan, and The Randolph Academy. He holds a BA from Guelph, an MA from UofT, and has trained with SITI Company in NYC/Madrid/Paris and SCOT in Japan and Italy.

Théa Pel (Stage Manager)

Théa is a stage manager/teaching artist from Stratford, Ontario. She is currently finishing up her second season at the Shaw Festival. She holds a Bachelor of Arts Honours in Drama and Linguistics and a Bachelor of Education, both from Queen's University.  Selected production credits include Sweeney Todd, Our Town, Peter and the Starcatcher, Top Girls, The Next Whisky Bar (Shaw Festival) Armide, Persée (Opera Atelier, Château de Versailles Tour), Abduction from the Seraglio (Opera Atelier), A Christmas Carol (Soulpepper), She Loves Me, Educating Rita (Thousand Islands Playhouse). She has held teaching practicums at Shakespeare’s Globe and the National Portrait Gallery in London, England.

Karyn McCallum (Set and Costume Designer)

In the past decade Karyn has designed in theatres across Canada ranging from major regional theatres to artist co-ops, including; Tarragon Theatre, Canadian Stage, National Arts Centre, Globe Theatre, GCTC, Persephone and Gateway Theatre. Her work extends across three design disciplines: set, costume and projection.  Karyn maintains an active research agenda which in recent years has involved her in developing interactive multimedia performance work with the Digital Dramaturgy Lab as well as having worked as an assistant to Michael Levine over the course of the design of two operas. Always interested in exploring different forms of artistic process, Karyn participated in an internship with the Wooster Group during the development of their interpretation of Harold Pinter’s The Room. Karyn is a recent recipient of the SATAward for outstanding set design and the Pauline McGibbon award for design. Karyn holds an MFA in theatre design from the University of Victoria, is a member and former board member of the ADC.

Mikael Kangas (Lighting Designer)

Mikael designs lights for theatre of all types and events. Mikael’s recent work includes: Directors Project (Shaw Festival), Sweeney Todd, Alice in Wonderland, Woman of No Importance, Twelve Pound Look,Top Girls, Lady from the Sea (Shaw Festival, assistant), Aladdin (Mirvish/Disney, PA), CATS(Mirvish, assistant) Barber of Seville, Merry Widow (Opera York), Peter Pan (Yellow Door), Full House!(Starvox) NINE (Randolph), Melancholy Play (Empty Room Collective), Waiting Room (Helix Dance Project). Mikael has assisted at Mirvish, Shaw Festival, Tarragon Theatre, Toronto Symphony Orchestra, Theatre Calgary, Opera Lyra, the National Ballet School of Canada and Banff Centre amongst others. Mikael is a graduate of Ryerson University and an associate member of the Associated Designers of Canada.

Noah Spitzer (Artistic Producer, Production Manager)

Noah Spitzer is an actor, theatre producer, and educator who holds a BFA (Honours) in Theatre: Performance Acting from Ryerson University. Since graduating, Noah has toured his highly acclaimed solo show, My Second Smile, across the country, from schools in Vancouver, Ottawa, and Richmond Hill, to the Factory Studio Theatre in Toronto, and to the 2013 Ottawa Fringe Festival. Past acting credits include Jem in To Kill a Mockingbird at Young People’s Theatre (Dora Award Nomination: Outstanding Ensemble, Theatre for Young Audiences) and Chorus in Yichud (Convergence/ Theatre Passe Muraille). He worked as both actor and producer on several successful indie productions, including Romeo and Juliet (Old Flame Brewing Company), The Four of Us  (Arts Court Ottawa), Two Noble Kinsmen (Kinsmen Collective), and Speed-the-Plow (33 Laurel Productions). As an educator, he has been a Teaching Assistant at Ryerson University and Young People's Theatre, as well as a guest artist at the elementary, secondary, and post-secondary level. Most recently, he played the role of young George Brady in Hana's Suitcase at Young People's Theatre.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Follow us on Facebook and Twitter (@yellrebelTO) so that you’ll get updates about the show, our team and our fundraiser!

Help us spread the word about this amazing play by using the Indiegogo share tools!

If you know any businesses that are looking for partnership opportunities, let us know by emailing us at yellrebeltheatre@gmail.com!

Mark your calendars for our Opening Night on November 10th!  We’d love to have you there!

 

A Huge Thank You To Those Who Helped With This Video!

DREW BERRY! She was our DOP extraordinaire for the trailer!

SIMON MIMINIS!  Simon composed this beautiful music!  To hear other scores he has created, visit: http://www.simonmiminis.com/

ALYSSA MARTIN! From background performer to production assistant on set (not to mention designing yellrebeltheatre.com and being the Artistic Director of Rock Bottom Movement), she does it all!
story_txt: Set in present-day Berlin and 1980s Divided Berlin, AGENCY investigates the relationship between the communist vs. post-Wall generation while exploring, intimacy in lonely human-beings, and the walls we build around ourselves.It is with great pleasure that Yell Rebel presents Eva Barrie’s Agency.  Why support Agency?If you've been following our #KeepContemporary series on Twitter (@YellRebelTO) you may have noticed we've been showcasing directors/companies who support new works. Why? Because that's what keeps Toronto moving forward! They allow our multi-cultural audiences to feel represented. Agency does just that. Canada is a nation of immigrants, so why doesn’t our theatre reflect this? We live in a globalised world. Events that happen far away effect us either directly or, in the case of Agency, indirectly, through inherited trauma.  Our citizens stories don’t always begin on Canadian soil, so let’s celebrate what makes this country unique, by hearing all of our stories! Get in on the ground floor of a World Premiere! Agency has never gone to production, but, in 2015, it was selected by Halifax’s DaPoPo Theatre for a staged reading in their National Live-In Series and appeared alongside works from Sharon Pollock and Guillermo Verdecchia. One audience member commented, "being a child of the Cold War, born in an Eastern Bloc country with parents who defected, I was impressed with the emotional truth of this play. In particular, the complexity of relationships with informants who are also friends is true. The research is impeccable." We Need Your Help To Bring Agency to Life!Thanks to generous funding from the Canada Council for the Arts and the Ontario Arts Council, we are able to put our initial funding towards what matters most to us: our artists. With our grant money, we have been able to secure honorariums for all our artists.However, we’ve still got a ways to go! We are busily working to raise $5000 to cover necessities like insurance fees (to keep everyone safe), marketing costs (to make sure we have an audience to perform to) and equipment rental (so our Lighting/Sound Designers don’t have to sit to the side of the stage and explain what they WOULD HAVE done if we could afford their gadgets).The $3000 raised in this campaign will be dedicated to:Paying the rental fee for our performance venue, the hub of innovative Canadian theatre: The Theatre Centre ($2400).Making our set sparkle! We have a stellar team of designers with us, and Set/Costume Designer Karyn McCallum can’t do her magic without a wee bit of green. Help us help Karyn!Every penny we make after the $5000 will go straight into the artist’s pockets. So, we’d like to introduce…. The Artists Megan Watson (Director)Megan is a director/theatre creator from Ottawa who makes Toronto her home. She just completed a season at The Grand Theatre in London, Ontario as the Apprentice Artistic Director/Artistic Associate where she assisted on main-stage productions, worked with local playwrights and directed a production of Julius Caesar with the spring High School Project. She holds an MFA in directing from the University of Alberta and a BFA in acting from Ryerson University. Select directing credits include: Extremophiles (Architect Theatre) Far Away  (PreShow Playlist), Crookback -a solo adaptation of Richard III (Beacon Theatre / touring), When the Rain Stops Falling, Much Ado About Nothing, Hear and Now (University of Alberta) The Queer Bathroom Stories (Buddies in Bad Times Theatre), Derailed (AMY Projects), As Is and Bent (Theatre Engine). Megan has also had the pleasure of assistant directing for some of Canada’s top directors including Eda Holmes, Richard Greenblatt, Micheline Chevrier and Susan Ferley. Upcoming projects: She will be returning to The Grand for a second season under new Artistic Director Dennis Garnhum.Eva Barrie (Playwright, playing Hannah)Originally from Okotoks, Alberta, Eva is a Toronto-based director, actor and creator and has created art in Germany, India, Italy, Poland, Canada and the United States. She is a graduate of Ryerson University’s Performance Acting Program and has trained with Anne Bogart’s SITI Company in Saratoga Springs, NY and New York City, NY. Recent Acting Credits include: Ben Affleck, Matt & Ben (Fancy Bits Theatre), Chris, Be Our Ally (Sheatre), Tilly, Melancholy Play (The Empty Room Collective), Brutus, Julius Caesar (Spur-of-the-Moment Shakespeare), The Bundle (Sheep No Wool), Lady Macbeth, Macbeth (Ale House Theatre), Lady Mortimer, König Heinrich der Vierte (Shakespeare im Park Berlin). Upcoming: Snow Queen at Theatre New Brunswick.Eva’s writing has been supported by Tarragon Theatre, Theatre Gargantua, Shakespeare in the Ruff, DaPoPo Theatre, the Toronto Arts Council, the Ontario Arts Council and the Canada Council for the Arts.   Earl Pastko (playing Thomas)Earl was born and raised in Chicago where he began his theatrical career, coming to Toronto in 1983 to work with Steven Rumbelow (Triple ActionTheatre) and returning in 1985 permanently. He has worked extensively in theatre and with noted directors Ken McDougall, Paul Bettis, Alexander Hausvater, Morris Panych, Sky Gilbert, Brian Quirt, Vikki Anderson and Alan Dilworth. He has received a DORA nomination for his performance in LA RONDE and a JESSIE Ensemble nomination for THE ENDS OF THE EARTH. Earl has also worked extensively in Film & Television - notably as Satan in Bruce McDonald's Highway 61, as Harley Otis in Atom Egoyan's The Sweet Hereafter, as the artist in Jeremy Podeswa's Eclipse, and the Hotel Detective in David Weaver's Century Hotel. He has also worked with Eugene Levy (Sodbusters), George A. Romero (The Land of the Dead) and Roger Christian (Masterminds & Battlefield Earth). Among his many TV credits are appearances in Street Legal, Poltergeist, Stargate, Lexx, Murdoch Mysteries, Orphan Black and Hemlock Grove.Ben Sanders (playing Peter) Ben Sanders is a Toronto-based actor. He has performed at the Shaw Festival for seven seasons, appearing in 14 productions, including The Intelligent Homosexual’s Guide to Capitalism and Socialism with the Key to the Scriptures, The Sea, Major Barbara, Cabaret, Our Betters, French without Tears, Misalliance, Serious Money, and four world premieres: Michel Marc Bouchard’s The Divine: A Play for Sarah Bernhardt, Peter Hinton and Allen Cole’s musical version of Alice in Wonderland, Lisa Codrington’s adaptation of The Adventures of the Black Girl in Her Search for God, and Michael Healey’s reimagining of On the Rocks. He also performed with The Grand Theatre (A Christmas Carol, Dry Streak, Playwright’s Cabaret) and with Toronto’s Praxis Theatre (Objections to Sex and Violence, Tim Buck 2). In 2015, he was named one of NOW Magazine’s Top 10 Theatre Artists of the year, and the MyTheatre Awards Performer of the Year. He trained at Ryerson University. Up next, Ben will be back at the Grand Theatre in The Lion in Winter.Thomas Morgan Jones (Dramaturge) Thomas is an award winning director, playwright, movement coach, dramaturg, and teacher. For over 15 years he has created theatre nationally and internationally with companies and schools that include: The Stratford Festival, Theatre Direct, Theatre Passe Muraille, The Charlottetown Festival, Carousel Players, Cia Enviezada (Brazil), NTS, Sheridan, and The Randolph Academy. He holds a BA from Guelph, an MA from UofT, and has trained with SITI Company in NYC/Madrid/Paris and SCOT in Japan and Italy.Théa Pel (Stage Manager)Théa is a stage manager/teaching artist from Stratford, Ontario. She is currently finishing up her second season at the Shaw Festival. She holds a Bachelor of Arts Honours in Drama and Linguistics and a Bachelor of Education, both from Queen's University.  Selected production credits include Sweeney Todd, Our Town, Peter and the Starcatcher, Top Girls, The Next Whisky Bar (Shaw Festival) Armide, Persée (Opera Atelier, Château de Versailles Tour), Abduction from the Seraglio (Opera Atelier), A Christmas Carol (Soulpepper), She Loves Me, Educating Rita (Thousand Islands Playhouse). She has held teaching practicums at Shakespeare’s Globe and the National Portrait Gallery in London, England.Karyn McCallum (Set and Costume Designer)In the past decade Karyn has designed in theatres across Canada ranging from major regional theatres to artist co-ops, including; Tarragon Theatre, Canadian Stage, National Arts Centre, Globe Theatre, GCTC, Persephone and Gateway Theatre. Her work extends across three design disciplines: set, costume and projection.  Karyn maintains an active research agenda which in recent years has involved her in developing interactive multimedia performance work with the Digital Dramaturgy Lab as well as having worked as an assistant to Michael Levine over the course of the design of two operas. Always interested in exploring different forms of artistic process, Karyn participated in an internship with the Wooster Group during the development of their interpretation of Harold Pinter’s The Room. Karyn is a recent recipient of the SATAward for outstanding set design and the Pauline McGibbon award for design. Karyn holds an MFA in theatre design from the University of Victoria, is a member and former board member of the ADC.Mikael Kangas (Lighting Designer)Mikael designs lights for theatre of all types and events. Mikael’s recent work includes: Directors Project (Shaw Festival), Sweeney Todd, Alice in Wonderland, Woman of No Importance, Twelve Pound Look,Top Girls, Lady from the Sea (Shaw Festival, assistant), Aladdin (Mirvish/Disney, PA), CATS(Mirvish, assistant) Barber of Seville, Merry Widow (Opera York), Peter Pan (Yellow Door), Full House!(Starvox) NINE (Randolph), Melancholy Play (Empty Room Collective), Waiting Room (Helix Dance Project). Mikael has assisted at Mirvish, Shaw Festival, Tarragon Theatre, Toronto Symphony Orchestra, Theatre Calgary, Opera Lyra, the National Ballet School of Canada and Banff Centre amongst others. Mikael is a graduate of Ryerson University and an associate member of the Associated Designers of Canada.Noah Spitzer (Artistic Producer, Production Manager)Noah Spitzer is an actor, theatre producer, and educator who holds a BFA (Honours) in Theatre: Performance Acting from Ryerson University. Since graduating, Noah has toured his highly acclaimed solo show, My Second Smile, across the country, from schools in Vancouver, Ottawa, and Richmond Hill, to the Factory Studio Theatre in Toronto, and to the 2013 Ottawa Fringe Festival. Past acting credits include Jem in To Kill a Mockingbird at Young People’s Theatre (Dora Award Nomination: Outstanding Ensemble, Theatre for Young Audiences) and Chorus in Yichud (Convergence/ Theatre Passe Muraille). He worked as both actor and producer on several successful indie productions, including Romeo and Juliet (Old Flame Brewing Company), The Four of Us  (Arts Court Ottawa), Two Noble Kinsmen (Kinsmen Collective), and Speed-the-Plow (33 Laurel Productions). As an educator, he has been a Teaching Assistant at Ryerson University and Young People's Theatre, as well as a guest artist at the elementary, secondary, and post-secondary level. Most recently, he played the role of young George Brady in Hana's Suitcase at Young People's Theatre. Other Ways You Can HelpFollow us on Facebook and Twitter (@yellrebelTO) so that you’ll get updates about the show, our team and our fundraiser!Help us spread the word about this amazing play by using the Indiegogo share tools!If you know any businesses that are looking for partnership opportunities, let us know by emailing us at yellrebeltheatre@gmail.com!Mark your calendars for our Opening Night on November 10th!  We’d love to have you there! A Huge Thank You To Those Who Helped With This Video!DREW BERRY! She was our DOP extraordinaire for the trailer!SIMON MIMINIS!  Simon composed this beautiful music!  To hear other scores he has created, visit: http://www.simonmiminis.com/ALYSSA MARTIN! From background performer to production assistant on set (not to mention designing yellrebeltheatre.com and being the Artistic Director of Rock Bottom Movement), she does it all!

story:
Lilliana is trying to raise $1000.00 so she can compete in a dance solo next year.  

Competition solos are a great chance for a dancer, such as Lilliana, to get one-on-one attention, be highlighted in their best style of dance under the choreographer of their choice, and receive unique stage experience, as they entertain a crowd alone and receive feedback from judges.  


The funds raised will be used as follows:

  • $400 will go to the choreographer
  • $500 for entry fees for 5 competitions & conventions
  • $100 for the costume


Lilliana has been dancing for almost all of her life, since she was three and she has been on a competitive team for almost five years.


Help Lilliana accomplish her goals!

story:
We are Three Hearts Dance, a story telling dance company committed to sharing testimonies of life, hope, and encouragement! We are creating relevant art with expressions based off of life experiences—the good, the bad, and the miraculous steps of our journey that are the building blocks of our lives. While some of the experiences are messy or heartbreaking; others have come with ease, excitement and refreshment. We have a heart to relate to audiences with these expressions. To share our stories, we want to create intimate showcases featuring dance concept videos and live performances that are both entertaining and thought provoking. The development of the concept videos will allow us to take our stories into almost any setting that cannot accommodate live performance, as well as create online viewing opportunities for non-local audiences. 

Some examples of our planned video projects include:

-Rebuilding the ability to trust after a betrayal

-Facing the causes of addiction

-Weighing the cost of a committed relationship

By staging intimate settings for performances and video viewings, we are creating an atmosphere in which dancers and audience members can interact directly, which is an important part of our company's purpose. We want to engage audiences not only through our art, but through a shared passion of the stories behind the dance. In each setting, dancers will share testimonies involved in the creation of the dance works, allowing the audience to form their own connection with both the dance and the dancers.

To see these stories come to life and engage audiences, please consider donating to our Indiegogo! Funds raised here will be used for project creation (video production costs, performance hosting costs, etc.) and admin costs (the paperwork involved in making creativity happen). While our dancers, choreographers, and consultant leaders are currently volunteering their time and skill in rehearsal and production, we are contracting with videographers, photographers, and venues to make these visions a reality. Thank you for partnering with us as we join together in the next chapter of our story!

story:
MPA Project Summary

My name is Yvonne Montoya. I am a mother, dancer/choreographer, and the MPA project (a dance film, blog, and earring collection) is my first ever solo project; a project seven years in the making.

The Motherhood and the Performing Arts (MPA) Project was born out of my desire to dedicate more of my time and energies to my son. Last year, while neck deep into a multi-year, multi-faceted visual and performing arts project with a heavy community engagement component, I realized I had dedicated a large amount of my life to growing and nurturing a company, frequently at the expense of quality time I could have spent with my son. Both my son and my company are seven years old.  I decided then that I would take a break from my company and create work centered around my son and my role as a mother. Thus was born the MPA project. This project is a reflection of the challenges and joys of juggling motherhood and a career in the performing arts.

The MPA project has three main components:

  1. A dance film that will be shot in the marginal and, often intimate, spaces where my career and role as a mother brush up against each other.
  2. A blog with reflections from the past seven years.
  3. An earring collection complete with block and puzzle earrings created from the lost and left over toys I am constantly stepping on in the hallway.

I Need Your Help!

  • This project needs at least $900 to cover the production costs of the dance film that is scheduled to be shot on location the third week of April 2016. 
  • In the case that the goal is not reached, all donations will still go towards the production costs for the dance film.

Take home YOUR Piece of the MPA Project!!

  • Did I mention the earring collection? That is the part of the MPA Project that is specifically for YOU! All earrings in the collection are available by donation to the project. The earrings are made from the little block pieces I am constatnly stepping on or accidentally vaccuming up or all the lost puzzle pieces found at the bottom of toy boxes and behind bookshelves.
  • All earrings are HANDMADE (by me!), UP CYCLED, and approved by my son! 
  • Check it out and donate today!

The Impact

This project is important because there is an under representation of artist mothers and artist parents creating work both in the performing arts and in the art world in general. The world needs art created by people who are raising and have raised children! 

I chose to do this project as a dance film because the project will have a life beyond the performance and can be shared with different communities of working mothers, working parents, and working artists. I envision the dance film to be a spring board for discussion about artist parents. Likewise, the MPA blog is a platform for discussion about issues surrounding working mothers and working parents and the popular model of artist living that is highly unsustainable.
And because Indiegogo is asking me to say this, I have six years experience successfully directing and producing performing arts projects (site-specific and site-adaptive work, work with a large community engagement component, and the regular old dance-in-a-theater productions). That work can be found at safosdance.org and on the Safos youtube and vimeo channels.

Other Ways YOU Can Help

  • Help get the word out! Share the campaign with artist mothers and artists partents who might be intersted or share with anyone who may want some block or puzzle earrings!
  • Read and share the blog!
  • If you are a parent and have lost blocks or puzzle pieces or other small toy items laying around the house, feel free to donate them to the MPA project! They will be added to the earring collection.
  • Host an MPA project party for your friends in your community! Contact me for more information on this one.
  • Share via the Indiegogo share tools!

THANK YOU for supporting artists and artist mothers!

story:
"My Pretty Loathsome" Workshop 2018

Your support will help us bring new work by young artists to life. "My Pretty Loathsome" is the story of a young woman in prison for witchcraft and her journey through her own past.  A new work by a female playwright/creator/director as well as a cast that features primarily femme roles! Thank you in advance for your support! This project is brought to you by Theatre out of Breath in co production with Floral Theatre. Your support provides: artist fees, venues+rehearsal space + production costs!

Theatre Out of Breathe is a Vancouver based company and Floral Theatre originated in Ottawa. Both companies share an interest in creating work by and for young artist. Thanks to Arts Club (Vancouver), we are able to kickstart this project, and your contributions would help us fund the next stages of this exciting work. 

What We Need

  • Our goal is $800
  • This will cover
    • compensating our committed actors and creative team
    • renting rehearsal and performance spaces
    • paying for an onstage intimacy workshop in order to raise the bar for what we expect in rehearsal rooms across the country

Other Ways You Can Help

We would love to see your smiling face at our show! Performances August 3+4 2018. More details to follow on our Facebook page: Floral Theatre, our Instagram/Twitter: @floraltheatre.

We would really appreciate you sharing our Indiegogo campaign as well as promotions for the show!

Thank you in advance!

story:
"A Touch of Ivory" - Costume Showcase 2018

Short Summary

The Queen Margaret University BA (Hons) Costume Course is a three to four-year degree in costume making, designing, hat and mask making, puppetry and many other aspects of working in the costume sector backstage or on screen. The university is situated in Musselburgh, just outside of Edinburgh, but welcomes students from all over the world.

Our showcase this year takes place in the beautiful St Cecilia's Hall, where everyone can come and see the students work from level 1 to graduation. As it is us students organising the event, we have to find our own funding, technicians, printers etc. etc.

With your help, we can showcase our work and ourselves in the best way possible. For the graduates of this course, the event is also their degree show and stepping stone into the industry and job world, which makes this event even more important to us. 

What We Need & What You Get

Currently, we are trying to raise £1000 for our event and with your contribution, we could make this event truly historical! No matter how much we raise, we will use your funds to enhance our event in some way.

Your money would go towards getting qualified lighting and sound technicians or setting up an interesting, professional looking exhibition or creating nice costume prints to brighten up your living room wall.

In regards to our exhibition, we are wanting to go down the more digital path this year to make it look more polished, but also give you the chance of visiting the exhibition from your sofa!

We have some great perks up our puffy 1830s sleeves which will definitely make your contribution all the more special. If you want to get a peak of the preparations for this event or catch a glance of the progress of our costumes, follow the @QMUCostume instagram or facebook page! 
 

Other Ways You Can Help

If these amazing perks haven't convinced you yet, we are still thankful for any publication of our event and you spreading the word about this unusual catwalk in the heart of Edinburgh.

story:
Who Are We? -Circle Theatre

Circle is dedicated to providing excellent entertainment utilizing local West Michigan talent, both on stage and behind the scenes! 

WHAT WE DO

Each year we produce 3 musicals, 2 plays, 3 - 4 concerts, and 1 children's show. We kick off each season by bringing our audience 2 nights of amazing music, with appetizers and a drink included! In the past we have brought you, Circle Celebrates: The Music of Queen, The Music of Jesus Christ Superstar, and The Music of Woodstock! 

THIS YEAR

We are excited to bring you Circle Celebrates: The Music of Stephen Schwartz! You will have two chances to see this concert and it will truly have something for everyone as the genres range from Musical Theatre, to Rock, to selections from Disney movies! 

The Circle Theatre thrust space gives concert goers an up close, unique, and intimate concert experience.

WHY SHOULD YOU CARE?

This annual Circle Celebrates Kick Off is what puts our summer season into motion. Circle Celebrates is really our annual fundraiser that allows us to bring you extraordinary theatre that you will have a chance to see during the rest of the season. The more we can raise during this concert experience, the better our product will be all season long. We are asking you to help us cover the cost of this concert so we can put all revenue from it into bringing you quality entertainment all season long.

For more information visit: http://circletheatre.org/special-events/circle-celebrates-stephen-schwartz.html

What We Need & What You Get

The breakdown: 

  • We are asking you for $4950 to cover the cost of lighting, sound, projections, musician fees, director fees, and audience hospitality.
  • Depending on your contribution, perks will include: A free ticket to the event, 2014 summer concert tickets, 2014 Main Stage summer flex passes, a Circle Theatre t-shirt, and a backstage tour of the theatre! Please email vfalbo@circletheatre.org with your shirt details. See the perks section for more information.

  • If we do not reach our goal of $4950, we will still use all funds we do receive to pay for our wonderful and talented musicians. They are local talents and are the heart of this concert experience. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to make a contribution, but would still like to help Circle Theatre, please share our campaign efforts with your family and friends. Thank you!

See You Around The Circle!

story:
WELCOME

We're glad you're here! Take a look around and please make a donation. We need your support to make this show happen!

Overview

Sips & Scripts invites you to the first fully staged production of The Waning Hours by local playwright Carol Torian! This September, Alzheimer’s takes center stage in a play about Lorna Bray Tucker, a woman who is losing her grip on reality due to the disease. Lorna is present, yet absent as her memories become tangled and lost, and those closest to her struggle to come to terms with what is happening.  

The Story

After more than four decades of marriage, Lorna Bray Tucker’s husband Bernard leaves her for a younger lover. Lorna is still reeling from the divorce when she starts down a path of irreversible memory loss. Once an aspiring singer and amateur photographer, she now drifts between the present day and the past as her mind is ravaged by worsening Alzheimer’s disease. Her long-time housekeeper Madeline bears the brunt of Lorna’s frustrations and quarrelsome ways, while the disease threatens to physically and emotionally overwhelm her son Arlo. Lorna’s forgetfulness and dementia also offer a glimpse of her younger self. Through vivid hallucinations, a  22-year-old Lorna emerges. She is fresh from the South and living in 1960s civil rights era Philadelphia. Lorna works a thankless job at the phone company and forms a singing group with her roommates. The trio is enamored of Diana Ross and The Supremes, and longs to appear on stage at the Apollo Theater in Harlem. Unfortunately, their lazy manager only books seedy nightclub gigs. Most of which pay little or nothing at all. Yearning for more, a talented, idealistic and naïve Lorna pieces together a life of hopes and dreams that slowly unravel over the years, bringing her to this moment.

Featuring an African-American cast and directed by Terra Hodge, The Waning Hours is a series of vignettes that attempt to mirror the thought process of someone who is suffering from moderate Alzheimer’s disease. The play is set entirely in Lorna's kitchen—the one place in a house where time matters most. And it here that we discover the songs that serve as an enduring reminder of who Lorna once was and who she might have become if she'd made different choices. This emotionally-charged play is tinged with disappointment and loss, but  woven with hints of humor, drawing us deeper and deeper into Lorna's mind.  

Check out the special PERKS for your chance to meet the cast and crew, and name-a-seat, grab a magazine subscription, take a photography lesson and more... You may need to click the reward square to see the full contents. We appreciate your support!

Show Dates:

  • Friday, September 18th - Sunday, September 20th,
  • Thursday, September 24th - Sunday, September 27th

Location: Pure Life Theatre, 3801 Hillsborough Street, Raleigh, North Carolina 27607

What is Alzheimer’s?

The Alzheimer’s Association reports that every 65 seconds someone in the United States develops Alzheimer’s.

Named for Dr. Alois Alzheimer, Alzheimer’s disease is an irreversible, progressive brain disorder that slowly destroys memory and thinking skills and, eventually, the ability to carry out the simplest tasks. In most people with the disease—those with the late-onset type—symptoms first appear in their mid-60s. Early-onset Alzheimer’s occurs between a person’s 30s and mid-60s and is very rare. Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia among older adults. Source: Source: NIH National Institute on Aging

The Alzheimer’s Association estimates that 5.8 million Americans are living with Alzheimer’s. More than 16 million Americans provide unpaid care for people with Alzheimer’s or other dementias. The Alzheimer’s journey is unique for every family, and while there is currently no cure for the disease, research continues.

Did you know?... September is World Alzheimer's MONTH. World Alzheimer's Month is the international campaign every September to raise awareness and challenge the stigma that surrounds dementia. The campaign was launched in 2012: World Alzheimer's DAY is on September 21st each year.

Who’s Involved? 

Female Playwright. Female Director. Female Producer.

The Waning Hours is produced by Sips & Scripts, a platform for North Carolina playwrights that supports, promotes and produces their work. From monthly group script readings to public staged readings to fully staged productions, Sips & Scripts founder Yvette Holder works to foster meaningful interactions between playwrights and audiences.

We are putting together an amazing team for The Waning Hours production. Terra Hodge is the director for the show. Some of her directorial credits include Caroline or Change (Justice Theatre Project), The Amen Corner (Agape Theatre), and Crowns (Raleigh Little Theatre).  Terra has also written, produced, and directed several short films.  Her film Torn was screened at the 2013 National Black Theatre Festival in Winston-Salem, North Carolina.

Playwright Carol Torian is from North Carolina. Productions of her work have included Cracked Grain for Cary Playwrights’ Forum and Ruby Slipper Fringe Festival; The Waning Hours (Staged Reading) for Ruby Slipper Fringe Festival and Sips & Scripts and the Burning Coal New Works Series; The Traditionalists for Cary Playwrights’ Forum and the Women’s Theatre Festival; and Previously Owned for The Flying Embers Winter Pajama Party and the Raleigh Film & Art Festival. Carol’s work crisscrosses racial, cultural, and socioeconomic boundaries to promote understanding, appreciation and awareness. She was inspired to write The Waning Hours because her paternal grandmother suffered with Alzheimer’s for over a decade. 

Watch for updates about the cast and crew on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/sipsandscripts/

Where your funds will go… 

Creating engaging, thought-provoking theatre is very important to us. Your support, in addition to in-kind donations and collaborative partnerships, will fund the best production design, sound design, orchestration, choreography and costumes! 

Performance space and rehearsal space. This covers the performance space, front-of-house services, lighting and sound equipment, etc.

Set design and construction. The set is going to be fantastic!

Costumes. We will work with our collaborative partners to source as many costumes as possible but anticipate that we will need to acquire some additional items to fill out the cast wardrobe.

Personnel. It takes a lot of people to stage a show. There are seven performances in this run of The Waning Hours, plus rehearsals. We are incredibly grateful to the actors, director, sound designer, lighting designer, costume designer, choreographer and stage manager who will bring this show to life. We want to be able to pay them something for their time and enormous effort.

Marketing. We appreciate the advertising that Pure Life Theatre does to promote upcoming performances, but ultimately, it is our responsibility to market our show to bring in audiences. 

The Perks

We’re offering a great selection of rewards in exchange for your support.  You may need to click the reward square to see the full contents. 

The Venue

A huge thank you to Pure Life Theatre and Deb Royals for providing us with a place to play. Pure Life Theatre is located in The Royal Baking Company on Hillsborough Street in Raleigh. Built in 1941 and expanded in 1946-1947, the building was devised by W.E. Long Company of Chicago and built by the local construction firm of James A. Davidson. The Royal Baking Company building joined the National Register of Historic Places in 1997. The building was redeveloped in 2000, and now houses a collection of tenants.

Ticket sales start on February 22, 2020, at Brown Paper Tickets!                                          The Waning Hours https://waninghours.brownpapertickets.com/

Show Dates:  

  • Friday, September 18th - Sunday, September 20th,
  • Thursday, September 24th - Sunday, September 27th

 

How You Can Help

  • Make a contribution! Any amount helps and is appreciated.
  • Share the campaign on your social media platforms and via e-mail.
  • Tell people why you’re excited about The Waning Hours and encourage them to contribute and attend the show.
  • Follow us on Facebook and join the Sips & Scripts e-mail list.
  • Be a volunteer greeter at the show and help us distribute information about Alzheimer’s to patrons.
  • Come to the show and bring friends and family and colleagues!

 

Thank you so much for your support of this project! We look forward to seeing you at a performance of The Waning Hours in September!

story:
Short(form) Summary

Dangerfield started as all good improv groups do - with a dream and a scheduling email chain. After assembling 8 dope af strong, funny women, the group began rehearsing, performing, and debating a team name (Stryker, Orange Slices). Now, 4 years later, we've performed up and down the East Coast, headlined festivals, and are ready to take our yonic style overseas.

What We Need & What You Get

We need money.

Quick breakdown of expenses:

  • Flights (8 girls in NYC and Boston x roundtrip flights to Scotland) = $3,440
  • Hotel (8 girls with PARTICULAR needs x 3 nights of Airbnb's finest) = $600
  • Rental Car (8 girls x 1 car jkjkjk 2 cars x 3 days) = $300
  • Beer (8 girls x 8 Miller High Lifes x 3 days) = $100
  • Total = $4,440

Quick breakdown of what we're asking you for:

  • $2,500. We understand improv comedy requires sacrifice. So meet us halfish way. Help us get to Scotland! Help Ashley meet a hot Scot and Amy see the Northern Lights.

PERK ALERT

  • Baby, you're getting some prizes for your $$$.
  • $5 - We will publicly acknowledge how much we like and appreciate you
  • $10 - A video thank you, from a hot tub in Glencoe (Scotland!!!)
  • $20 - gotdamn did someone say, swag? Pins baby. (Kristina designed em, so you want em)
  • $30- ya getting some MORE swag, stickies (^^^)
  • $50 - SWAG CENTRAL - ya getting all the pins and pins and stickers AND a postcard from Scotland and maybe that vid in the tub.
  • $69 - We hang out with you. It's a date, but it probably won't end in sex, sry.
  • $75 - WORKSHOPS BABY. You and your comedy buds can go in together on your choice of IMPROV (Harold or Spokane), SKETCH that passes the Bechdel test, tighten up your STAND UP, or Francesca will teach you and a group how to take the PATH train. 
  • $100- Framed photo of Dangerfield (of our choosing) and ALL THE SWAG.
  • $250 and above- Whatever you want. We have particular skills.

The Impact

Here's the deal, this would me so much to us. We've done shows for 3 people in empty hostels and shows for 100+ in packed auditoriums. We've met women around the country who have said watching us perform inspired them to keep going, to try improv, or just be louder on and off stage. We support each other, love each other, and even give wedding toasts. We want to bring the heat to Scotland, and show folks that strong women also make strong improvisers.

It's what Del Close would have wanted.

Risks & Challenges

We're going to Scotland. The risk is, will we go broke on the way. Also here's a list of risks I wrote that are honest and true to Dangerfield:

  • Will Amy micromanage all travel until she resents the rest of the group?
  • Will Jen be too tall to fit in Scottish Air Bnbs?
  • Will Kristina give a compelling enough Spokane speech?
  • Will Francesca have the opportunity to play a convincing little boy?
  • Will Mina remember her passport?
  • Will Ashley meet a single, sexy Scottish man? Will we film a Mary Kate and Ashley Olsen style movie about their budding relationship?
  • Will Gloria see the northern lights?
  • Will Mary meet a best friend in her hostel?

story:
Trivia Puppet Company, in March 2020, will produce a full day special event of eight hours or more to be titled Puget Sound Puppetry Festival. The festival will provide a cultural service to an estimated 1200 King County residents with a focus on school children 6-18 years of age located in the Central District of Seattle. The festival will be celebrating World Day of Puppetry. We will also be presenting a summer series of Queer focused hand puppet comedy theatre with Peppercorn and friends! This live series will pop-up over 6 days in August of 2019 at various parks and beaches in Seattle with the intent to entertain and delight the queer community.

 

Our main goals with these projects are:

1. Provide puppetry to communities who may not traditionally attend due to access or economic conditions.

2. Provide work for practicing puppeteers.

3. raise awareness of and encourage participation in puppetry with the general populace. 

 

We have generous grant funding in place but are seeking to raise seed money to begin work on these projects.  As you know, must expenses are fronted and then reimbursed from the grant. The earliest we could start under that process would be August. We are seeking to offer early access to the festival, sponsorship opportunities for both the festival and the summer puppet series, as well as access to early advertising all at a discounted price. These funds will allow us to send in the deposits needed for the event and performers. We will also start pre-production work such as website, graphic design etc. 

The summer puppet series has to be constructed and built by late July. We would not be able to fund it with just revenue produced by our company. We would scale down the project if needed to make it happen on the weekends of August 2019.

 

The Festival is funded!  We are seeking early funding before tickets go on sale to get the pre-production work started. We will identify and seek sponsorships and advertising as we move forward. The festival is under contract to produce on the identified times.  The largest risk is scaling down payment it artists if we do not meet sponsorship goals.

 

We hope that you would like early access to these fun events or that they deserve your support as a business. 

 

Thank you,

Xx Dustin

story:
WHAT BEGAN AS "I" HAS TURNED INTO "WE" 

My name is Jessica DeSalva, a recent law school graduate. While in law school, I became a certified sexual assault counselor, working on a 24-hour hotline and as a hospital advocate. Over the past two years, I have worked with numerous victims even crossing over into human trafficking, and what I have realized is the lack of education that surrounds these topics. Due to the federal budget cuts, the non-profit organization, I volunteer with is going to lose its ENTIRE education and prevention program. Education is key to ending sexual violence, not something the federal government should be taking away. I have always lived by the quote "be the change you wish to see in this world" and I am taking action by putting together an entire production of The Vagina Monologues, as a fundraiser to save the program! What began as an individual mission, has turned into a group effort of other concerned community members to help with this effort.   WE have an entire cast of 18 ladies ready to perform, a venue, professional printing, and production crew ready! However, we are starting at a ZERO budget and we need your help to offset costs! I invite you all to be part of this change, to end sexual violence. 


We are raising money to host the Vagina Monologues on Friday, April 25th and Saturday, April 26th at The Frida Cinema as a larger fundraiser for Sexual Assault Victims' Services (SAVS), a branch of Community Service Programs' (CSP). SAVS serves as the one and only rape crisis center for Orange County. In addition to serving as advocates for victims in the courthouse, at the DA's office, in the hospital and on the hotline, SAVS also operates a prevention and education program. This program serves to help decrease sexual violence in the community and increase awareness. 

 WHY WE ARE HOSTING THE VAGINA MONOLOGUES 

SAVS just received awful news that their prevention program will not be funded next year! SAVS gets a large portion of its funding from the federal government and one important use of this funding has been to educate middle school, high school, and college students throughout Orange County about sexual violence under their prevention program. Due to various budget cuts from the federal government, SAVS will not have the crucial funding for their prevention services. The lack of prevention programming means that middle and high school students across Orange County will not receive valuable information about an important topic that affects ALL people. Knowledge is power and everyone deserves to be informed, especially in regards to their personal safety and the safety of those they know and love. 

To help SAVS maintain their prevention program we are hosting the Vagina Monologues, an episodic play written by Eve Ensler about the experiences of women. The Vagina Monologues consists of about 20 different monologues covering topics from childbirth and menstruation to consensual sex and rape; it is a roller coaster of emotions that range from funny to sad, but all together inspiring and eye opening. By hosting this event we hope to raise money to keep the prevention program open while increasing awareness, creating a sense of community and utilizing the arts as a medium of liberation and a vehicle of change. The Vagina Monologues is a part of the larger V-Day movement which is a global non-profit started and ran by Eve Ensler, herself. All of the proceeds from these productions will go directly to the cause. The first 90% will go to our local beneficiary, SAVS, and the remainder will go to the umbrella organization, V-Day. 

In addition to the play, each production will incorporate visual arts, culinary arts, and the business community. Visual art will be displayed at the productions and a silent auction will be held for the pieces. Culinary arts will be celebrated through food and drinks available during the event. Finally, supportive members of the business community will be on site with products for purchase.

 WHY PREVENTION AND EDUCATION IS NECESSARY 

Current statistics suggest that 1 in 4 women will be sexually assaulted in her lifetime. While this statistic points to the importance of prevention and education to increase the well-being of women, men are also impacted by sexual violence, both as victims and as friends, relatives, and partners of women. The issue of sexual violence is relevant to all communities and happens among individuals of any socioeconomic status, race, religion, and culture with devastating effects on individuals, families and communities. This is an issue that is receiving national attention; the Centers for Disease Control declared the issue of sexual violence a public health epidemic due to its widespread nature and devastating effects. The physical, emotional, spiritual, and mental pain, is too high.

SAVS education and prevention program speaks in almost every high school district in OC to talk about topics including but not limited to: cyber crimes (internet predators & sexting), sexual assault prevention, bystander intervention, stalking and healthy relationships. The program alters the above presentation to best fit the intended audience, whether it be high school students, at risk youth (i.e. LGBT teens, teens in a shelter, etc), college students, law enforcement, professionals, parents, and more. The program does hundreds of presentations a year to thousands of individuals. This program also contains Orange County’s Clothesline Project which as over 800+ t-shirts from survivors of violent crimes in Orange County (homicide, Human trafficking, sexual assault, domestic violence, etc).

These survivors need to feel loved, treasured and valued, for many SAVS provides assistance down this path. Without the validation and support they need and deserve, these people are more likely to experience other problems ranging from eating disorders to post traumatic stress disorder and so much more. 

WHAT WE NEED 

Our goal of $7000 is set to cover the costs of putting this production on 3 times in one weekend! This money will cover costs such as: venue rental, stage lighting, light and sound crew, printing, food and beverage, technical support and more. All proceeds above production costs will be donated directly to SAVS and V-Day.

Please take a moment to donate so we are able to host this production for the entire Orange County community! Please share this link with everyone you know, feel free to use the Indiegogo share tools! Help put a stop to this horrible crime and increase awareness. Every little bit helps and gets us one step closer to being able to put on this show and more importantly, keep the prevention program open! Then come join us at the show and have a good laugh and learn with us!

LIKE us on FaceBook:https://www.facebook.com/VDAYOC

For more information please visit our website: http://www.vdayoc.com  


· $15USD

VAGINA BELIEVER

Thank you for believing in The Vagina Monologues! Receive a public thank you on the VDayOC website.


·  $30USD

VAGINA GIVER

You took a few moments out of your busy day to give to vaginas in need. Receive the public thank you on the VDayOC website + Facebook shout-out!


·  $50USD

VAGINA ROCKSTAR!

You believe that we must come together as a community to end sexual violence across all genders, sexual preferences, socioeconomic statuses, races, religions and cultures! Receive a public thank you on the VDayOC website + Facebook shout-out + 1 “VDAY” mini campaign button.


·  $75USD

VAGINA CONNOISSEUR

You truly believe in the power of the community coming together to create change! Receive a public thank you on the VDayOC website +  Facebook shout-out + 1 “VDAY” mini campaign button + cast autographed program.

 

 

·  $150USD

VAGINA WARRIOR

You are a warrior- a fighter for human rights! Receive a public thank you on the VDayOC website + Facebook shout-out + 1 “VDAY” mini campaign button + cast autographed program + 1 business card size ad or message in program.

 

·  $300USD

VAGINA VISIONARY

Thank you so much for making a substantial commitment towards bringing this show to the OC community! Receive all of the above + a book give away of Eve Ensler's, The Vagina Monologues!
story_txt:
WHAT BEGAN AS "I" HAS TURNED INTO "WE" My name is Jessica
DeSalva, a recent law school graduate. While in law school, I became a
certified sexual assault counselor, working on a 24-hour hotline and as a
hospital advocate. Over the past two years, I have worked with numerous victims
even crossing over into human trafficking, and what I have realized is the lack
of education that surrounds these topics. Due to the federal budget cuts, the
non-profit organization, I volunteer with is going to lose its ENTIRE education
and prevention program. Education is key to ending sexual violence, not
something the federal government should be taking away. I have always lived by
the quote "be the change you wish to see in this world" and I am
taking action by putting together an entire production of The Vagina Monologues, as a fundraiser to save
the program! What began as an individual mission, has turned into a
group effort of other concerned community members to help with this effort.   WE have an entire cast of 18 ladies ready to perform, a
venue, professional printing, and production crew ready! However, we are
