story:
Mission Statement: Roving Roots is a no-to-low-budget production company developing and producing original work, untethered by place.  Roving Roots migrates, especially between Philadelphia, NYC, and the Pioneer Valley, requiring the ability to transport shows in a single cargo van. With that in mind, we work with minimal props and sets, depending, instead, on the script and the actors to fill the performance space and the imaginations of the audience.  While conceptually rooted in the tradition of a traveling theatre company, we are otherwise unbound by arbitrary restrictions of form, style, and content.Furthermore, as contemporary American theatre artists we also hold full-time jobs and have families that are dearly important to us, so we work in the time and space we can afford.  

Event Description:  In April 1984, Claire Stukel was brutal attacked.  When she wrongly identified the attacker, an innocent man, Gene Shephard, spent 17 years in prison, only to be released on DNA evidence in 2002.  His release forces Claire to reconsider all that she believes, including how to raise her son, Justin.  But as Claire struggles to forgive herself, the past comes back to victimize her anew, and Gene’s innocence isn’t as clear as it was the day he was released.

The creative team includes:

Kellye Rowland (Claire Stukel) is an actor and a relatively new East Coaster. She recently graduated as an Ada Comstock Scholar from Smith College with a B. A. in Theatre and Philosophy. Appearing on stage in every semester at Smith, Kellye performed inMoment, Habitat, Hedda Gabler, Macbeth,andThe Servant of Two Masters, among others, and upon graduation was awarded the 2013 Denton Snyder Acting Prize.  [Read Kellye’s complete bio here:http://rovingroots.com/kellye-rowland/]

Spencer Aste (Gene Shephard) is an experienced actor who has performed across the nation and internationally.  Spencer was recognized by NYTheatre.com as one of 2012's People Of The Year. He received his M.F.A. from the National Theater Conservatory in Denver, CO and his B.F.A. from the University of Utah.  [Read Spencer’s complete bio here:http://rovingroots.com/spencer-aste/]

Michael DeSantis (Justin Stukel) is an actor originally from Sarasota, Florida where he appeared in numerous productions at the Asolo Repertory Theatre and co-founded Abraxas Theatre Company. Since moving to New York, he has performed with The Looking Glass Theatre, A Festival of Fools, and Everybody Nose NYC. Notable roles include: Mercutio (Romeo and Juliet), Warren (This Is Our Youth), Gene (The Author's Voice), Valet (No Exit), Sebastian (Twelfth Night), and Prospero (Rough Magic). He is thrilled to be working with Roving Roots on this exciting new project.

Daniela Dakich (Pauline Lans) graduated from Drama Youth School, Acting Conservatory, HB Studio and UCB New York. Former child TV star performed in over 1000 stage productions. [Read Daniela’s complete bio here:http://rovingroots.com/daniela-dakich/]

G. Michelle Robinson (Forgive Us Our Trespasses) – Originally from Seattle, Michelle was one of the original cast members of the acclaimed stage production of Black To My Roots. That production went to the 2001 Edinburgh Fringe Festival, where it won a Fringe First Award. After that trip, she knew acting was going to be her career. Michelle moved to New York in 2004 to pursue her MFA and her dream of actually making a living doing something she loves. She’s halfway there.  [Read Michelle’s complete bio here:http://rovingroots.com/g-michelle-robinson/]

Jesse Kane-Hartnett(director) moved to Brooklyn after graduating with a BFA in Acting from Emerson College. He is a photographer, filmmaker, theater director and actor.

Favorite directing credits include Shared Intimacy, by Rose Martula, Sarah Haught and Troy Deutsch, Seascape with Sharks and Dancer, by Don Nigro, Advanced Programs System by Bella Poynton, and Rough Magic by Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa. [Read Jesse’s complete bio here:http://rovingroots.com/jesse-kane-hartnett/]

Mingyu Dong (Lighting Designer) was born and raised in Shanghai, China and came to US in 2009, ready for a brand new adventure. She graduated from Smith College in May with an B.A degree in Architecture and Urban Studies and is currently pursuing a Master of Architecture and an MFA in Lighting Design in Parsons The New School for Design. Although the focus of her undergraduate study was in architecture, she has always been interested in theatre design and has worked with amazing professors in Smith’s theatre department. She designed lighting for two pieces in Smith College Senior Dance Concert 2013, set and lighting for Black Dot and she worked as assistant lighting designer in Man of La Mancha during the summer of 2012. [Read Mingyu’s complete bio here:http://rovingroots.com/mingyu-dong/]

Jeffrey Stingerstein (playwright) is a theatre artist currently living in Philadelphia.  Some of his plays include: Where the Body Is Not(nominated for the Cherry Lane Mentor Project 2013, and a semifinalist for the Eugene O’Neill Theater Center’s 2012 National Playwrights Conference); Hear Me Pray (semifinalist for the 2013 National Playwrights Conference); and Martha Martinez Washington (semifinalist for the 2014 National Playwrights Conference).  His short plays “Weaving,” “Towed,” “Dinner with Peter and Polly,” and “Seeing and Being Seen” can be found on Indie Theatre Now.  [Read Jeff’s complete bio here:http://rovingroots.com/jeffrey-stingerstein/]

story:
Our Story

 

The Quickening Theatre is a non-profit entrepreneurial company that is dedicated to producing original, accessible and entertaining theatre of the highest merit. We believe in telling stories simply and truthfully. With humility and respect, we create an imaginative world that is both edifying and delightful.

 

The Impact

 

Developing and producing new work is expensive; the creation of original theatre requires skill, space and time. The money you donate to our company will contribute directly to the creation and production of a new piece of original Canadian theatre.

 

In 2009 we successfully produced Fish Face, winner of the 'Culchivating the Fringe Award' at the Vancouver International Fringe Festival. The award included a residency and week long production of the play at the Vancouver East Cultural Centre. Fish Face was named for Outstanding New Play, Outstanding Production, Outstanding Performance and Outstanding Design at the Fringe. Check out the 'making of' video: http://www.thequickeningtheatre.com/images--video.html

 

This year we are returning to the Vancouver Fringe with a brand new piece entitled The de Chardin Project:

 

Pierre Teillard de Chardin (1881-1955) was a Jesuit priest, a paleontologist, a world traveler, a soldier and a philosopher. Condemned by the Catholic Church for his ground-breaking discoveries in human evolution, his visionary ideas ultimately gave rise to the World Wide Web. From the origins of the universe to the very end, where "everything that rises must converge", The Quickening Theatre proudly premieres a daring tale of love, adventure and humanity.

 

The Vancouver Fringe Festival is an ideal forum for the production of new work, as the festival engenders a wonderfully supportive, inspired community of artists and celebrates the achievements of independent theatre. By premiering The de Chardin Project at in Vancouver this year, we will be better placed for future production and touring, and join a diverse community of independent theatre companies for mutual support and enrichment.

 

What We Need

 

Our campaign goal is $2500. With your support, we can bring our new play to Vancouver.

Your donation will fund:

 

1. Rehearsal studio rental (where we will devise, write and rehearse, $661).

 

2. The design and building of our set, costumes and props ($300).

 

3. Honorariums for Sound and Set Design collaborators ($200).

 

3. Our marketing and promotional materials ($100).

 

4. The cost of flights to Vancouver ($1200).

 

5. Accommodation while at the Festival ($500).

 

6. The Fringe Festival Fee ($750 for the performance venue, an experienced technician and promotion in the Fringe Program)

 

7. Equity Artist fees/Insurance ($84).

 

Total = $3795

 

The International Fringe Festivals ensure that the participating artists receive 100% of the box office revenue. The Canadian Actors Equity Association requires that this money be distributed equally between the artists after all expenses our paid. However, after expenses it is rare that any money is left to pay the artists who have given their time and skills for free. Your support will ensure that the artists are paid and that we will not be producing this show at a cost.

 

And there are PERKS!

 

We greatly appreciate your support. See the perks sidebar to see what tokens of appreciation we're offering you for your generous contribution.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

You can help us further by getting the word out!

 

Please share our links:

 

Website http://www.thequickeningtheatre.com,

Facebook  http://www.facebook.com/QuickeningTheatre

Twitter http://twitter.com/#!/QuickTheatreTO

Tumblr http://www.thequickeningtheatre.tumblr.com

 

 

We will keep you abreast of our activities.

Please share what we are up to, and please come out and see our shows!

3. Our marketing and promotional materials ($100).
 
4. The cost of flights to Vancouver ($1200).
 
5. Accommodation while at the Festival ($500).
 
6. The Fringe Festival Fee ($750 for the performance venue, an experienced technician and promotion in the Fringe Program)
 
7. Equity Artist fees/Insurance ($84).
 
Total = $3795
 
The International Fringe Festivals ensure that the participating artists receive 100% of the box office revenue. The Canadian Actors Equity Association requires that this money be distributed equally between the artists after all expenses our paid. However, after expenses it is rare that any money is left to pay the artists who have given their time and skills for free. Your support will ensure that the artists are paid and that we will not be producing this show at a cost.
 
And there are PERKS!
 
We greatly appreciate your support. See the perks sidebar to see what tokens of appreciation we're offering you for your generous contribution.
 
Other Ways You Can Help
 
You can help us further by getting the word out!
 
Please share our links:
 
Website http://www.thequickeningtheatre.com,
Facebook  http://www.facebook.com/QuickeningTheatre
Twitter http://twitter.com/#!/QuickTheatreTO 
Tumblr http://www.thequickeningtheatre.tumblr.com
 
  
We will keep you abreast of our activities.
Please share what we are up to, and please come out and see our shows!

story:
Our Story

"Coming: A Rock Musical of Biblical Proportions" is a new work of musical theatre by playwright/composer Erik Ransom. It premiered in Philadelphia at The Prince Music Theatre under the direction of Mark A. Dahl and Bill Egan of the Traverse Arts Project. "Coming" enjoyed a sold-out run with universal praise from local and national press, including The Huffington Post, the Philadelphia Inquirer and The Edge Media Network. Our brief run, had audience members coming back up to 6 times, and scalpers outside the theatre on closing weekend! Now, with the support of Philadelphia's Barrymore Award-Winning Brat Productions, "Coming" is looking to take Manhattan! Under the direction of acclaimed director Madi DiStefano, "Coming" will be showcased for Broadway and Off-Broadway investors at the beginning of 2012, with the goal of opening the show for a commercial Off-Broadway run later that year. In addition to our Philadelphia team, "Coming" is now being supported enthusiastically by New York's own Brierpatch Productions and is being represented by The Pepper Law Group. We have a stellar team and a realistic business plan in the works, and we need support!


Recently we acquired a $7500 grant from the very generous Wyncote Foundation, which challenged us to raise a matching amount on our own! We need support from friends and fans like yourselves to match Wyncote and get to our goal budget!


The Impact

In addition to being an entertaining piece of theatre, ("Bold, campy, glam fun", according the Toby Zinman of The Philadelphia Inquirer) "Coming" has proven to be a very moving, thought-provoking play for many different kinds of people young and old, ranging from self-identified Christians to ardent atheists and everything in between. In spite of its irreverent sense of humor, "Coming" takes all sides of the age old religious arguments very seriously, and has been able to do so in a way that is both entertaining and moving. If you're not sure, check out our press!

"Coming" in The Huffington Post

"Coming" on The Edge

"Coming" in The Art Blog

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to show New York that we have a viable, marketable show for their commercial audiences! So, we're renting a theatre space, hiring a band, bringing together some top-notch Equity and Non-Equity actors, and putting on a basic version of the show for potential investors who might want to take a chance on our daring story. Obviously, with this happening in New York, even a small presentation like this is an expensive endeavor. We want to do this right, and that means money! We're looking for financial support on all levels!


We know it's tough out there, right now, but if everyone on the fan page alone can spare just $10 (Less than a single martini or glass of wine in many places!), we will be well on our way to our goal!


Fortunately, with the sponsorship of the Brat Productions Non-Profit for this presentation, all of your donations are tax deductible! In addition to tax deductible donations, we can also accept inquiries from potential investors who might like to see a return on their contribution. But, as we're only seeking a limited number of investors, this option is open to large sum contributions only.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you're a true victim of the recession, living in a tent city with hipsters, 'Occupying' some parking lot: at least please share this with friends, family and anyone you know who may be interested in supporting a brave new piece of musical theatre with an uncompromising voice, and a powerful message.

story:
Music by Tom Kitt | Book & Lyrics by Brian Yorkey | produced by MUSICALLY HUMAN THEATRE PRODUCTIONS | directed by DAVID NORWOOD | opening night - Thursday, October 25, 2012

(Photo: Next to Normal writers, Tom Kitt and Brian Yorkey)

The highly acclaimed, edgy rock-musical comes back to New York City in an intimate, new production. Heralded as “a brave, breathtaking musical” (The New York Times) that “pushes Broadway in new directions” (Rolling Stone) this emotional powerhouse portrays the intricacies of a family trying to take care of themselves and each other in the face of a mother’s deteriorating mental state. With a pulsing, exhilarating, and contemporary score, this TONY Award winner also took home the Pulitzer Prize for Drama.

 

The Impact

You are being presented with an amazing opportunity to change people’s lives through the American art form known as Musical Theatre. It not only has the power to entertain audiences, but it can also educate them and evoke such powerful human emotions. Musically Human produces work that is raw, visceral and starts conversation among our audiences. Grab hold of this opportunity to make change happen in the world.

 

What We Need / The Plan

We're currently in the midst of raising funds here in New York City for the production. There is so much money required for every little aspect of any production.  Just a few expenses involved are theater rental, rehearsal space, costumes, designer fees, scenic expenses, and much more. Truly, every single dollar helps and is so deeply appreciated!!

 

Now we need your help to get us through the final stages of production. Every penny you donate will go directly to the costs necessary to making this production successful. You can donate as little as $10 to as much as you are capable of. No matter what you give, you’ll immediately be recognized as a Season Donor for Musically Human Theatre Productions' 2012/13 season. Please join us in bringing this unique, intimate production to life. We greatly appreciate your support and look forward to seeing you at NEXT TO NORMAL!

 

IF 70 PEOPLE GIVE $50 EACH, WE'LL HIT OUR GOAL IN NO TIME!!!

 

*NOTE ABOUT TICKETS: Any donors who give an amount entitling them to tickets will be emailed and will be able to select a date of their choice. The production will run October 25 - November 11, 2012 for 16 performances at Studio 501 @ CAP 21. 

 

MORE WAYS YOU CAN HELP:

  • Please "Like" us on Facebook and follow our updates!  

http://www.facebook.com/musicallyhuman

  • Also "Follow" us on Twitter!  

www.twitter.com/musically_human

For more info on Musically Human, visit our website, www.musicallyhuman.org

Feel free to re-post this to all other social networking sites - the more who view, the better! 

THANKS FOR YOUR SUPPORT!  We are so very grateful for anything you can do!

story:
PWR Presents: Rawhide Rave

Austin, Texas's fully unhinged quarterly WRESTLING MEGA PARTY kicks down the saloon door once more! If you've been to one of these events, you have shared precious moments with us! Precious moments such as: 

  • a muscular horse destroying some alive manikins
  • someone named "Pasta Man" physically attacking an itinerant folkpunk over manga
  • a furious Italian chef trying to make a pizza out of a cursed, arcane artifact

Perhaps you even shared the exaltation and terror with us as a Dallas land-developer crossed swords with a furious pixie? Or cried with us as their partner was rebirthed from a cocoon ? This is wrestling! This is Party Violence! This is PWR! 

 

WRESTLESLAM VI: RAWHIDE RAVE

 

Rawhide Rave! What is it!? This is our Spring show, our biggest show of the year! We're bringing several storylines towards their thrilling climaxes, and pulling out all the stops in creating the most splendid and thrilling Spring party event of all time! And it's FREE TO ATTEND!

Are you ready to experience COWBOY STUFF like you never have before? Are you ready to mashup RAVE CULTURE with COUNTRY-WESTERN ELEMENTS?! Saddle up and glowstick out!
"Yee-Hey!" We're bringing our considerable artistic resources to bear on 4th Tap Brewing Co-op (10615 Metric Blvd, Austin, TX) -- converting their warehouse area into a FULL NEON RODEO! What does that mean, even? Well, you can expect horses, cacti, tumbleweeds, covered wagons, varmints, and plenty of  buckaroos rendered into a vibrant, immersive dayglow, starlit  landscape that you can live in on March 14th, from 6:30 to midnight!

There, PWR's patented blend of absurdist comedy, violent spectacle and weirdly-vulnerable performance will manifest like never before. BIG DADDY BOLERO will defend his Partyweight Title against his next contender! LIVING PIZZA TOPPINGS will battle Trash Mutants! And more!

This crucial spectacle will be illuminated with a full professional lighting system, shout with a clear and juicy sound system, and broadcast on 3 screens and beyond with a sweet 3-camera video setup! Wow. 

We had our first WRESTLESLAM event in March of 2015. Since then, you -- the MULTIVERSE -- have become a part of what PWR is. It sounds clichéd, but your support and interest has seen us go  from a handful of people in a homemade ring to an 80 person organization with a training program and several operational departments. That we are able to keep doing PWR in a DIY fashion as a free-to-attend show means so much to us. 

THE STORY SO FAR

PWR Presents: WassailMania saw some devastating defeats, and the despised man of Dallas -- Big Daddy Bolero --  retained his Partyweight Championship belt.  

Now, he's in trouble. Everyone is! An impromptu rodeo/rave has sprung up near PWR's ring. From the shadows saunters "The Ancient DJ:" a tough-as-leather revenant that controls this arcane party with his decks -- his hands working at quickdraw speed. The power of his music is attracting Cow-Ravers from all across the Multiverse, as well as transforming the very landscape into a form that's somewhere between a Tokyo nightscape and a craggy gulch. This ferocious COWBOY ENERGY has summoned competitors both good and evil to compete in feats of Party Athletics. Will one of these NEWJACK RUSTLERS dethrone Big Daddy Bolero? Or will they aid him in his final domination of Austin's real estate market?

Will PWR itself be destroyed by a rampant COWBOY infestation?! 

We're going to find out, plus see the continuation of the stories of Sweetie Tuff and Crybaby, Ralph Macchiato, The Dumpster Babes, Alexandra Cage, Luigi Primo, Dark Master, Gary the Goat, The Crimson Spark, Bench Horse, Olive, Anchovius, Hot Dog and many more!

What is this money used for?

 

$6000 is a lot of money! What’s it going toward?

First, an important recitation: PWR's quarterly Austin shows are free. PWR is for everyone, even if they can't afford to pay cover at a show. We'd like to keep from having to charge admission for as long as we can.

PWR is also now a 80-person organization putting on one of the largest free events in Texas. Increased expectations beget increased (and wholly worthwhile) costs: we spend north of $10,000 on each of our shows.

We diligently budget and carefully save so that we can ask for an amount that is sustainable. We are continuously able to improve the show and make it grander; our rigorous planning -- combined with your support -- have allowed us to do this without our costs ballooning to a hellish degree! It's all on the backs of our beautiful volunteers who submit themselves to the Multiverse out of love. We've survived more than five years as we've grown into the massive wrestling party you know today—and we're not slowing down! Accept no impostors! HELL RIGHT

Some of the cool things your donations will help us do include:

Art and design. We have an extremely talented team of designers who transform the venue into an art piece by using garbage.  4th Tap Brewing Co-Op is about to get jammed with tumbleweed mirrorglobes and laser cacti. Though most of our resources are scavenged from trash bins and thrift stores, filling a venue of our size with cool decorations—and the storage to keep them preserved show after show!—costs money.

Air Conditioning. We're budgeting to get coolers, just in case it gets hot outside! You know how Texas is.

Paying artists. We work hard to make sure everyone who contributes to our production gets some money in exchange—whether our art team, our powerful tech wizards, or our A/V crew.

Safer space/security. PWR is a party for everyone. Our performers have always followed anti-sexist/homophobic/transphobic/racist guidelines, and we wanted to make sure that comfort extends to our audience. We’re proud of our security phone line. Any member of the audience may use this number to report gross behavior at the show, and we resolve the problem. Your support lets us keep reaching toward a goal of ULTIMATE PARTY VIOLENCE for everyone.

Projection and lighting. PWR has some of the most advanced lighting for an independent wrestling show in the country! And we built it ourselves, with your help. We always have tweaks to make to reach towards our goal of TV-quality lighting. If you saw our lights at the last show, you know how shockingly powerful our latest generation is! Also, our projection system allows people to watch the show from 3 different places in the venue, each with different sitting and standing options! Plus, we now STREAM our shows over twitch, and your support helps us improve the quality of it.

Training. Party Violence is its own unique sport. We have crafted a training program that makes use of experienced pro-wrestling coaching to help keep our PARTY ATHLETES smooth n' safe.  

Profit split. after we cover all our costs, we take 20% of our profits and reinvest it in PWR. We split up whatever is left among performers and staff who worked on the show.

For transparency: this Indiegogo doesn’t cover all of adolescent PWR’s expenses, but it takes care of a big chunk of them. Below is our complete operational budget.

Show Expenses: $2515.00:

Art Supplies: $400.00
Equipment Rental and Accessories (AC units, Video/Sound, Generators, etc): $600
Construction Supplies: $50
Insurance: $455.00
Performer Assistance Fund: $200.00
Ring/Facilities Maintenance: $175.00
Office Supplies: $30.00
Props/Costume: $75.00
Security Phone: $60.00
Transportation: $400.00
Service Subscriptions: $70

Operational Expenses: $4470:

Artist and Staff Pay: $4070
New Projects Capital: $400.00

Indiegogo Reward production and fulfillment: $2960
Indiegogo and credit card fees: $550


Extremely Hype Swag

As always, your donation comes with a cool perk! Check out the new shirt design by Zeke Guadiana, available in both Tee and Tank and on both black and navy blue fabric -- in TWO DIFFERENT COLORWAYS!




Looking for some lower body garb? how about some PRINTED TIGHTS  by Zeke Guadiana? The print appears on BOTH LEGS! Woah...

Need something different? Something...flammable? How about a PWR CANDLE?!

But what are you gonna put this stuff in? How about PRINTED tote bags, with this design by Nat Bradford!?


And get ready for the return of PWR Bandanas by Zeke Guadiana, including a new  color!



Risks and Challenges

 

As PWR continues its evolution from backyard party to professional art-collective, we never want to lose the heart of partying and stupidness that makes it good. We aim to balance a relentless work ethic with a light touch and and inviting environment for our attendants, volunteers and staff. It's hard wrangling 80 people to put on a huge free show, but knowing others will join us to reap the rewards makes it worth it one million times. Rest assured we're working tirelessly to have the time of our lives on December 7th! 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't want to donate money you can help us by getting the word out about this campaign and/or just word out about PWR and RAWHIDE RAVE!

Here is the Facebook event page:https://www.facebook.com/events/479044936320948/

HMW

If you don't want to donate money you can help us by getting the word out about this campaign and/or just word out about PWR and RAWHIDE RAVE!
Here is the Facebook event page:https://www.facebook.com/events/479044936320948/
HMW

story:
Goblins! Fairies! Live Music! Magic! The Bog of Eternal Stench!

Pan Productions is pleased to announce the upcoming live stage musical, The Goblin King’s City, an adaptation of the 1986 film Labyrinth, which featured David Bowie and Jennifer Connelly, and was directed by Jim Henson.

From the directors and producers of Rocky Horror at The Firehouse, and A Swimming in the Head, this full stage production includes a large cast and crew of seasoned favorites, along with many new faces. A live, re-imagined version of the score will be brought to life by local favorites Jerusafunk, including an original song written and performed by We Are Hologram, the first full band performance by local musician I am Hologram. The show will also include an original song written by Serene Dominic.

Our cast features local musical and theater artists from all over the valley.

Our passionate cast and crew have been working non-stop to bring you something unique and special. Now we need the assistance of our community and supporters to see our vision through.

This is our largest production to date, and with your contribution, you will help us bring something to Phoenix that’s unlike anything you’ve seen before!

You will enjoy our re-imagined version of the script and score, with songs and scenes that you know and love, along with our own new surprises.

We face huge challenges in our final stretch to produce this show. We are in need of building and costuming materials, as well as taking care of numerous technical tasks. Please support the local arts, and help push us each step closer to our final product. This will provide a number of rewards, not to mention an entertaining and magical production!

There are also other ways to get involved. We are still welcoming set builders, stage-hands and extras. You can also help by spreading the word about this campaign and production.

https://www.facebook.com/events/1274595772618675/

We thank all of our supporters; past, present, and future!

story:
Inspired by his own terrifyingly confused understanding of masculinity, playwright Sam Stagg began work on Between a Cock and a Hard Place in the Fall of 2016.  Since the initial reading of the play, which included current cast member Eduardo Olmos, we have been working tirelessly toward a full scale production. With the help of Dixon Place and the incredible cast & crew, your generosity will assist in making this dream become a reality on June 16th. 

That's cool but what's it about? 

  • Between a Cock and a Hard Place satirizes the male compulsion to be aggressive and violent as a means of asserting masculinity. Two overly confident amateur robbers, an unyielding mob boss, and a blue collar criminal at the end of his rope collide with an innocent boy who is coerced into making a decision that will undoubtedly affect his life forever. The characters in this play comedically exemplify the toxic ways in which we define and understand masculinity.

Who we are

  • Salmon Run Productions is a company founded by a collection of actors, writers, filmmakers, and storytellers who are passionate about producing work that makes visible the absurd projections of realities that we all see in our heads.
  • An artistic incubator since 1986, Dixon Place is a Bessie and Obie Award-winning non-profit institution committed to supporting the creative process by presenting original works of theater, dance, music, puppetry, circus arts, literature & visual art at all stages of development. Presenting over 1000 creators a year, this local haven inspires & encourages diverse artists of all stripes & callings to take risks, generate new ideas & consummate new practices.

Cast and creative team

DIRECTED BY: Molly Johnson

WRITTEN BY: Sam Stagg

PERFORMED BY: Dan Foster, Eduardo Olmos, Kieron Anthony, Michael Piazza, Sam Stagg, Zachary Guttman

STAGE DESIGNER: Alex Floyd

COSTUME: Ruby Frankel

LIGHTING AND SOUND: Jacob Nichols

Performance information

FRIDAY, JUNE 16 AT 10PM at Dixon Place Mainstage

161A Chrystie Street, between Rivington and Delancey.

Click for event page, ticketing, and more information.

Pricing:

  • $15 in advance
  • $18 at the door
  • $12 Stu./Sen./idNYC

Estimated Runtime
45 minutes

Thank you for your intrigue and willingness to come on this crazy old journey with us. We hope to see you there!

story:
Short Summary

Humans of Ashford is a community theatre project that will draw together a diverse ensemble of local people aged 14-100, to co-create a unique devised performance about life in Ashford, Kent. The project will run throughout July, culminating in a performance at a Council-led community picnic in Victoria Park, set to attract over 400 people. Humans of Ashford will be a creative and inclusive process, weaving the memories, stories, hopes and dreams that co-exist in our town into a meaningful piece of locally-made theatre. 

The project is being organised by two local professional practitioners: award winning theatre maker, Grace Holme and Emily Parrett, a highly experienced drama facilitator and performer.

To read more about the facilitators and for up-to-date news on the project, please visit our blog: www.humansofashford.wordpress.com

What We Need & What You Get

We're looking to raise £1350.

A breakdown of the costs suggests what your donation could support:

  • £80 will pay for high quality portrait photographs of all the participants
  • £125 will pay for transport for any young people requiring financial support to attend 
  • £240 will pay for a full-scale evaluation report of the project, supporting future arts investment in Ashford, Kent 
  • £380 will pay for the total resources, materials and refreshments needed for the length of the rehearsal process and performance

In return for support, for donations of £20 or more we will thank you online via our social media and blog, and for £50 or more we will publicly thank you in front of our large audience at the picnic in Victoria Park, if you so wish. Additionally, companies who donate £250 or more will have their logo featured on future Humans of Ashford marketing. 

The Impact

Humans of Ashford will provide local people with the opportunity to meet new people, create a unique piece of theatre, and share it with the wider community. The performance will be enjoyed by an audience of all ages at the picnic in Victoria Park.

This is a vital opportunity to support not only this one-off event, but also Ashford's expanding arts and culture scene. A successful project means we will be able to organise more and more theatre and performance opportunities in the area in future. This is just the beginning. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand not everyone has the financial means to contribute, however there are multiple ways to support our project. Why not:

  • Spread the word to colleagues, family and friends
  • Get involved yourself
  • Come and support us at 'Mr Harper's Birthday Picnic' on the 23rd July in Victoria Park
  • Share the project via email and social media 
  • Give us a 'Like' on Facebook www.facebook.com/HOfATheatre/ and follow us on Twitter @HofATheatre

story:
Short Summary

Hi! Matt and Naomi here. Thanks for checking out our campaign. We need your help to support a portion of our budget for an upcoming live improv theatre show in Toronto. 

We are the co-founders of the National Theatre of the World -- a multi-disciplinary, Toronto-based, not-for-profit theatre company that creates exciting, provocative, and instantaneous theatre through the art of improvisation.

Some of you will know us as Matt Baram from Nickelodeon’s Make it Pop and Naomi Snieckus from CBC’s Mr. D. You might know us as Second City alums or the folks you see walking our dog at the park.

We are really excited to tell to you about our brand new project. It’s a little bit improv, a little bit theatre, and a whole lot of fun!

BARAM & SNIECKUS is a show that’s very close to our hearts. Together we satirize the male/female dynamic in all of its complicated splendor. BARAM & SNIECKUS showcases the unique point of view and chemistry that comes from being a real life comedy couple.

We're going back to our roots. We met at Second City and fell in love doing sketch --  we're revisiting all those fun times.

From that familiar awkward first kiss to the unexplored territory of “spaceship infidelity”, the story of men and women will be told through a satirical sketch comedy lens, informed by our very own personal experiences, fully heightened and explored in a unique and hilarious way.

What We Need & What You Get

It takes more than standing on stage to put on a show. We need your help to help us offset the costs of the planning and putting on a quality live show. Box office sales aren’t enough to make BARAM & SNIECKUS go.

There are technical expenses like getting qualified tech personnel to load up and take down equipment. Set, props, lighting, programs, and costumes are all expenses we’re going to have to cover.

There are personnel expenses because our director can’t pay rent with high fives and home-baked cookies. We also have a stage manager and musician to pay. Skilled workers are valued by the National Theatre of the World. They get paid for their hard work and that’s something we’re very proud of.

There are publicity expenses like paying our designer (who is very, incredibly talented) and getting flyers printed. Even with discounts and help from our friends, these things still cost money.

At the end of the day, we hope that -- like us -- you value artistic expression, cultural richness, and experimenting with creativity. This is what the National Theatre of the World is all about. We are so very over-the-moon grateful for your support.

Yer Perks

You show us some love, we give it right back! Our perks are all based on your support for the National Theatre of the World and this particular show. We’ve got postcards, tickets, and meet-and-greets to express our deep gratitude for your support. Thank you! Check out the listed perks for specifics about what you get when you contribute to this campaign. 

Did we say "Thank You" yet? Thank you. Hey you. Thank you. Thanks so much. Gosh you look great. Thanks for your support. 

:)

The Impact

Funding this project means supporting local theatre art. You're enriching the theatre and improv community by allowing artists and creators to do what they do best! 

We pride ourselves on acting as mentors on- and off-stage. Everything we learn from our experience with BARAM & SNIECKUS will become part of our teaching through the National Theatre of the World. 

Risks & Challenges

Art is risky. But you know that taking some risks is the the only way we can advance art. 

Together we've tackled many live shows with a great deal of success. 

In 2008,  we (still Matt and Naomi here) along with Mad TV alumnus Ronald Pederson and firecracker Kayla Lorette began to produce our very first show with the National Theatre of the World. That show was Impromptu Splendor at Comedy Bar in Toronto. From its earliest incarnation, Impromptu Splendor (The Improvised Play) has always delivered a fresh, artful and provoking spectacle brought to life in the fashion of a one act play.

Shortly afterImpromptu Splendor, we joined forces with Chris Gibbs (a real comedic genius) to produceThe Carnegie Hall Show. With song, circus acts, special guests, and an improvised radio play, The Carnegie Hall Show  was executed with all the grandeur of The Kennedy Centre Honors.

In July of 2011, with help from world class improviser Christy Bruce, The National Theatre of The World assembled Torontoʼs most prolific comedic improvisers and created an ongoing improvised episodic packed with drama, romance, intrigue and betrayal and simply called it The Soaps! After a successful inaugural season at Comedy Bar, the troupe was invited to participate in the Toronto Fringe as a benefit show for the festival called Shawford-On-The-Pondwhich played to sold out houses at The Bathurst Street Theatre. In 2011, The National Theatre of The World was the recipient of The Canadian Comedy Award for Best Improv Troupe for the second time and Ronald Pederson received the Best Male Improviser Award.

Read our full history here. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute financially? Dude, we totally get it. If you like what you've read consider sharing this campaign online and in the streets. 

You can use Indiegogo's handy share tools to tell people why they should kick over some cash to support Toronto's improv and live theatre scene. 

THANK YOU. Thank you times a million billion hundred zillion. We can't do this without you. 

Much love, 

Matt, Naomi, and the crew

P.S. 

Here are our show dates:

Preview (Wednesday, October 21) 7:30 pm
Opening (Thursday, October 22) 7:30 pm
Show 1 (Friday, October 23) 7:30 pm
Show 2 (Saturday, October 24) 2:00 pm
Show 3 (Saturday, October 24) 7:30 pm
Show 4 (Sunday, October 25) 2:00 pm
Show 5 (Wednesday, October 28) 7:30 pm
Show 6 (Thursday, October 29) 7:30pm
Show 7 (Friday, October 30)7:30 pm
Show 8 (Saturday, October 31) 2:00pm
Show 9 (Saturday, October 31) 7:30pm
Show 10 (Sunday, November 1) 2:00pm

story:
Cantankerous Theatre 

We are Cantankerous. We met 4 years ago and started being funny together.  After a 2 year break we decided it was high time we milked our Irish-ness, and came together in Bristol to develop characters and write a script.

After 9 months of devising, improvising and trying out material at every chance we could get, our play “Woolly eyed turtle” has slowly unfolded. Our dream of taking our duo to the Edinburgh Fringe has become a terrifying and exciting reality. It is a true showcase of our friendship and everything we have been working on to date.

We cannot express how much it means to us to have your support, to make this happen.  We want it so much, and we can't do it without you.  We plan to take the show on tour and continue making work together in the coming year.  This money will really set us up for a year of creativity and allow us to concentrate on the tasks at hand to achieve this goal. 


Our Play - "Woolly Eyed Turtle 3D"

One stupid town and all its inhabitants - played by 2 ridiculous women. Cantankerous brings you "Woolly Eyed Turtle 3D". Watch Maeve & Emily attempt to weave seamlessly from character to character with funny and awkward results and unexpected twists every night.


What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

We need to raise £8000 to get to the fringe.  I know it sounds like a lot, but it all makes sense if you break it down.  We will be in Edinburgh for 6 weeks, rehearsing and preparing for our show.

  • Printing Costs - £450
  • Design Costs - £150
  • Accommodation- £1850
  • Travel in Edinburgh- £324
  • Transport to and from Edinburgh- £350
  • Living Expenses  - £1,580
  • Costumes - £300
  • Make-up - £150
  • Wigs - £75
  • 3D Glasses - £100
  • Advertising - £800
  • Set and staging - £700
  • Technical equipment - £590
  • Contingency @ 10% - £740
Having this money will allow us to concentrate on writing, rehearsing and producing our play.  We need to take 2 months off to make it happen, so have had to include costs of living in Bristol and Edinburgh.  

We have a host of amazing perks for you to enjoy for the money you give.  

£5 - Facebook shout out and our eternal gratitude.
£10 - Hold hands with one of our characters...   too shy to take it to the next step?  Just have a gentle introduction to the courting ritual and hold hands with Noreen, Biddy, Mick or Joanne.
£15 - Why not have a shift with the character of your choice?  Do you fancy Siobhan, Mick, Ann-Marie or Liam?  Give just £15 and you can shift them, go on, why not!  (shift is Irish for snog, in case you were wondering)
£25 - We will make a video in the character of your choice thanking you for your contribution.   
£50 - Receive all of the above perks and a thank you post card hand made by us and sent to you at home.
£100 - You can take one of our characters out on a date - on you.
£200 - A personalised sketch made in consultation with yourself. (Skype consultations can be arranged.)  Is there someone in your life you find hilarious and want to see depicted on the big screen, are you constantly thinking that your life takes funny twists and turns?  Why not work with us to immortalise that, in a sketch on youtube forever.
£600 - Star in your very own professionaly filmed and produced sketch.  If you don't want to be in it, we can play you.  
£1000 - We will bring our Edinburgh Fringe play to you, wherever you are and perform for you alone, or all your family and friends.  At a party, event, festival, wedding or first date.  It could make the perfect present for the ones you cherish. Whatever floats your boat like!

Our travel expenses will have to be paid by you, if you decide you want it in the Carribean or other far flung regions of the world such as 'the London' etc.

Our Journey so Far!

We have worked really hard for the last year to make this all happen for us.  Travelling between Bristol and Edinburgh to perform and create. It's cost us a lot of time and money to do this, but we've enjoyed every second and all the challenges that have arisen. 

We have learned a lot about how we work as individuals and as a partnership and are looking forward the future of Cantankerous and watching how it will grow and grow.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can donate some money to our campaign, then that brilliant and thank you so much.  But don't worry if you can't, there are lots of other ways you can support us.

  • Tell all your friends about us and how funny we are and deserving of support.
  • Share this link on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and your Blog.
  • Email people directly who you think would be interested in supporting us.
  • Come and see our show in Edinburgh.
  • Like us on Facebook - Cantankerous Theatre

What We Need & What You Get Break it down for folks in more detail:
We need to raise £8000 to get to the fringe.  I know it sounds like a lot, but it all makes sense if you break it down.  We will be in Edinburgh for 6 weeks, rehearsing and preparing for our show. 
Printing Costs - £450
Design Costs - £150
Accommodation- £1850
Travel in Edinburgh- £324
Transport to and from Edinburgh- £350
Living Expenses  - £1,580
Costumes - £300
Make-up - £150
Wigs - £75
3D Glasses - £100
Advertising - £800
Set and staging - £700
Technical equipment - £590
Contingency @ 10% - £740

Having this money will allow us to concentrate on writing, rehearsing and producing our play.  We need to take 2 months off to make it happen, so have had to include costs of living in Bristol and Edinburgh.  

We have a host of amazing perks for you to enjoy for the money you give.  


£5 - Facebook shout out and our eternal gratitude.

£10 - Hold hands with one of our characters...   too shy to take it to the next step?  Just have a gentle introduction to the courting ritual and hold hands with Noreen, Biddy, Mick or Joanne.

£15 - Why not have a shift with the character of your choice?  Do you fancy Siobhan, Mick, Ann-Marie or Liam?  Give just £15 and you can shift them, go on, why not!  (shift is Irish for snog, in case you were wondering)

£25 - We will make a video in the character of your choice thanking you for your contribution.   

£50 - Receive all of the above perks and a thank you post card hand made by us and sent to you at home.

£100 - You can take one of our characters out on a date - on you.

£200 - A personalised sketch made in consultation with yourself. (Skype consultations can be arranged.)  Is there someone in your life you find hilarious and want to see depicted on the big screen, are you constantly thinking that your life takes funny twists and turns?  Why not work with us to immortalise that, in a sketch on youtube forever.

£600 - Star in your very own professionaly filmed and produced sketch.  If you don't want to be in it, we can play you.  

£1000 - We will bring our Edinburgh Fringe play to you, wherever you are and perform for you alone, or all your family and friends.  At a party, event, festival, wedding or first date.  It could make the perfect present for the ones you cherish. Whatever floats your boat like!

Our travel expenses will have to be paid by you, if you decide you want it in the Carribean or other far flung regions of the world such as 'the London' etc.


    Our Journey so Far! We have worked really hard for the last year to make this all happen for us.  Travelling between Bristol and Edinburgh to perform and create. It's cost us a lot of time and money to do this, but we've enjoyed every second and all the challenges that have arisen. 
We have learned a lot about how we work as individuals and as a partnership and are looking forward the future of Cantankerous and watching how it will grow and grow.  
    Other Ways You Can Help If you can donate some money to our campaign, then that brilliant and thank you so much.  But don't worry if you can't, there are lots of other ways you can support us.


Tell all your friends about us and how funny we are and deserving of support.
Share this link on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and your Blog.
Email people directly who you think would be interested in supporting us.
Come and see our show in Edinburgh.
Like us on Facebook - Cantankerous Theatre

story:
The Short Version

A quick message from writer/performer Helen Monks:

This is a comedy. I promise. But I want to do a VERY brief serious (as serious as I can be) spiel about the show.

This is mostly to manipulate you into giving us money. But it also happens to be true.

It was becoming a daily thing for a friend to text or call or come round and say: ‘I want to die.’

Sometimes this would be ‘good dying’ – ‘I saw Taylor Swift last night and now I want to LITERALLY die.’

(FYI oldies, you can normal tell it’s not literal when we preface it with the word ‘literally’.)

But otherwise ‘I want to die’ was always delivered with this weird, underlying small quiver of truth. This deep, exhausted sigh… this ‘what if?’…

And then we’d laugh and talk about Taylor Swift and pretend everything was ok. But it would make the air just that little bit stickier. And I’m not very good at showering so the stick started to build up into a sort of depressing, icky paste.

It’s like when I went to uni. I ate A LOT of food at uni. But you don’t notice weight gain when it’s on you – it happens slowly. It takes going back to your home friends, who have only seen the before and after, and them saying, ‘Who ate Helen?’ for you to actually spot something’s up.

I remember looking round and realising that everyone was mentally OBESE. I realised I was sticky all over.

And not in the way I would normally like.

I remember thinking, this is not normal. Yes, people struggle with their mental health. Yes, people get down in the dumps. But for an entire generation to be totally crippled by loneliness, hopeless, poverty and fear.

This is not normal.

We shouldn’t have got used to this being our normal.

‘Dolly Wants To Die’ is about fighting against everything that society – grrr, society – is throwing at us. Overdrafts, debt, crammed house shares, unpaid internships, being overworked and undervalued, being lonely, being poor. It’s about holding up a mirror to all those friends who called in the middle night, and all those friends who didn’t but really, really wanted to, and saying – look, see! It’s not just you. It’s ok.

Well, it’s not ok.

But it’s not just you.

 

(IT’S A COMEDY I PROMISE.)

 

A quick message from LUNG:

Creating a new show requires a lot of time, love and money. We've been making theatre together and touring work nationally since 2012, so we've clocked in the hours, and tried and tested our mutual affection for one another. As Associate Artists at The Lowry we've been able to develop the show there, and at The Civic in Barnsley, and both venues have been extremely generous in providing us with valuable rehearsal space, advice and other in-kind resources. Now though we need your support to help us remain financially secure in getting Dolly up to the Fringe this year, and ensure we can keep making work long afterwards. 

If this sounds like something you might like to help us with, or perhaps you're just eager to find out more, then read on for more info or check out what our dear Dolly has to say in the video above. Next, see the lovely shiny perks to the right? Well we've made them specially for you. Choose one you really like the look of and give us a helping hand. Your contribution - large or small - will be hugely appreciated and go a long way in helping us bring the show to it's full potential.

Alternatively, if you don't feel able to help financially, that's OK. Give us a like instead. Follow us on Twitter, share this campaign, and come and see the show. We've got dates in Sheffield and London before we hit the Burgh. Helping us spread the word is half the battle, and we'd love to hear from you.

Thanks for reading.

Love LUNG xxx

The Show

Dolly is a potty-mouthed, chain-smoking, whiskey-swigging china doll. She can sing, she can dance, she can throw a tea party like a bitch – she can do anything the kids she looks after could ever want. But Dolly can’t do the one thing that she really wants: Dolly can’t die.

With no skin to cut, no lungs to pop and no heart to stop, every attempt on her life fails drastically. Dolly is determined that with some assistance she could manage it: someone to run her over with the toy tractor, or help her in the bed-time-bath with the toaster.
The first generation to grow up poorer than their parents, having to coach kids from childhood to adulthood is now a cynical job for Dolly. Much like the kids she looks after, love has turned to hat, ambition has turned to pessimism and any chance of happiness has become heavily dependant on Xanax.

Presenting first world problems in an imaginary world, this offbeat comedy is a modern Toy Story for the Prozac generation. Through story-telling, dance and standup, Dolly Wants to Die explores the peril of entering adulthood and what an absolute ball ache it is staying alive. 

Written and performed by Helen Monks, Germaine in channel 4's 'Raised by Wolves'. 

What Will My Money Buy?

Creating a new show costs a lot of money, and Edinburgh - wonderful, bonkers, inspiring Edinburgh - is expensive. We need your support to help us fund the final few weeks of rehearsal and development of Dolly Wants To Die, bring it to full production ready for previews at Theatre Delicatessen and Funny Women Festival followed by a month long run at Underbelly, Edinburgh.

A small amount can go a really long way in ensuring we can get to Edinburgh in one piece, sleep easy at night and ensure Dolly Wants To Die will be the best show it can be. Your money will go towards what we'd like to think of as the "Bear Essentials":

  • Props and set. A bear costume and helping us create a real kids bedroom! 
  • Travel. This includes our own travel costs up to Edinburgh (doesn't matter where you're from in the country, that's a long way!) and van hire to transport our set for Dolly, which we will share with our other show - E15.
  • Marketing. A portion of this money will contribute to flyers and posters to be used to promote the show in the Edinburgh.
  • Workshops. This is something our writer and performer Helen Monks is really passionate about. And we are too (see about us for more info). We want to run workshops ahead of the Fringe, and afterwards, with school children aged 15+ to help encourage young women to get into comedy - a still male-dominated genre. Your donations will help facilitate these.

To make the above possible we're looking for the meagre(ish) sum of £1,750. 

In addition to Indiegogo we are seeking funding from other sources to complete the project, but with no guarantee the money raised from this campaign will play a huge part in getting the project to where we need it to be.  And it is, we think, a really manageable figure.

A Little More About Us

LUNG (formally FYSA Theatre) is a Barnsley-based theatre company. We are Associate Artists at The Lowry and have recently been working under commission from Battersea Arts Centre on the sell-out production of Chilcot, ★★★★ The Guardian.
Founded in 2012, our mission statement is to work closely with communities to develop innovative and politically driven work that broadens horizons and investigates modern Britain.

We've recently concluded a national tour of verbatim production The 56 (developed with The Civic in Barnsley, BAC and The Lowry). Our second verbatim production E15 was also developed and commissioned by BAC and premiered with Gilded Balloon at the Edinburgh Fringe 2015. Alongside Dolly Wants To Die, the show will be returning to the Edinburgh Fringe this summer with Northern Stage at Summerhall.

LUNG has also run a dedicated outreach programme for over four years, where young and aspiring theatre-makers are invited to attend verbatim theatre workshops.

Awards:
The Directors Guild Award for Best Newcomer

The Spotlight Award for Most Promising Actress 

The National Student Drama Festival Judges Award for Best Ensemble  

Shortlisted for the Amnesty International Freedom of Expression Award 2015

★★★★ "Political theatre at it's very best" The Stage 
"A young remarkable company" The Independent



Thank you!

www.lungtheatre.co.uk

https://www.facebook.com/lungtheatre/

https://twitter.com/LungTheatre

#DollyWantsToDie

Photographs: Joseph Samuel Priestley

story:
STILLPOINTE THEATRE FINALLY HAS A SPACE TO CALL OUR VERY OWN! HELP US TURN IT INTO A HOME!

We are Stillpointe Theatre.  We are a diverse group of artists committed to bringing accessible, professional, quality theatre to the city of Baltimore. 

For the past 5 years, Stillpointe's shows have been produced in a nomadic sense, moving from space to space to fit the production at hand.  We pride ourselves on transforming non-theatrical spaces into intricately designed, intimate theatre environments that transform both classic and original works of theatre.  We have produced work in art galleries, churches, coffee shops, old bathhouses, and refurbished vinyl factories, and now we move into the next phase, because we have wonderful news...

WE FOUND A SPACE!  

That's right!  A real space!  Not a THEATRE space really, but a space nonetheless!  Located in the burgeoning Station North Arts and Entertainment District, we finally have a space to call our very own!  No more extensive load-ins and load-outs!  No more stressing to find rehearsal space!  Finally we can stop having meetings at each other's houses!  What a wonderful thing!

Here's where you come in.  YES, YOU!

As we are sure you are well aware, the cost of transforming this space into a full functioning theatre is not cheap.  We're looking to our patrons, friends, families and the public at large to help us raise the money for necessary improvements and additions to our space.  Your support allows us to make needed renovations, install lighting and sound equipment, and produce our first season in our new space!  In addition, you'll be providing the city of Baltimore with another multi-use arts space! 

The theatre scene of Baltimore is vast and diverse, providing audiences with a wide array of quality entertainment and cultural enrichment. However, most companies do not have a space to call their own and many end up in the same boat as Stillpointe, having to relocate from show to show to suit scheduling demands and limited space options. The addition of The Stillpointe Theater will provide an additional space for companies to utilize outside of our regular season, allowing more theatre to be produced, and therefore, greater opportunities for community enrichment. 

OK, SO WHAT COULD YOU POSSIBLY NEED TO TURN THIS INTO A THEATRE?

For this campaign we are looking to raise $25,000. That number may seem steep, and honestly, it is! But turning an old store front space into a black box theatre is going to require a bit more than some black paint and a spotlight! Here's how we plan to upgrade the existing space so better fit our needs! 

RENOVATIONS/WINTERIZING:

Our space is unique because it is an old store front space on Charles Street. A fortune teller used to operate out of the building next door and Pearson's Florists, a Baltimore Institution is to our right. The space may have worked for retail, but now we need something different. The entire back section of the space is unfinished brick and concrete, leading to an alley that is , well, not very accommodating. With your support, we plan to winterize our new "back stage area" so that it is comfortable year round.  The front section will become our shop, so additional power will have to be run, and workshop space will have to be constructed.  We also plan to turn the far back room into dressing rooms, which will require further materials and labor. Making this backstage area into a comfortable space for our artists to construct and prepare for a show is very high on our list of priorities for the space. 
   

LIGHTING AND SOUND:

Well I guess we DO have to let you see and hear what we're doing right? While our space is not the Hippodrome, we still pride ourselves on the the caliber of work we produce. A solid lighting rig will allow the space to function more universally, giving us options of how to light, design, and configure the space. Our lighting tools will also be at the disposal of any outside performers, from an open mic with a single spotlight, to a full production with strobes and hazers! Unfortunately, these rigs are not something you can acquire over time, and can cost a pretty penny. The great thing is, however, once it is installed, it is an invaluable resource for our company, as well as other companies that may utilize the space. 

Sound equipment also plays into this. Again, while our space is not the largest, good sound can be what makes or breaks a show.  Our artists sometimes have to combat outside noise as well as very loud instrumentalists, and with proper amplification, we can ensure that our artists will be heard and the audience will get the full Stillpointe experience. This is also beneficial to visiting artists utilizing the space, as this equipment can usually be very expensive to rent. 

MAINTENANCE

This new space, like any other apartment, home, or office comes with its own set of challenges and hurdles. While we can be confident in our ability to create dynamic, moving pieces of theatre to pay our rent, some expenses come out of the blue. Things like insurance, permits, and unforeseen renovations can really throw a curveball to small companies like ours. With your support, we can make sure these minor hiccups will not deplete us financially, so that we can get back to doing what we do best, making theatre for the city of Baltimore. 

BUT WHAT'S IN IT FOR ME?!

Well, we're glad you asked! Along with your donation being tax-deductible, we have an array of perks and prizes for various levels of donation. These offers include having your name immortalized on our donor lobby display, to Stillpointe swag, to the full VIP Stillpointe experience! No matter which level you choose to give, we promise that it will not go unnoticed! Take a look at the list of perks and prizes listed to the right to find the level you're most excited about! 

But the real perk is not in t-shirts and complimentary tickets.  The real prize in all of this is that the city of Baltimore will have one more theatre space to enrich the community. The community of Station North is growing fast, and with the addition of The Stillpointe Theater, it can continue to do so. 

We also must note that if all funds are not met, not all is lost! We are appreciative of any support we can get, and support for this campaign means something more. We aren't just trying to raise funds to produce our season. We're not trying to get rights to a particular show. We're creating a space for art to come to life. A place where people gather to laugh, or cry, or maybe just try to put the outside world on mute for a moment. This is so much bigger than anything we've done, and the support we garner from this campaign will be plugged directly back into the space, however little the amount. 

MAKING AN IMPACT

We won't be long-winded with this section, for fear of sounding like a broken record, but the impact of a space like The Stillpointe Theater within our community would be notable. As you likely remember, our city suffered a serious blow in April of this year. Stillpointe had to move back our opening of "AVENUE Q" by one week to accommodate curfews and safety, due to the events happening in Baltimore. When the curtain finally rose on opening night, and the audience broke into their first round of laughter, it felt as if something was lifted. People needed to laugh. They needed to be reminded of the beauty and humor of the world. And if a silly, dirty puppet show can do that, imagine what more and more works can do. We don't just do our work for ourselves. We do it for the community. 

By becoming a fixture of the Station North Arts and Entertainment District, we can continue to enrich the community and participate in the cultural renaissance our city is experiencing!

WHAT'S LIFE WITHOUT A LITTLE RISK?

While we are confident in our abilities to produce quality theatre, we also know that running a theatre space comes with it's own set of headaches. The costs of keeping the lights on and the heat pumping are going to add up. We know that as a company we have to step up to increase audience development and outreach, as well as stepping up our game production-wise to keep the seats filled and the space well funded. 

But if the past 5 years have taught us anything as a company, it's that we are stronger together than we are apart, and that includes maintaining our relationship with our audiences. We've asked patrons to drive 40 minutes outside the city, to a field on a cow farm, to watch our first show, "TITUS ANDRONICUS". And they did it! Those same people have attended show after show because they believe in our vision. They believe in our spirit. And they believe that no matter what we set our minds to, the finished product will always be perfectly "Stillpointe." 

HOW ELSE CAN YOU HELP, YOU SAY?! 

We understand, as working artists, that money is tight. But not all support for Stillpointe has to be monetary! 

Sharing our campaign and helping us get the word out is a wonderful way to show support! Use the buttons of this page to share our campaign across several social media platforms. The more people that can see our story and know our goal, the better chance we have of raising $25,000. Tell your friends! Tell your co-workers! Tell your grandma over Christmas dinner! You know she loves theatre! 

Better still, if you'd like to help us even further, volunteering for Stillpointe is also a great way to support! Are you good with tools? Happen to be a gifted grant writer?  Do you bake (food)? Have a unique skill we don't know we need yet? Drop us a line and let's chat! There are so many ways to help Stillpointe. We pride ourselves on being a collaborative, community of artists, and we are always happy to welcome others into the fold!

We here at Stillpointe thank you so much for taking the time to get to know us and our campaign. If we may speak frankly, having our own space is a dream we have been chasing for quite a while. And now it's finally within our grasp! Our goal as a company has always been to produce quality work for our audiences and to let that work propel us into becoming a permanent fixture in the Baltimore theatre community. We firmly believe that with the installation of this new space in Station North, we can do all that AND MORE! We hope you will support us however you can, and we hope to see you at our next production! 

Stillpointe Theatre is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Stillpointe Theatre must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.
