our space.  Your support allows us to make needed renovations,
install lighting and sound equipment, and produce our first season in our new
space!  In addition, you'll be providing the city of Baltimore with
another multi-use arts space! The theatre scene of Baltimore is vast and diverse, providing audiences with a wide array of quality entertainment and cultural enrichment. However, most companies do not have a space to call their own and many end up in the same boat as Stillpointe, having to relocate from show to show to suit scheduling demands and limited space options. The addition of The Stillpointe Theater will provide an additional space for companies to utilize outside of our regular season, allowing more theatre to be produced, and therefore, greater opportunities for community enrichment. 
OK, SO WHAT COULD YOU POSSIBLY
NEED TO TURN THIS INTO A THEATRE?
For this campaign we are looking
to raise $25,000. That number may seem steep, and honestly, it is! But turning
an old store front space into a black box theatre is going to require a bit
more than some black paint and a spotlight! Here's how we plan to upgrade the
existing space so better fit our needs! 
RENOVATIONS/WINTERIZING:

Our space is unique because it is
an old store front space on Charles Street. A fortune teller used to operate
out of the building next door and Pearson's Florists, a Baltimore Institution
is to our right. The space may have worked for retail, but now we need
something different. The entire back section of the space is unfinished brick
and concrete, leading to an alley that is , well, not very accommodating. With
your support, we plan to winterize our new "back stage area" so that
it is comfortable year round.  The front section will become our shop, so
additional power will have to be run, and workshop space will have to be
constructed.  We also plan to turn the far back room into dressing rooms,
which will require further materials and labor. Making this backstage area into
a comfortable space for our artists to construct and prepare for a show is very
high on our list of priorities for the space.    LIGHTING AND SOUND:
Well I guess we DO have to let
you see and hear what we're doing right? While our space is not the Hippodrome,
we still pride ourselves on the the caliber of work we produce. A solid
lighting rig will allow the space to function more universally, giving us
options of how to light, design, and configure the space. Our lighting tools
will also be at the disposal of any outside performers, from an open mic with a
single spotlight, to a full production with strobes and hazers! Unfortunately,
these rigs are not something you can acquire over time, and can cost a pretty
penny. The great thing is, however, once it is installed, it is an invaluable
resource for our company, as well as other companies that may utilize the
space. 
Sound equipment also plays into
this. Again, while our space is not the largest, good sound can be what makes
or breaks a show.  Our artists sometimes have to combat outside noise as
well as very loud instrumentalists, and with proper amplification, we can
ensure that our artists will be heard and the audience will get the full
Stillpointe experience. This is also beneficial to visiting artists utilizing
the space, as this equipment can usually be very expensive to rent. 



MAINTENANCE



This new space, like any other
apartment, home, or office comes with its own set of challenges and hurdles.
While we can be confident in our ability to create dynamic, moving pieces of
theatre to pay our rent, some expenses come out of the blue. Things like
insurance, permits, and unforeseen renovations can really throw a curveball to
small companies like ours. With your support, we can make sure these minor
hiccups will not deplete us financially, so that we can get back to doing what
we do best, making theatre for the city of Baltimore. 
BUT WHAT'S IN IT FOR ME?!


Well, we're glad you asked! Along with your donation being tax-deductible, we have an array of
perks and prizes for various levels of donation. These offers include having
your name immortalized on our donor lobby display, to Stillpointe swag, to the
full VIP Stillpointe experience! No matter which level you choose to give, we
promise that it will not go unnoticed! Take a look at the list of perks and
prizes listed to the right to find the level you're most excited about! 
But the real perk is not in
t-shirts and complimentary tickets.  The real prize in all of this is that
the city of Baltimore will have one more theatre space to enrich the community.
The community of Station North is growing fast, and with the addition of The
Stillpointe Theater, it can continue to do so. 
We also must note that if all
funds are not met, not all is lost! We are appreciative of any support we can
get, and support for this campaign means something more. We aren't just trying
to raise funds to produce our season. We're not trying to get rights to a
particular show. We're creating a space for art to come to life. A place where
people gather to laugh, or cry, or maybe just try to put the outside world on
mute for a moment. This is so much bigger than anything we've done, and the
support we garner from this campaign will be plugged directly back into the
space, however little the amount. 
MAKING AN IMPACT
We won't be long-winded with this
section, for fear of sounding like a broken record, but the impact of a space
like The Stillpointe Theater within our community would be notable. As you
likely remember, our city suffered a serious blow in April of this year.
Stillpointe had to move back our opening of "AVENUE Q" by one week to
accommodate curfews and safety, due to the events happening in Baltimore. When
the curtain finally rose on opening night, and the audience broke into their
first round of laughter, it felt as if something was lifted. People needed to
laugh. They needed to be reminded of the beauty and humor of the world. And if
a silly, dirty puppet show can do that, imagine what more and more works can
do. We don't just do our work for ourselves. We do it for the community. 
By becoming a fixture of the
Station North Arts and Entertainment District, we can continue to enrich the
community and participate in the cultural renaissance our city is experiencing!
WHAT'S LIFE WITHOUT A LITTLE
RISK?
While we are confident in our
abilities to produce quality theatre, we also know that running a theatre space
comes with it's own set of headaches. The costs of keeping the lights on and
the heat pumping are going to add up. We know that as a company we have to step
up to increase audience development and outreach, as well as stepping up our
game production-wise to keep the seats filled and the space well funded. 
But if the past 5 years have taught
us anything as a company, it's that we are stronger together than we are apart,
and that includes maintaining our relationship with our audiences. We've asked patrons to drive 40 minutes
outside the city, to a field on a cow farm, to watch our first show,
"TITUS ANDRONICUS". And they did it! Those same people have attended show after show
because they believe in our vision. They believe in our spirit. And they
believe that no matter what we set our minds to, the finished product will
always be perfectly "Stillpointe." 
HOW ELSE CAN YOU HELP, YOU SAY?! 
We understand, as working
artists, that money is tight. But not all support for Stillpointe has to be
monetary! 
Sharing our campaign and helping us get the word out is a wonderful way to show
support! Use the buttons of this page to share our campaign across several social
media platforms. The more people that can see our story and know our goal, the
better chance we have of raising $25,000. Tell your friends! Tell your
co-workers! Tell your grandma over Christmas dinner! You know she loves
theatre! 
Better still, if you'd like to
help us even further, volunteering for Stillpointe is also a great way to
support! Are you good with tools? Happen to be a gifted grant writer?  Do
you bake (food)? Have a unique skill we don't know we need yet? Drop us a
line and let's chat! There are so many ways to help Stillpointe. We pride
ourselves on being a collaborative, community of artists, and we are always
happy to welcome others into the fold!
We here at Stillpointe thank you
so much for taking the time to get to know us and our campaign. If we may speak frankly, having our own space is a dream we have been chasing for quite a while. And now it's finally within our grasp! Our goal as a company has always been to produce quality work for our audiences and to let that work propel us into becoming a permanent fixture in the Baltimore theatre community. We firmly believe that with the installation of this new space in Station North, we can do all that AND MORE! We hope you
will support us however you can, and we hope to see you at our next
production! 


Stillpointe
Theatre is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service
organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Stillpointe Theatre
must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the
extent permitted by law.

story:
Zirkrobajka was founded in 2011 by some friends who wanted to combine circus and traveling. What first looked like a one-time-thing is growing to be an international network for people sharing a passion for performance arts. Contemporary circus is a way of exchanging with people from different backgrounds and getting to know their cultures. With this year's tour, we want to intensify this exchange, get to know more artists and projects and learn from them.
Therefore we need your help!

What is Zirkrobajka all about?

Since 2012, Zirkrobajka has gone on tour every summer with a different crew. We travelled through Poland, Romania, Ukraine, Turkey and Germany. At the different stations, we have workshops for kids and teenagers in social projects and performed on the streets or at festivals. Apart from our interest in other cultures and living situation we are of the opinion that contemporary circus and theatre can cross linguistic as well as cultural borders.
The members of Zirkrobajka themselves come from different countries and backgrounds. Some of them work with circus or theatre on a professional level, for others it has been a passion for years, others are just (re)discovering performing arts.
Zirkrobajka shows us that it's possible to realize something growing and lasting without professional help or big financial means. Without working together closely within the project, but also with the partner projects, a continuity would not be possible.
Zirkrobajka is not supposed to exist only during the summer, but to provide a platform for mutual inspiration thorughout the whole year. The yearly summer tour is laying the groundwork for this development.

What are the goals and who is the project for?

After the last tours, this year we want to focus on the exchange with other young people active in performing arts. We are going to visit several projects in Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Serbia - both social projects and circus or theare groups, who are active in the social realm themselves. We want to get to know and learn from each other to mount something together - be it workshops for kids or fellow artists lead together or a free show for the people of the village or neighbourhood. This form of exchange is supposed to be more sustainable than the simple visit of a social project - all parties can learn from it.
Zirkrobajka mainly approaches kids, teenagers and young people, with or without experience in the performing arts, from various backgrounds and countries.

Why should you support Zirkrobajka?

Zirkrobajka was mounted by friends, who share the same passions: circus and performing arts, traveling and curiosity for other cultures. Since its foundation, many people have joined us and it's great to see how we can work together thorughout the year to realize a common project.
The project was never aimed at financial gain, all the people active in Zirkrobajka invest their time and ideas voluntarily.
Outside the field of professional peforming arts, there are not too many possibilities for networking and cooperation between semi-professional projects, which also have a social dimension. Zirkrobajka fills exactly this gap, which is also proven by the positive feedback of the already or to-be-visited projects.
Unfortunately, Zirkrobajka's concept of traveling through different countries and to various projects alongside with the status between a youth project and a professional one doesn't fit most funding programs. However, we still hope to be able to continue traveling and making Zirkrobajka live on!

If you are not able to donate any money, you can still help us by spreading the word about our project and this campaign! Therefore, you can also use the tool provided by indiegogo.

How will we use the money if the project is successfully funded?

During the last years, our circus bus was carrying us over many bumpy roads. After three tours, it had to retire. That's why we urgently need a new means of transport. Some of our destinations are difficult to reach with public transport. Also, a circus journey requires (apart from several artists) a lot of equipment such as costumes, juggling material, tools, tents, etc. Therefore, we want to collect money for a new (second hand) bus, which will carry us this summer and hopefully also in the future!
If we even get more money than to buy the bus, we are also happy - after all, a bus also needs insurance and gas.

You can find more information, pictures and videos as well as a actualized tour-diary during summer on www.zirkrobajka.wordpress.com.

Who are the people behind the project?

Zirkrobajka is not an official association, but an informal group and network of young people. This year's traveling crew consists of nine young women between 21 and 29 years.
Some of us go to university, others work. Some are professionals in the area of circus- or theatre paedagogy, others do performance arts as a hobby for many years already or are just rediscovering it.

Thanks to:
Anja Mangels & Maria Schmidt: movie-impressions from the tours
Mihaela Gladovic: editing & sound

story:
Hello! First World Production Company, here. We produced 'Bachelorette' as part of the 2013 Orlando Fringe Festival with your help, and we're trying to do it again. But with a different show, of course.  Check out our website to get the whole picture.

Our deal:

We're producing a show as part Orlando Fringe 2015, but need a little help getting there. Our dreams are big, but our wallets are not. And it costs money to put on a good show. Thats why we need people like YOU!

What we're asking:

We hope to raise a beautiful $2,000. It might sound like a lot, but it costs money to put on a good show!

Your money will be put to good use, including production costs such as:

  • Renting rehearsal space
  • Festival application fees
  • Props 
  • Costumes
  • Paying our hardworking cast and crew
  • Promotional materials

Why you should totally donate:

If we reach our goal, we get to keep all our money and Indiegogo only gets 4% commission. If we don't reach our goal, they get to keep 9% of the funds. Plus, you'll help make our little Fringey-dreams come true!

If you're broke (like us):

Times are hard. We get it! If you don't have any spare change to throw our way, come see our show anyway! All four performances will be FREE OF CHARGE.

story:
Hello!  My name is Bronwyn Preece: an improvisational eARThist who lives completely off-the-grid on a small island off the west coast of British Columbia.  I am the pioneer of earthBODYment: both an exploratory arts-based method which I facilitate and an orientation towards reciprocal performance.  My artistic explorations through site-specific improvisations, writing and visual art have me continuously exploring my relationship to earth in this time of unprecedented ecological/social crisis.  My current work is focussing particularly on embodying notions of 'ecology' and 'disability': exploring both the metaphoric and material implications of these orientations with relevance to our current climatic crisis and my own embodiment of both terms.  I am trying to explore these questions in both a personal and global context...and am trying to be as judicious and as ethical as I can be with regards to international travel methods....

I am seeking your assistance towards assisting with my travel expenses to the UK in April/May...where I will have the opportunity to perform, offer a workshop and work with other artists: enhancing my perspective and ability to both develop my own artistic palette...but also to add dimension to the offerings I share with others!  I would be so GRATEFUL for any and all help....and wow there are some amazing perks to be had....from pins, to cards, to books, to even the possibility of a private performance!

I thank you from the bottom of my heart....

and I can also draw your attention to my website where there are many examples of both my performance and written work: www.bronwynpreece.com

(Please note that the expenses associated with this trip are far greater than what I am asking...I am just conscious of not being greedy....!)

In Deep Gratitude,

Bronwyn

story:
Our workshop team for Ever Onward contains six actors, a director and a musical director. Each member of the team will be paid in line with standard Independent Theatre Council rates, and any funds we raise via Indiegogo will go towards this part of our budget.

We have been fortunate to receive the incredibly generous support of The Other Palace for all rehearsal and performance space.

All other administrative costs associated with the project (photocopying, recording, contingency) will be covered by ourselves.

Thanks in advance for any support you can give!

story:
MTM 2021: New world. New ways. New works. 

Music Theatre of Madison has programmed an exciting 2021 season and you can help us make it truly remarkable! Featuring a musical theatre concept album, a brand new, Madison-based musical, and a multidisciplinary children's book, we have created a program that we feel adapts to the challenges of the year with diverse, unique, powerful storytelling.

Music Theatre of Madison is Madison, Wisconsin's home for the new and different in musical theatre. With the support of an incredible community of artists, staff, donors, volunteers, grantors, and sponsors, we have been able to grow, innovate, and create exciting theatrical works that are diverse, local, unique, and professional. Because of this, our 15th anniversary season is a real milestone: Our first season of 100% new work. This season includes:

AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY
A professionally recorded musical theatre concept album with each song on the album being worked on and written by BBIPOC (Black, Brown, Indigenous, and Person of Color) creatives in Wisconsin.

AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY asks the creators and the audience "what is the canon of American Mythology?" "Who is in our American Pantheon?" "What lessons do we learn from them?" "Where does our magic come from?" "Where are the myths we find within our own myths?" At the core, AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY is an exploration of the complex stories we tell and the stories that aren't being told in the modern United States.

Co-Directed by Adam Qutaishat and Nathan Fosbinder
Written by:
Camille Hunt
Christian Adams
Clara Adams
Maaz Achmed
Jackey Boelkow
Anthony Cao
Alexis "L.E.X." Dean
Autumn Maria Reed
Hayley San Fillippo
Kailea Saplan
Shayne Steliga
Mark Wurzelbacher

THE LAND OF THE GIFTED

 

A diverse classroom of students with disabilities learns to believe in themselves and each other while working on a project provided by their teacher. The Land of the Gifted is a multimedia project written by Krystyn Jones, illustrated by Ana Gonzalez, and composed by Adam Qutaishat. The audiobook will be directed by Siobhan Jackson.
  
When it's all done, this multi-faceted project will consist of:
- Print versions of the book in English and Spanish, with a playlist included to hear the songs as the book is being read.
- E-books in English and Spanish with the same playlist included.
- An online "read-aloud" video featuring the illustrations, voiced, sung, and narrated by local youth actors and including an ASL translator.
- Free distribution to 100 Dane County libraries, schools, and community centers.
- Sales of the books for whomever would like a copy.
- Visits to schools and libraries across Dane County to do readings, sing-alongs, and discussions with kids.
- Online educational content that will include the sheet music and an adapted short play version for kids to act out with their friends.

THE YELLOW WALLPAPER

Book, Music, and Lyrics by Erin McConnell and Evan Lange
Directed by Janine Gardner and Trinity Gardner
Featuring MTM Executive Director Meghan Randolph
Streaming LIVE August 13-15th, 2021

In the late 1800s, a woman suffering from a "nervous condition" is brought to a country house to recover. Her husband refuses a first-floor room and instead selects the top floor of the home, a large space covered end to end in a bizarrely-patterned yellow wallpaper, by which the woman is instantly disgusted. As the weeks pass, her condition deteriorates, and she discovers a terrifying secret hidden beneath the paper's seams.

Based on Charlotte Perkins Gilman's iconic story, THE YELLOW WALLPAPER is an MTM original, brought to life by local composers Erin McConnell and Evan Lange, directed by Janine Gardner and Trinity Gardner, and performed by Executive Director Meghan Randolph. Embracing the story's deep impact on feminism, literature, and the horror genre, this tightly-woven psychological thriller is sure to give you chills, even on a hot summer night.

This production will include discussions with experts Emily Auerbach, Dr. Brigitte Fielder, and Karla Strand, who will explore the literary significance of The Yellow Wallpaper as well as the important history of Charlotte Perkins Gilman and what she did (and did not do) for feminism. 

Our Goals and Perks

Our goals will allow us to present the best possible season we can, reach a broad and diverse audience, and keep artists creating and exploring all of the facets of what musical theatre can be. We have three levels of funding we're hoping to achieve.

Initial Goal: $3,500

This will allow us to provide funds for additional resources to present our season to as many audience members as possible. This will include the ability to provide these events to more people free of charge. A portion of these funds will also go directly to the Artist Fund to continue our work of increasing artist pay long-term.

Stretch Goal #1: $6,500

This will allow us to commission a professional artist to develop a visual art work inspired by the the AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY concept album. (Additional Perks will be added once we meet our Initial Goal.)

Stretch Goal #2: $12,500

This will allow us to guaranteed future live performance of An AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY when it is safe to gather again and a professionally recorded Original Cast Recording of THE YELLOW WALLPAPER. (Additional Perks will be added once we meet our Initial Goal.)

Perks:

To express our appreciation for your help in meeting our goals we are offering the following thank yous to our community supporters. (All levels of donation all previous levels of thank you unless otherwise indicated.):

$10 - Special thank you in the digital program of each show.

$15 - An eerie digital wallpaper inspired by THE YELLOW WALLPAPER for your phone's wallpaper or lock screen.

$25 - Digital copy of AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY.

$50 - Poster signed by writers and musicians of AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY.

$75 - Invitation to either AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY or THE YELLOW WALLPAPER opening night gathering (AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY gathering will take place on Zoom. THE YELLOW WALLPAPER gathering will be arranged based on safety concerns and regulations at the time of the event.) 

$100 - Access to an early release of AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY before the official digital release. 

$150 - Two digital tickets to THE YELLOW WALLPAPER or a free copy of THE LAND OF THE GIFTED.

$200 - Access to a digital folder containing Librettos, Sheet Music, and Original Demos for the tracks from AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY.

$300 - Personalized thank you from the writers of AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY.

$400 - Season tickets for MTM's 2022 season. 

$500 - Credit as a sponsor in the digital program for AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY or THE YELLOW WALLPAPER. (For individual or business.) 

$750 - Backstage tour and meet and greet with YELLOW WALLPAPER team. (Either digitally or in person, dependent on the safety regulations and concerns at the time of the event.) 

$1000 - Behind the scenes video and chance to watch AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY recording session live. (Recording session will be streamed live to accommodate safety concerns related to COVID-19.) 

$2000 - A short song created especially for you by one of the composers of AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY. 

The Impact

For all shows: With your support alongside our amazing staff and artists, we'll be able to hire over 80 people for work in the Madison area.  

For An American Mythology: Your investment in us helps our organization create a concept album that offers perspectives from BIPOC writers whose heritages span the globe. 

For The Yellow Wallpaper: With your donation, our company will create a brand new piece based on the classic short story while also enlisting local experts to explore the piece's impact and Charlotte Perkins Gilman's troubled history. 

For The Land of the Gifted: Your support in conjunction with our efforts will also help us bring a brand new learning experience infused with music, visual art, and storytelling, with an emphasis on reaching kids and families who are traditionally underserved by the arts. 

Risks & Challenges

Due to the theatrical shutdown of COVID-19, we've been forced to create alternative programming for our community. This has allowed us to conceptualize events like AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY and THE LAND OF THE GIFTED, and we're very grateful for the innovation it has brought out. But uncertainties are part of innovation, and while we embrace them, we rely on a lot of people to help us get to the finish line. We have been working hard to make sure everything is done to the utmost of our artistic ability and following the safety guidelines that will protect our community and artists.

While MTM is confident that we will be able to produce all of our 2021 offerings, your support will help us continue to innovate and grow for this season and many more, while also allowing us increased flexibility to conquer the challenges of creating new art. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone can donate financially, however, that doesn't mean that you aren't a valued member of your support community. If you can spread the word about this fundraiser to five (5) individuals or organizations we will send you a special thank you from the staff at MTM in appreciation for you valuable contributions to our success!
story_txt:
MTM 2021: New world. New ways. New works. 
Music Theatre of Madison has programmed an exciting 2021 season and you can help us make it truly remarkable! Featuring a musical theatre concept album, a brand new, Madison-based musical, and a multidisciplinary children's book, we have created a program that we feel adapts to the challenges of the year with diverse, unique, powerful storytelling.
Music Theatre of Madison is Madison, Wisconsin's home for the new and different in musical theatre. With the support of an incredible community of artists, staff, donors, volunteers, grantors, and sponsors, we have been able to grow, innovate, and create exciting theatrical works that are diverse, local, unique, and professional. Because of this, our 15th anniversary season is a real milestone: Our first season of 100% new work. This season includes:
AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGYA professionally recorded musical theatre concept album with each song on the album being worked on and written by BBIPOC (Black, Brown, Indigenous, and Person of Color) creatives in Wisconsin.
AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY asks the creators and the audience "what is the canon of American Mythology?" "Who is in our American Pantheon?" "What lessons do we learn from them?" "Where does our magic come from?" "Where are the myths we find within our own myths?" At the core, AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY is an exploration of the complex stories we tell and the stories that aren't being told in the modern United States.
Co-Directed by Adam Qutaishat and Nathan FosbinderWritten by:Camille HuntChristian AdamsClara AdamsMaaz AchmedJackey BoelkowAnthony CaoAlexis "L.E.X." DeanAutumn Maria ReedHayley San FillippoKailea SaplanShayne SteligaMark Wurzelbacher
THE LAND OF THE GIFTED

 
A diverse classroom of students with disabilities learns to believe in themselves and each other while working on a project provided by their teacher. The Land of the Gifted is a multimedia project written by Krystyn Jones, illustrated by Ana Gonzalez, and composed by Adam Qutaishat. The audiobook will be directed by Siobhan Jackson.  When it's all done, this multi-faceted project will consist of:- Print versions of the book in English and Spanish, with a playlist included to hear the songs as the book is being read.- E-books in English and Spanish with the same playlist included.- An online "read-aloud" video featuring the illustrations, voiced, sung, and narrated by local youth actors and including an ASL translator.- Free distribution to 100 Dane County libraries, schools, and community centers.- Sales of the books for whomever would like a copy.- Visits to schools and libraries across Dane County to do readings, sing-alongs, and discussions with kids.- Online educational content that will include the sheet music and an adapted short play version for kids to act out with their friends.
THE YELLOW WALLPAPER
Book, Music, and Lyrics by Erin McConnell and Evan LangeDirected by Janine Gardner and Trinity GardnerFeaturing MTM Executive Director Meghan RandolphStreaming LIVE August 13-15th, 2021
In the late 1800s, a woman suffering from a "nervous condition" is brought to a country house to recover. Her husband refuses a first-floor room and instead selects the top floor of the home, a large space covered end to end in a bizarrely-patterned yellow wallpaper, by which the woman is instantly disgusted. As the weeks pass, her condition deteriorates, and she discovers a terrifying secret hidden beneath the paper's seams.
Based on Charlotte Perkins Gilman's iconic story, THE YELLOW WALLPAPER is an MTM original, brought to life by local composers Erin McConnell and Evan Lange, directed by Janine Gardner and Trinity Gardner, and performed by Executive Director Meghan Randolph. Embracing the story's deep impact on feminism, literature, and the horror genre, this tightly-woven psychological thriller is sure to give you chills, even on a hot summer night.
This production will include discussions with experts Emily Auerbach, Dr. Brigitte Fielder, and Karla Strand, who will explore the literary significance of The Yellow Wallpaper as well as the important history of Charlotte Perkins Gilman and what she did (and did not do) for feminism. 

Our Goals and Perks
Our goals will allow us to present the best possible season we can, reach a broad and diverse audience, and keep artists creating and exploring all of the facets of what musical theatre can be. We have three levels of funding we're hoping to achieve.
Initial Goal: $3,500
This will allow us to provide funds for additional resources to present our season to as many audience members as possible. This will include the ability to provide these events to more people free of charge. A portion of these funds will also go directly to the Artist Fund to continue our work of increasing artist pay long-term.
Stretch Goal #1: $6,500
This will allow us to commission a professional artist to develop a visual art work inspired by the the AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY concept album. (Additional Perks will be added once we meet our Initial Goal.)
Stretch Goal #2: $12,500
This will allow us to guaranteed future live performance of An AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY when it is safe to gather again and a professionally recorded Original Cast Recording of THE YELLOW WALLPAPER. (Additional Perks will be added once we meet our Initial Goal.)
Perks:
To express our appreciation for your help in meeting our goals we are offering the following thank yous to our community supporters. (All levels of donation all previous levels of thank you unless otherwise indicated.):
$10 - Special thank you in the digital program of each show.
$15 - An eerie digital wallpaper inspired by THE YELLOW WALLPAPER for your phone's wallpaper or lock screen.
$25 - Digital copy of AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY.
$50 - Poster signed by writers and musicians of AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY.
$75 - Invitation to either AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY or THE YELLOW WALLPAPER opening night gathering (AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY gathering will take place on Zoom. THE YELLOW WALLPAPER gathering will be arranged based on safety concerns and regulations at the time of the event.) 
$100 - Access to an early release of AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY before the official digital release. 
$150 - Two digital tickets to THE YELLOW WALLPAPER or a free copy of THE LAND OF THE GIFTED.
$200 - Access to a digital folder containing Librettos, Sheet Music, and Original Demos for the tracks from AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY.
$300 - Personalized thank you from the writers of AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY.
$400 - Season tickets for MTM's 2022 season. 
$500 - Credit as a sponsor in the digital program for AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY or THE YELLOW WALLPAPER. (For individual or business.) 
$750 - Backstage tour and meet and greet with YELLOW WALLPAPER team. (Either digitally or in person, dependent on the safety regulations and concerns at the time of the event.) 
$1000 - Behind the scenes video and chance to watch AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY recording session live. (Recording session will be streamed live to accommodate safety concerns related to COVID-19.) 
$2000 - A short song created especially for you by one of the composers of AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY. 

The Impact
For all shows: With your support alongside our amazing staff and artists, we'll be able to hire over 80 people for work in the Madison area.  
For An American Mythology: Your investment in us helps our organization create a concept album that offers perspectives from BIPOC writers whose heritages span the globe. 
For The Yellow Wallpaper: With your donation, our company will create a brand new piece based on the classic short story while also enlisting local experts to explore the piece's impact and Charlotte Perkins Gilman's troubled history. 
For The Land of the Gifted: Your support in conjunction with our efforts will also help us bring a brand new learning experience infused with music, visual art, and storytelling, with an emphasis on reaching kids and families who are traditionally underserved by the arts. 

Risks & Challenges
Due to the theatrical shutdown of COVID-19, we've been forced to create alternative programming for our community. This has allowed us to conceptualize events like AN AMERICAN MYTHOLOGY and THE LAND OF THE GIFTED, and we're very grateful for the innovation it has brought out. But uncertainties are part of innovation, and while we embrace them, we rely on a lot of people to help us get to the finish line. We have been working hard to make sure everything is done to the utmost of our artistic ability and following the safety guidelines that will protect our community and artists.
While MTM is confident that we will be able to produce all of our 2021 offerings, your support will help us continue to innovate and grow for this season and many more, while also allowing us increased flexibility to conquer the challenges of creating new art. 

Other Ways You Can Help
We know that not everyone can donate financially, however, that doesn't mean that you aren't a valued member of your support community. If you can spread the word about this fundraiser to five (5) individuals or organizations we will send you a special thank you from the staff at MTM in appreciation for you valuable contributions to our success!

story:
Short Summary

As a recently graduated undergraduate director, I have found kickstarting my theatrical difficult in the current times. Rather than wait for the industry to liven up, I've decided to take my career into my own hands and work with the medium available to me in this time: the internet! While in person theatre may not be viable for the forseeable future; experiencing a live production, thanks to technology, is. 

Why not take this opportunity to showcase my own, and many other female collaborators' talents?

This play is one that I have been in love with for 4 years now. It's an extremely dark satire on the "female teen comedy" trope. Think Mean Girls, Heathers, etc. 

The playwright perfectly sums it up in this quote: 

This is a play that deconstructs destructive female stereotypes through appropriation and release. Borrowing from contemporary tropes such as “teen comedy” as well as “classical fairy tale” narratives, the play highlights the untenable standards girls are subjected to daily while encouraging uncensored, brutal insights about womanhood.

Why funding is important:

As an independent project produced solely by myself, Grace, all financial risks are shouldered by me. While I am fortunate to have savings that will account for some costs, I cannot shoulder the costs of fully mounting a production on my own. For a specific account of projected expenses, please look below.

My biggest priority in this project is ensuring that all of my collaborators are compensated for their time and work. The entire team, including the cast, will be made up of young, 20-23 year old womxn. I believe our time, our efforts, and our voices are valuable, so I  want to show my fellow early-career collaborators that they are worth being paid for their art! 

Why this play is important: 

As a young woman, and especially as a young woman of (confused) color, I identify with nearly all of the ideations, struggles, and upsetting moments this play associates with growing up as a girl in America.  I’ve always struggled with the genre of “teen comedy,” the tropes of “mean girls,” and especially the trope of the “nice girl/protagonist" (who is almost always white, and still confusingly perfect). Admittedly, however, these stories have shaped my judgements of myself and others. Even more dangerously, these narratives have shaped who I have become, what I believe is and isn't possible for me, and where I believe I "fit" in the narrative. 

What draws me to this play is the way it unabashedly hyperbolizes the tropes of these stories. It brutally demonstrates the violent, stereotypical, yet pervasive connotations that come with being a young woman.

What I hope this play will do is make the more subtle violences embedded in the stories we tell young women visible, in order to empower everyone to change our narratives.

What We Need & What You Get

Here is a breakdown of expenses for this production:

  • Licensing costs: $300 (fee for putting on this play, goes to the playwright & her agency)
  • Actor stipends: $1750 ($250 for 7 actresses total)
  • SM stipend: $250
  • Musical Composer stipend: $250
  • Graphic Designer stipend: $50
  • Props & Costumes: $200
  • Marketing budget: $50
  • Script Printing costs: $100
  • Mics & Lights: $560
  • Zoom Premium (must be purchased as annual subscription): $150
  • Streamyard Premium (for 2 months) : $80
  • Directing Virtual Productions Workshop for Grace: $25
  • Indigogo fees- approx $150, dependent on amount of money raised. 

Any additional funds raised will go toward increasing cast and team stipends. 

Risks & Challenges

The show is a risk. It is deliberately not "Politically Correct" and therefore is not a play that will sit well with audiences from many different sides of the spectrum. I believe in the narrative purpose of the potentially uncomfortable or disturbing moments in the play, and aim to handle them in the most respectful, safe, and non-gratuitous way possible. Audiences will be warned of any potentially triggering or upsetting subject matter well in advance, as well as immediately prior to every performance. 

Other Ways You Can Help

I completely understand that many people are not in a financial situation where they are able to donate. That's totally fine! Here are some ways you can help besides donating:

  • Sharing this Indigogo campaign on your social media! 
  • Sharing any marketing campaigns on your social media!
  • Spreading the word to your family and friends. 
  • Spreading the word to any theatre industry folx you may know! Especially theatre critics!
  • Share ideas & feedback with our team about how we can better market and fundraise this project! Email gdolezalng@gmail.com .

story:
STRETCH GOAL!!!!

We are so thrilled to have hit our initial goal of $2000 in under two weeks!  We have set a stretch goal of $3000 and would be so grateful if you would contribute any amount to help us reach this new goal.  Why do we still need money? Because our initial goal of $2000 covered the bare bones costs of making this show happen.  With this figure, provided we sell a decent amount of tickets, we will be able to pay our theater rental figure ($700), our lighting designer ($250), our producer ($500), our floor rental ($250), and marketing expenses ($300) - but leaves no money to pay to our professional performing artists.  It is a sad reality that in the arts, especially in dance, the DANCERS who actually make the show what it is are often the last people paid.  Please help us show our performers that we value them by helping us raise that extra $1000 that will be paid to them!  Read below for our full story if you aren't familiar with this project yet!

WHO ARE WE?

Touché Taps was founded in July 2014, and since its inception, the company has maintained commitment and attention to providing quality tap and percussive dance education to teens and adults.  By pairing professionals and students, the company strives to continue tap and percussive dance’s long history of cultivating and nurturing community. By bringing together guest artists, professionals, and students from across Massachusetts, New Hampshire and the greater Northeast, Touché Taps offers affordable, high quality instruction to those interested in diving deeper into a dance form that is not often at the forefront of studio dance education.

About the Artistic Director:

Shaina Schwartz has been performing and teaching throughout New England for over 10 years.  An attendee of the Boston Youth Moves program at Jeannette Neill Dance Studio, she went on to study music and theater at the Hartt School of Music in Hartford, CT. A former resident artist at the award-winning children's theater, The Peacock Players, and dance captain/co-choreographer with the Boston Tap Company, Shaina is now the primary tap instructor at Boston University and several Greater Boston area studios.  As Artistic Director Touché Taps, Shaina has provided comprehensive music, dance and composition training to over 300 dancers, ages 7-65+!

THE SHOW:

Touché Taps was founded in July 2014, and since its inception, the company has maintained commitment and attention to providing quality tap and percussive dance education to teens and adults.  Touché Taps believes that performance is an incredibly important aspect of education: in order to fulfill their mission of well-rounded education, the company seeks to showcase the students’ and professionals’ hard work and dedication throughout the 2017-2018 season.  4 on the Floor will feature works performed by students, professionals, and a mix of both, all influenced and enhanced by a year of intensive study with some of the finest tap educators in New England and beyond.  This show will take place in the Studio 7 event space at The Dance Complex on Sunday October 21 at 6 and 8pm: for more information, or to buy tickets, be sure to visit 4onthefloor.eventbrite.com!

The Impact

At this point, it has been well documented that access to arts education is incredibly impactful for youth.  On average, adolescents exposed to arts education are less likely to use drugs and alcohol, and are more likely to be engaged in academic pursuits and optimistic about their academic futures.  Research also shows that exposure to the arts at a young age is a strong predictor of continued participation in the arts in adulthood.  The arts continue to benefit individuals as they age.  Young adults who continue to participate in the arts tend to be more optimistic about their futures and engaged in academic pursuits.  Beyond emotional health and academic engagement, dance in particular is becoming increasingly recognized as a method to help treat Parkinson's disease, and of course, has always been known as a way to stay physically fit and mentally strong.  Dancers have strong balance and coordination skills, become dizzy less often than non-dancers, and maintain higher levels of serotonin (our "feel good" hormone).

Touché Taps is a company that is committed to providing low-cost, high-quality dance instruction to recreational and professional dancers of all ages.  In supporting Touché Taps, you are supporting not only this production and those performing in it, but the health and well-being of the hundreds of students who receive arts engagement via the company.  Furthermore, if we are successful in our fundraising efforts for this show, we will be able to offer tickets at an extremely affordable rate (as little as $8!), which will remove one of many barriers to entry for those who wish to enjoy the benefits of witnessing live performance... this can be just as valuable for people as doing the actual dancing!

The Budget

We are anticipating production costs for this show to be between $1800 and $2200.  This includes very modest quotes for theater rental, lighting design, printing costs, and marketing fees... it all adds up quickly!  We also hope to pay modest honorariums to each of our professional performing artists, all while keeping costs low for attendees.  Even if we sell out each of our performances, we would likely be at a deficit of $2000 or more.  There are very few dance performances in Boston, the United States, and even the world that are able to cover all costs via ticket sales.  Fundraising is a necessity for almost all art forms in this country, but especially for dance.  We absolutely need a minimum of $2000 in order to make this show a reality.  Any money raised over $2000 will allow us to increase honorariums paid to dancers, thereby more accurately reflecting their incredible commitments of time, energy, and talent.

RISKS & CHALLENGES

We are putting this together VERY quickly and with VERY little back up funding.  Every dollar helps, but if we are unable to raise enough of them, we will not be able to host this show.  Additionally, many of our current dancers are based in New Hampshire.  Doing a show in Boston will take us a little further away from our usual audience.  We are hoping that making this move will help us connect with new friends and fans, but we might need some help in drawing attention to this double header event.

OTHER WAYS TO HELP:

If you want to help, but are lacking the financial means to do so, contributions of any kind, big or small, tangible or intangible, are greatly appreciated:

-Spread the word! Share this project with folks who might be interested, and help us gain some momentum.

-Stay connected! Follow us on Instagram and Facebook (@touchetaps).

-Attend one of our events! We are planning on hosting a few fundraising events leading up to the show.  Follow us on social media to learn more!

-See the show! Get a group together and come watch us light up The Dance Complex.  We made an effort to price tickets affordably, but if funds continue to be a barrier, please let us know and we will get you a discount if we are able to!

OTHER WAYS TO HELP:
If you want to help, but are lacking the financial means to do so, contributions of any kind, big or small, tangible or intangible, are greatly appreciated:-Spread the word! Share this project with folks who might be interested, and help us gain some momentum.
-Stay connected! Follow us on Instagram and Facebook (@touchetaps).
-Attend one of our events! We are planning on hosting a few fundraising events leading up to the show.  Follow us on social media to learn more!
-See the show! Get a group together and come watch us light up The Dance Complex.  We made an effort to price tickets affordably, but if funds continue to be a barrier, please let us know and we will get you a discount if we are able to!

story:
OUR STORY

We are Natalia Bushnik and Robin Luckwaldt. Together, we form KAIROS theatre.

There is a complex, grey morality in each of us. We strive to connect to this place through our work. Above all, our mission is to give power to the underestimated through performance. We are, predominantly, a physical theatre company; the stories and the structures of our plays are dependent upon the movement score supporting our original text. We have collaborated on, and produced four original works. Our first, The Bathtub Girls, is a fiction inspired by the first documented case of sibling matricide in Canada. The Bathtub Girls began as a contact improvisation project at the University of Windsor in 2016, and has since travelled in Canada and the US. We feel that it's high time we share it with the vital community here in Toronto. 

The Bathtub Girls is a fiction inspired by the first documented case of sibling matricide in Canada. The play follows two sisters who, encouraged by their friends, drown their mother in the bathtub of their family home. The play examines how three immigrants’ determination to assimilate into a Canadian suburb in Mississauga leads to the destruction of their family, and the rebuilding of the girls' lives. Their mother falls into a deep depression and alcoholism, until — from their perspective — the only solution is to end her life.

This is a story of marginalized young women. It is culturally necessary that we uplift the stories and needs of young people; it is our responsibility to help them cultivate tools for their future. The Bathtub Girls is an effort to wake people to this necessity. The events of the story take place in part due to neglect and complacency from the girls’ community. Our play exemplifies the consequences of ignoring young people in their times of need.

In its various iterations over the past three years of development, The Bathtub Girls has been produced at: Hamilton Fringe (Critics’ Choice, 2016); Tapestry Opera Space, as part of Then They Fight's Then Speak series 2017; Winnipeg Fringe 2017; and the curated season of the Twin Cities Horror Festival 2018, Minneapolis, USA.

Praise for The Bathtub Girls :

“A dark but compelling piece of theatre” - CBC

“Truly remarkable” - Minnesota Playlist

“Gripping storytelling” - City Pages, Minneapolis

“Extraordinary” - Winnipeg Free Press

“Truly phenomenal” - Fringe Review

What We Need

We have been given the incredible opportunity to perform a two-week run of our show, The Bathtub Girls; however, we will not be able to stage this production without the generosity donors like yourself. We are launching this campaign as an effort to cover costs for the rental space, purchase stage/costume materials, and provide subsistence for our Stage Manager, Sound Designer, Lighting Designer, and ourselves.

The Impact

A great strength of the show is the use of music and voiceover montages to score movement. We intend to take this integral aspect to a new level, by hiring and collaborating with the inimitable Phoebe Wang as Sound and Set Designer. Phoebe Wang is a queer installation and sound artist working between the US and Canada. She was recently named a 2018 NLGJA Excellence in Journalism Award winner, and Best New Artist at the 2018 Third Coast International Audio Festival for her work, God + The Gays. She was a member of The Heart, an audio art project and podcast, and the senior producer of The Shadows podcast (CBC). She designed five cues in our most recent iteration of The Bathtub Girls, and her work greatly enriched the arc of the play.

Other Ways You Can Help

Monetary donations aren't the only way to contribute! Make some noise and spread the word about our campaign, and The Bathtub Girls at the Assembly Theatre, May 21 - June 1, 2019!

xoxo

scrub a dub dub.

- Natty and Bobby

story:
From the team who brought you ‘The Diary of a Hounslow Girl’. Writer Ambreen Razia returns with her second play, POT, exploring the landscape of Britain’s invisible children, adrift in the care system and inadvertently impacted by gang culture.  Ambreen developed a passion for telling stories which were on her my doorstep but rarely ever seen in the mainstream. Excited by some of the stories she's heard by the young people she'd taught, it's now a mission of hers to carry their voices on to our stages and make sure that the theatre industry is accessible enough to provide seats to the voices and communities in which it portrays. 

POT

Louisa wakes up in a flat on her estate surrounded by debris from last night’s blow out. Her boyfriend, Josh’s effort to conceal last night’s events is faltering. With the front door sealed and no signal on her phone, she realises she is not alone. Is Miles her means to get back to the world and reclaim her existence?    

Pot was inspired by Ambreen's work surrounding Gang culture as a facilitator, and also the likes of Tracey Millers autobiography 'Sour' and the Britain's forgotten  children season on channel 4.

The play explores questions which need answers: 

Why are young people who come from care falling into Gang culture?

Why is their sense of belonging not being met?

Does society provide enough rehabilitation programmes and opportunities for our young people?

POT explores these questions through the characters which gives audiences a greater personal and intimate insight as to why ‘Gang culture’ is on the rise and why young people who come from care often turn to crime.

Outreach

As well as creating a full production and touring POT, We will engage audiences with Q&A discussions after performances. Having worked as a facilitator for a number of years Ambreen will run workshops around some of the themes within the play. It's Ambreen's aim to set up open and facilitated discussions between audiences, those who have come from care the system, ex-gang members, care workers and local councils. The key questions being - How can we work together to help dissolve gang culture? How can we work together to make sure young people who leave care are able to re-assimilate into society in a healthy way? 

Partners

 

We are working with our partners, Ovalhouse and Stratford Circus to plan a production and national tour for Autumn 2018. We need to raise funds to make this happen. Our approach to raising income is through:

  • Partners support
  • Fees from tour venues
  • An application to Arts Council England
  • Match-funding

Match-funding is crucial for Arts Council England as they will not invest in project without partners and match-funding. We are keen to make the best production we can, we want to ensure we can pay all our artists and creative team professional fees and we want to fully realise our aims for the production and its promotion.

We've set a reasonable target of raising £1200 from this campaign and with your help, reaching this target will help us to:

1) Pay all the cast and creative team professional fees (Equity/ITC)

2) Confirm a full design team and provide them with a reasonable budget to create a sound, lighting and stage design that is suitable for touring

3) Cover costs and expenses for Tracey Miller (Ex Gang members of the under 28's) to run Q&A sessions and be a part of rehearsals

4) Work with our filmmaker, Sean Hynes and photographer, Suzi Corker, to make a promotional trailer and promotional images to help marketing the show

5) Work with a Press Agent to ensure that the themes of the show are being highlighted in the media and provoke discussion online, in print, on the radio and hopefully nationwide

In return for your contributions we have a range of Perks & Rewards including:

  • Tickets to see POT the play at Ovalhouse, Stratford Circus Arts Centre or on Tour

  • Signed copy of the playtext

  • Meet the cast & team 

How you can help?

Gang culture is a worldwide issue and sit's within the cracks of every city. Once we bring this issue to the surface only then can we dissect it and make a difference. POT the play allows us to do that in an incredibly engaging way. Following an initial development at Ovalhouse in March 2017 we sold out 3 scratch performances as part of FIRST BITES. Our conclusion is that there is a hunger for stories like this.

Without your donation, there is a risk of having to cut costs which reduces the quality fo the production and reduces the audience experience. We need your contribution to set up post shows and workshops with those people. This is an important part of the process in order to make sure people aren't being excluded from seeing and engaging with their own stories. Make a donation and we will be able to reach people who have a direct connection to the themes and character E.g. ex-gang members, people who are working with ex-gang members, young adult care leavers, families and individuals who have been affected by gang culture and the care system.

Staging and touring a show involves teamwork and there are many costs, such as: transporting the set and cast and making sure they've somewhere to stay when touring. With your help we can tell this story and hopefully bring it to your local theatre! Every single contribution is valuable, from £1 to £1000 it will go directly towards the costs of bringing POT THE PLAY to life!

We understand money is tight! If you are unable to make a contribution at this time, you can still help:

  • Share this campaign with others, spread the word and make some noise about it. Share this campaign link on your social media, call/text/whatsapp/snapchat/email your friends, family and network
  • Booking the show, if you're a venue programmer and interested, please get in touch
  • If you work with care leavers and/or ex-gang members and would like to get involved, let us know

Thanks for your time and hope to see you at a performance of POT in Autumn 2018!

#pottheplay

story:
THE PLAY

In April 1915, chemist Fritz Haber is already recognized as the giant of Western science who literally pulled food out of thin air with the Haber-Bosch process, averting the famine that threatened the world in 1912.  This will win him the Nobel Prize, but right now the world is at war and Fritz has just come home from the front.  His wife Clara Immerwahr, the first German woman to become a Doctor of Chemistry, is appalled to learn that he has directed the release of chlorine gas near the Belgian town of Ypres. 

Fritz Haber has brought chemical warfare to the Western Front and into the 20th century. 

The explosive argument that follows has implications for more than just the Haber family.  This is a true story that combines science with family drama into a ferocious spectacle that to this day shakes the world.

Our goal is to raise $6,000.00

And perhaps more.  $6,000 will get the production started by helping us to:

  • Hire experienced actors.  The roles of Fritz and Clara are demanding and difficult.
  • Construct costumes -it's hard to get a 1915 uniform of a German Captain of Infantry.
  • Acquire rehearsal space, festival fees, props and other items. 
  • Construct a light and transportable set.
  • Create Programs, Posters and Marketing Materials.
  • Hire our Musical and Technical Directors.

But the single performance at the Milwaukee Fringe Festival is only the beginning.  If we can raise the entire $6,000, then there will be;

  • Theater rental and a longer production at a Milwaukee venue in the Spring of 2018.  Several theaters have indicated interest. 

Our expanded goal

We have left open the option of raising funds past our goal, to a maximum of $16,200.  With the extra funds, then after the production in Milwaukee, we can stage, also in the spring of 2018;

  • Performances at the esteemed Broom Street Theatre in Madison, WI.  The Broom Street is sometimes described as America's original hippie theater, an alternative space open since 1969.
  • Tour of the production to at least two other venues in Wisconsin, and one in Minnesota, who have indicated interest. 

Why This Play Is Important, or What's At Stake?

Can we make science a religion?  Can a scientist free himself from all moral considerations? Is scientific progress always progress for humanity?  Clara Immerwahr confronts her famous husband with these questions and more, never letting him distract her with his insistence that he is first of all a German patriot.  Demanding to know why Fritz would let himself become a tool for a class system that sneers at converted Jews such as themselves, their argument roars into the night louder than any barrage on the Western Front.

We are now living in the centenary of The Great War, and to the best of our knowledge, this is the only play about World War One being produced in the United States.  In a world where some estimates claim that half of all scientists are working on military projects, WHO ARE YOU, FRITZ HABER? addresses a monumental issue:   When you've applied scientific genius to weapons of mass destruction, have you really served your country? 

The Haber family, one of the most accomplished in German history, was destroyed trying to answer this.  A warning for the future?  We shall see. 

Who are we?

Since 2011, KACM Theatrical Productions has developed new plays such as SQUARE; searched out unusual plays such as THE LIZARD KING, a rarely produced dark comedy about rock star Jim Morrison's last days in Paris; and adapted the award-winning science fiction story THE DARFSTELLER as a play.  What we bring to the stage is always worth seeing.  Our web page is linked for further information.

What Do You Get?

Any help is greatly appreciated, and we've offered some fun perks for our supporters to enjoy.

But this production offers more than just perks.  Some stories should never be forgotten, and the tragedy of Fritz Haber and his family is one of them.  The themes involved in WHO ARE YOU, FRITZ HABER? involve the impact of war on a family, the corruption of conscience every war generates, the incredible contribution Germany made to western science in the beginning of the 20th century, the contradictions of a religious minority in a country that looked down on them even while they loved it; and the awesome, and to this day unresolved implications that the world's first industrialized war brought with it. 

All is quiet now on the Western Front; but the Great War continues on other fronts, closer than you realize.

But if you can't contribute

Please share our page with those who can.  Any German-American society and club.  Any Jewish or Franco-American organization.  Anybody fascinated with the history of the Great War.  People who admire science or worry about it's implications.  Those who study family and relationships.  And especially those who want to see the unusual and unexpected when they go to the theater.  All will find value in our project.

story:
HI THERE!

We are Opera Lab, an ensemble specialized in experimental contemporary music theatre, based in Berlin. Last November we had the opportunity to work with the Filmmaking Team Counter Production. Over the course of two days with three cameras they made a cinematic documentation of our production of "Gunfighter Nation" that was incredible! That was funded by the German Council of Music. Sadly, it was a one time opportunity...
We want to continue working with Counter Production and making high quality operatic movies to reach a wider audience, so WE NEED YOUR HELP!

 

About "STAATSTHEATER"

Pierre Boulez memorably declared in 1971 that the future of opera lay in the destruction of all opera houses, but in the very same year, Mauricio Kagel presented a revolutionary vision of the clean-up operation that could follow. The première of "Staatstheater" at the Hamburg State Opera disassembled the traditional operatic institution and indeed the whole genre into its constituent parts, creating a much sought-after path for new music theatre which is as relevant today as it was almost half a century ago.

In creating the score, Kagel gathered hundreds of theatrical, instrumental, vocal and physical miniatures; certain rules govern their usage, but they are fundamentally intended to be combined freely into a unique production. A new interpretation of the work therefore presents a compositional jigsaw whose pieces have neither clear edges nor, when combined, can present an overall picture.

Kagel's music theatre however operates beyond simple representation; one finds no acts and figures or beautiful songs about emotions or feelings. It rather creates a kaleidoscope of distorted quotations rotating lewdly around themselves, presenting a grotesque representation of a damaged world.

 

Our Take on the Piece

If Opera Lab Berlin is to devote itself to recreating Kagel’s classic yet rarely performed magnum opus, then we must also design a kaleidoscope-like musical theatre world which interested in more than itself. In our version, the elderly Staatstheater will become a Theatre of the Elderly State:

Amongst the ruins of destroyed opera houses, the Phantom of the Opera runs its retirement home. Through torture chambers from the days of the commune, eternal youth is forced into a hospice without a memory of the future, the Zeitgeist has been diagnosed with dementia...

 

Meet the "STAATSTHEATER" Cast:

Performers: Catherine Gayer, Klaus Lang, Alba Genitili-Tedeschi, Alexandros Giovanos , Evdoxia Fillipou, Mia Bodet, Jone Bolibar Nunez, David Eggert, Shin Joo Morgantini, Magnus H. Jonsson, Gina May Walter, Angela Braun, Enrico Wenzel, Antoine Daurat and more.

Artistic director and compositional editor: Evan Gardner
Director: Michael Höppner
Musical Director: Antoine Daurat
Choreographer: Margaux Marielle-Trehoüart
Set design: Martin Miotk, Cristina Lelli
Costume design: Günter Hans Wolf Lemke
Light: Fabian Eichner
Make up: Martin Rink

Supported by the Hauptstadtkulturfonds Berlin

              

 

Première: 2nd May 2017, 8pm at Ballhaus Ost
Further performances: 3rd, 5th, 6th and 7th May, 8pm

Tickets: 15€ / 10€
Booking: +49 30 440 391 68 / karten@ballhausost.de

For more information visit us via our website and on Facebook!

- www.opera-lab-berlin.com
- www.facebook.com/events/1357742090949122/
- www.instagram.com/operalabberlin/
- www.ballhausost.de

 

 

About OPERA LAB BERLIN

Opera Lab Berlin is an independent, free-form ensemble dedicated to creating interdisciplinary music theatre that is tightly bound to its contemporary surroundings.

A laboratory for instrumental and vocal performances, the ensemble breaks down traditional musical and theatrical forms: distilling, filtering, boiling, heating, mixing, crystallizing, freezing, melting, and then recombining all possible genres until something new has been found. We aim to premiere new musical theatre works alongside unique versions of pre-existing contemporary repertoire. The cornerstone of our ensemble is equality amongst all artists involved. Opera Lab Berlin is its own producer and curator, a platform for the production and dissemination of new music theatre with cooperative and collective authorship.

Opera Lab Berlin emcompasses everyone involved in our musical theatre world. At the heart of our work is the performer, there to entertain and engage an audience whilst also promoting and popularizing contemporary music through its fusion with contemporary theatre. By deliberately not restricting our modes of artistic production or representation, a genuine sense of worldliness can form the basis of our musical theatre. Contemporaneity means for us to be independent of the cultural zeitgeist; to have a self-critical awareness of reality. As our work develops both theatrically and musically, thematically and physically, Opera Lab Berlin can address the ever-broadening needs and desires of our surrounding environment. We are continually striving to provide an open door for all to our musical theatre experience. 

 

Help us to record our production capturing the show from a unique point of view, making it available not just to our Berlin audience but to everybody!

 

7.000 € will pay for:

- Sound Equipment + Fees (1.500 €)

- Camera / Lighting Equipment + Fees (5.000 €)

- Administation Fee (500 €)

 

THANK YOU SO MUCH!

A big THANK YOU to all our supporters for your donations and your constructive feedback!  
You make this project possible! Please keep spreading the word, come visit our performances and we look forward to sharing the final work with all of you!
story_txt:
HI THERE!We are Opera Lab, an ensemble specialized in experimental contemporary music theatre, based in Berlin. Last November we had the opportunity to work with the Filmmaking Team Counter Production. Over the course of two days with three cameras they made a cinematic documentation of our production of "Gunfighter Nation" that was incredible! That was funded by the German Council of Music. Sadly, it was a one time opportunity...We want to continue working with Counter Production and making high quality operatic movies to reach a wider audience, so WE NEED YOUR HELP! About "STAATSTHEATER"Pierre Boulez memorably declared in 1971 that the future of opera lay in the destruction of all opera houses, but in the very same year, Mauricio Kagel presented a revolutionary vision of the clean-up operation that could follow. The première of "Staatstheater" at the Hamburg State Opera disassembled the traditional operatic institution and indeed the whole genre into its constituent parts, creating a much sought-after path for new music theatre which is as relevant today as it was almost half a century ago.
In creating the score, Kagel gathered hundreds of theatrical, instrumental, vocal and physical miniatures; certain rules govern their usage, but they are fundamentally intended to be combined freely into a unique production. A new interpretation of the work therefore presents a compositional jigsaw whose pieces have neither clear edges nor, when combined, can present an overall picture.
Kagel's music theatre however operates beyond simple representation; one finds no acts and figures or beautiful songs about emotions or feelings. It rather creates a kaleidoscope of distorted quotations rotating lewdly around themselves, presenting a grotesque representation of a damaged world.
 
Our Take on the Piece
If Opera Lab Berlin is to devote itself to recreating Kagel’s classic yet rarely performed magnum opus, then we must also design a kaleidoscope-like musical theatre world which interested in more than itself. In our version, the elderly Staatstheater will become a Theatre of the Elderly State:
Amongst the ruins of destroyed opera houses, the Phantom of the Opera runs its retirement home. Through torture chambers from the days of the commune, eternal youth is forced into a hospice without a memory of the future, the Zeitgeist has been diagnosed with dementia...
 
Meet the "STAATSTHEATER" Cast:Performers: Catherine Gayer, Klaus Lang, Alba Genitili-Tedeschi, Alexandros Giovanos , Evdoxia Fillipou, Mia Bodet, Jone Bolibar Nunez, David Eggert, Shin Joo Morgantini, Magnus H. Jonsson, Gina May Walter, Angela Braun, Enrico Wenzel, Antoine Daurat and more.Artistic director and compositional editor: Evan GardnerDirector: Michael HöppnerMusical Director: Antoine DauratChoreographer: Margaux Marielle-TrehoüartSet design: Martin Miotk, Cristina LelliCostume design: Günter Hans Wolf LemkeLight: Fabian EichnerMake up: Martin Rink

Supported by the Hauptstadtkulturfonds Berlin
              
 

Première: 2nd May 2017, 8pm at Ballhaus OstFurther performances: 3rd, 5th, 6th and 7th May, 8pm
Tickets: 15€ / 10€Booking: +49 30 440 391 68 / karten@ballhausost.de
For more information visit us via our website and on Facebook!
- www.opera-lab-berlin.com- www.facebook.com/events/1357742090949122/- www.instagram.com/operalabberlin/- www.ballhausost.de
  About OPERA LAB BERLIN
Opera Lab Berlin is an independent, free-form ensemble dedicated to creating interdisciplinary music theatre that is tightly bound to its contemporary surroundings.
A laboratory for instrumental and vocal performances, the ensemble breaks down traditional musical and theatrical forms: distilling, filtering, boiling, heating, mixing, crystallizing, freezing, melting, and then recombining all possible genres until something new has been found. We aim to premiere new musical theatre works alongside unique versions of pre-existing contemporary repertoire. The cornerstone of our ensemble is equality amongst all artists involved. Opera Lab Berlin is its own producer and curator, a platform for the production and dissemination of new music theatre with cooperative and collective authorship.
Opera Lab Berlin emcompasses everyone involved in our musical theatre world. At the heart of our work is the performer, there to entertain and engage an audience whilst also promoting and popularizing contemporary music through its fusion with contemporary theatre. By deliberately not restricting our modes of artistic production or representation, a genuine sense of worldliness can form the basis of our musical theatre. Contemporaneity means for us to be independent of the cultural zeitgeist; to have a self-critical awareness of reality. As our work develops both theatrically and musically, thematically and physically, Opera Lab Berlin can address the ever-broadening needs and desires of our surrounding environment. We are continually striving to provide an open door for all to our musical theatre experience. 
 

Help us to record our production capturing the show from a unique point of view, making it available not just to our Berlin audience but to everybody!
 
7.000 € will pay for:
- Sound Equipment + Fees (1.500 €)
- Camera / Lighting Equipment + Fees (5.000 €)
- Administation Fee (500 €) THANK YOU SO MUCH!
A big THANK YOU to all our supporters for your donations and your constructive feedback!  You make this project possible! Please keep spreading the word, come visit our performances and we look forward to sharing the final work with all of you!

story:
Hello

and thank you for having a peek at our campaign! We're Off Kilter, a Glasgow based emerging theatre company. We're a female-led creative team, which we think is fairly cool. The Edge of You is our debut show, about the gaps between what we say and what we think. For more information please head to our listing on the Official Edinburgh Fringe Festival website (eek!) which you can access here.

The Edge of You was originally created for the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland's On The Verge Festival in June 2017. It was pretty well received. So well in fact, that we won the Bruce Millar award to help us take the show to the fringe. Now we've revamped, rewritten, gotten in a wonderful team of people, and we're ready to go.

Unfortunately, the fringe is pretty expensive. Even with many wonderful people and organisations volunteering time and resources, we still come up short. The £5000 we received from Bruce Millar pretty much covers our venue, set, marketing, travel, and rehearsal costs. We still need to at least £1000 to ensure that the actors can still pay their rent while taking a chance on this wonderful new play. Reaching our stretch goal of £2000 would ensure that nobody ends up out of pocket. Even if we don't reach our goal, any amount of money would be a massive help. 

If you honestly can't chuck any money our way, that's cool. We understand. But there are things you can do to help. If you could share our campaign on Twitter, Facebook, Instagram, at your village knitting group, that would be amazing. And if you're coming to the Fringe this year, please come see our show and say hi!

Thanks for reading all this. 

Love,

Off Kilter
