story:
Here are some quick links for your

The Play ** The Money ** The Team 
Plans B, C, D... ** Your Help ** Special Thanks

MOS is a vibrant piece of theatre that focuses awareness on American Sign Language and its critical importance in Deaf education.   Our multi-talented production team, half of which is made up of Deaf actors, designers, administrators and crew is working to bring this play Off Broadway and ultimately to Broadway. 

It's time to bring the world's attention to this little known  but fascinating and significant part of American History and the dynamic beginnings of Deaf culture.  

Help Movements of the Soul make its journey to the BIG LEAGUES by supporting this Indiegogo Campaign.

We are honored to welcome the preeminent neurosurgeon and author of Seeing Voices, Dr. Oliver Sacks to our advisory board.

Back in the 1800s, two iconoclastic men brought Deaf education to America using a revolutionary technique of teaching in the Deaf’s native language:  sign language. 

Most of mainstream America doesn’t know about Laurent Clerc and Thomas Gallaudet.   They broke down barriers and changed the world in the face of insurmountable odds.    

 a play in two acts, is about the day they confronted the most difficult obstacles of all:  themselves.   

This theatrical production is a passionate introduction to their incredible story told in a dazzling display of American Sign Language, English and French by a top-shelf cast of Deaf and hearing actors.

Alexandria Wailes as Eliza Boardman and Frank Dattolo as Laurent Clerc in workshop.  Photo courtesy of Allan Rothstein

With the help of this dedicated Broadway-credited cast and with the multi-talented director, Joe Cacaci at the helm, playwright Carol Schneider, has carved out and refined this play for the past six years. 

Our long term goal is to get this production to Broadway. 

This Indiegogo Campaign is part of a series of concerted efforts we’re making to achieve this goal.

Join the Movement and  be a part of this show’s monumental journey. 

Back to Top

This $60,000 raise is the key to the kingdom for us, it will provide the makings of an elegant, vibrant workshop/backers audition that displays the talents of the company and the poignancy of the story for producers, investors & artistic directors. 

It will pay for:

  • Union salaries of the large cast of ten high-caliber performers and a stage manager for the concentrated rehearsal time needed to translate the play and get it on it’s feet. 
  • Salaries for the sign master, choreographer and company manager.
  • Rehearsal space for several weeks.   

HOWEVER  as you read this, we are working through many channels, including  our team at Mana-hq to raise the full amount that will allow us to move directly into full production. 

If we raise this greater amount, your $60,000 will go into making the production that much better.  Every dollar will go towards upgrading the show in terms of set, costumes, lighting and creative captioning. 

Please note that while Indiegogo cannot accept checks, Fractured Atlas, our not-for-profit umbrella sponsor, can.   Please contact us if you would like to donate by check.  

Craig Fogel hard at work in MOS rehearsal.   Photo courtesy of Allan Rothstein.

Back to Top


Joe Cacaci, the director, has been Artistic Director of East Coast Arts, and co-AD of Berkshire Playwrights Lab, and the Playwrights Kitchen Ensemble. He has written or directed plays at The Public, The Long Wharf, The Alley, Queens Theater in the Park, Coconut Grove and Berkshire Playwrights Lab, as well as commercially in LA. He has written/exec produced prime time series and movies for CBS, NBC, ABC, SHOWTIME and Lifetime, and directed a pilot for PBS. He teaches writing at the Columbia, NYU and Wesleyan film schools.

Carol Schneider, the playwright,has spent 30 years in the theatre acting on the stage in Broadway, Off Broadway and regionally produced plays as well as in major motion pictures and films that have shown at Sundance, Tribeca Film Fest. and Slamdance.  She’s been Associate Artistic director of  the Actors Conservatory where she taught extensively.  Her writing has been seen on stage at HERE Arts Center, Berkshire Playwrights Lab,  and Naked Angel’s Tuesdays @9. 

Our Sign Master & Cast have collectively a few centuries of formidable theatre experience working with such renowned art institutions as National Theatre for the Deaf, Deaf West, the Atlantic Theatre Co., The Public Theatre, The Long Warf and the Kennedy Center among others.

Mana-hq founders, Kathryn Rolston & Ariane Brandt, their team and Richard L. Gant  & the R. L Gant Group have experience in content creation and development, production, sales, marketing and distribution.   

Our Associate Producer, Mechelle Lassiter is the result of a one night stand between Einstein and the Energizer Bunny.  Seriously.  Check her birth certificate.

The talented Jess Thurber has just joined our campaign.

We only drop names when we're really serious.  Which leads us to...

Those on our Board of Advisors have Executive Produced for Law & Order, been nominated for Pulitzers and Tony Awards, starred on Broadway, hold doctorates in history, teach at Gallaudet, interpret on Broadway, and, most importantly, they're all really nice.

We are partnering with Gallaudet University & LaGuardia Community College's ASL-English Interpreters Program.          

Frank Dattolo as Clerc, Candace Broecker, Stephanie Zimmering, in the New York Theatre Workshop supported workshop. 
Photo Courtesy of Allan Rothstein

Back to Top

….and we have more plans than letters.

So… what happens if we don’t raise our full $60,000? 

We will use what we do raise to bring a barebones, rehearsed reading for  investors, producers and artistic directors. 

But since this show is a visual feast, the more dynamically we can realize its full potential,  the better our chances are for showing off its theatrical power.

Back to Top

Your endorsement means the world to us.

  • Send the link to this campaign to 10 of your friends.
  • Like us on Facebook & follow us on Twitter.
  • Sign up for our newsletters @ www.themovementsofthesoul.com
  • Help us build our audience!

Alexandria Wailes and Stephanie Zimmering in rehearsal for MOS. Photo Courtesy of Allan Rothstein

Back to Top


Sonic Alert®, specialists in high quality, reliable alert products for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing, for being the first company to join us with their support and ongoing promotion of MOS. Please check out the special Perks they’ve generously donated.   www.sonicalert.com  

Harris Communications for spreading the word!  

American Society For Deaf Children, for joining the Movement!  

Tania O’Brien, the artistic wizard behind our logo and the beautiful posters and for allowing us to use them as Perks!

Allan Rothstein for his dynamic and elegant photo chronicle of our workshop.  All photos here are his.

Candace Broecker, Frank Dattolo, Bill Moody & Alexandria Wailes for the many ways they’ve supported this campaign and the show all these many years.

Barry Neikrug for offering his prodigeous talent to boost our Perks!

Composer Joel Styzens, via D-PAN, www.relax-your-ears.com for allowing us to use his tracks “Reflection” and “7 8 6” from his award winning album “Relax Your Ears” and for making his album available as a Perk!

Nathan Zebedeo & Fractured Atlas for their ongoing counsel and sponsorship.

Adrean Mangiardi & Mark Levin of D-PAN (Deaf Professional Arts Network) for their advice on the video www.d-pan.com. 

 Embracing diversity is the solution to so many problems in the world.  The MOS team strives to exemplify the value of inclusion by demonstrating the advantages multiple perspectives can provide.

Back to Top


Artwork courtesy of Tania O'Brien

Back to Top

story:
Short Story Short

South Philadelphia Spin Coalition is a constantly evolving troupe of flow artists, created by hoop dancers & cultivated by the spin community.

  • We're proud to have been invited to host a theme camp & perform at Pennsylvania's premier hoop festival, Return2Roots
  • In order to provide space for rehearsals, costumes for the performance, & a killer camp for the community, we need some financial help
  • We've worked hard the past 2 years to provide classes & hoops for the city of brotherly love, now it's our time to show our skills at the R2R Showcase

We are so excited to perform as a group, in front of the best performers the East Coast has to offer.  Please help us make this dream a reality!

What We Need & What You Get

While our individual members are covering most of their own needs at the festival, the group itself will need significant funds

  • Costumes, SPinCo promo materials, & camp equipment will be the bulk of the expenses
  • But we love to share!  Help fund our performance, & we'll teach you how to hoop dance.  Spend enough, and we'll not only teach you, we'll give ya the hoops!
  • We have various options ('good, better, best') for the things we need.  Even if we can't reach the $700 goal, we will still strive to provide the members & festival with a performance & camp they won't forget

More About SPinCo

Our members cultivate, maintain, and sustain the Spin Coalition. We hold weekly hoop jams and classes in Center City, in addition to community outreach programs, teaching vulnerable children how to sooth & expand their sense of self-worth by experiencing the flow of hoop dance. 

  • We dance, we teach others to dance, & we dance for others
  • We've been building our brand - & thus our group - for 2 years, with great success
  • We are all ages, all skill-levels, all backgrounds, & all about the hoop-love

Winners Never Quit!

We can do the camp & performance ourselves, but it will be MUCH BETTER with your help.  

  • Even small donations will go a long way.  We appreciate any & all help you can offer.
  • We don't just want your help, though, we also want YOU!  Donate & receive free entry to one of our weekly spin sessions.  We can't wait to dance with you! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't support us financially, you can still help!

  • Pimp us out on your social medias.  Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Message us if you have some other ideas of donations in mind

And that's all there is to it.

story:
The 40 Project

For a year starting September 1, 2014, I'm launching a funding campaign every 40 days. Nine organizations that mean something to me personally will benefit

Mission

The 40 Project is a charitable organization that creates and promotes fundraising campaigns for the time span between September 1, 2014 and September 1, 2015. Nine organizations with intrinsic personal connection to Jason Robert LeClair will benefit from this venture.

Description

On September 1, 2014, I am launching the first of 9 fundraising campaigns. Why the 40 project? I am turning 40 on September 1. For that year I want to give back. Every 40 days of my 40th year, I will be trying to raise at least $1,000 funds for nine causes that mean something to me. 

The nine fundraisers will be run through Indiegogo. All funds will be paid directly to the organizations. The organizations are as follows:


9/1/14 - 10/10/14 - Rhode Island Stage Ensemble
10/11/14 - 11/19/14 - Walk for Life
11/20/14 - 12/29/14 - Beacon Charter High School for the Arts
12/30/14 - 2/7/15 - Educational Theatre Association
2/8/15 - 3/19/15 - National Art Educators Foundation
3/20/15 - 4/28/15 - Polycystic Kidney Disease Foundation
4/29/15 - 6/8/15 - ASPCA
6/9/15 - 7/19/15 - The Haitian Project
7/20/15 - 8/29/15 - St. Thomas Food Pantry

Thank you for your support of these amazing organizations trying to better our world in so many ways!

Our first cause is the Rhode Island Stage Ensemble

We're looking for $1,000

What it will support is the ability for this amazing community theatre company (comprised of primarily volunteers) to keep going and growing. They are starting to launch a new education program that will impact the community of northern Rhode Island and nearby Massachusetts in a very positive way.

Arts enrichment for all ages and the ability to come together to learn new skills that can be applied to everyday life in a fun and safe environment is their goal. They use theatre to accomplish this. 

    The perks:

    RISE has donated several complimentary tickets and listings in their programs (over 3,000 people will see your name and/or company this season) as well as sponsorship listings for larger contributors to their website and facebook pages. They'll also send the largest contributors signed copies of all of this season's posters and programs (There may be a future star signing... you never know)!

    It's the least we can do for your your help in allowing RISE to continue their mission of education and art. 

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Please share this campaign with all of your friends. 

      There are share tools located at the top of the campaign for you to blast us out to social media!
story_txt:
The 40 Project



For a year starting September 1, 2014, I'm launching a funding campaign every 40 days. Nine organizations that mean something to me personally will benefit

MissionThe 40 Project is a charitable organization that creates and promotes fundraising campaigns for the time span between September 1, 2014 and September 1, 2015. Nine organizations with intrinsic personal connection to Jason Robert LeClair will benefit from this venture.

Description
On September 1, 2014, I am launching the first of 9 fundraising campaigns. Why the 40 project? I am turning 40 on September 1. For that year I want to give back. Every 40 days of my 40th year, I will be trying to raise at least $1,000 funds for nine causes that mean something to me. 
The nine fundraisers will be run through Indiegogo. All funds will be paid directly to the organizations. The organizations are as follows:

9/1/14 - 10/10/14 - Rhode Island Stage Ensemble10/11/14 - 11/19/14 - Walk for Life11/20/14 - 12/29/14 - Beacon Charter High School for the Arts12/30/14 - 2/7/15 - Educational Theatre Association2/8/15 - 3/19/15 - National Art Educators Foundation3/20/15 - 4/28/15 - Polycystic Kidney Disease Foundation4/29/15 - 6/8/15 - ASPCA6/9/15 - 7/19/15 - The Haitian Project7/20/15 - 8/29/15 - St. Thomas Food PantryThank you for your support of these amazing organizations trying to better our world in so many ways!

story:
A Magazine for the Global Tribal Belly Dance Community

Launched in fall of 2010, 'fuse' Magazine celebrates the creativity, artistry, and beauty that defines the Tribal and Fusion belly dance communities. Our print version is released four times a year in brilliant full color - properly showcasing and honoring this art form. We have released 10 issues, and are busily working on Issue #11, to release late this year.

In each issue, we strive to include:

  • Compelling interviews from some of the most fascinating dancers, artists and musicians
  • Articles on the history and culture of this art form, as well as international/global features and current news
  • Reviews of the latest or noteworthy DVDs, music, books and other products
  • Columns on dance therapeutics, ATS around the world, do-it-yourself creations and final adornments

Help Us Keep 'fuse' Magazine In Print

Due to rising printing and postage costs, we spend roughly $4,000 to print each edition of 'fuse' and distribute it to our subscribers worldwide. This doesn't account for the hours of time and talent spent by our writers, editors, designers and photographers working on each issue.

We need your help to keep 'fuse' in print by allowing us to get ahead in our expenses. The funds raised will go toward current and future printing and mailing costs, as well as help us continue to offer stipends to our designer and copy editors.

Our 'Thank You' Incentives

We were overwhelmed by the generosity of many who have been featured in fuse who have provided us with exciting incentives to thank those who give to our campaign. In addition to being able to offer pledgers print subscriptions and back issues, we also have a limited number of signed magazines, online and Skype classes, vouchers for upcoming events and more! And you get those thank you gifts even if we don't reach our goal. Check the incentive offerings to the right for the latest details!

Thank you in advance for your help!!

And thank you to those who generously gave incentives to support our campaign:

  • Rachel Brice and Datura Online
  • Stephanie Bolton
  • Kajira Djoumahna and Tribal Fest
  • Zoe Jakes and Beats Antique
  • Las Vegas Belly Dance Intensive
  • Carolena Nericcio
  • Deb Rubin
  • Amy Sigil
  • Something Tribal This Way Comes
  • Tempest and Nathaniel Johnstone

story:
Our Cause, Our Dance

"Welcome to the World" is a monumental work of modern dance choreographed by two-time nominated CNN Hero Susan Slotnick. The dance promotes world peace and explores the universal human experience through themes of separation, war, suffering, love, and reconciliation in a compelling 20-minute performance, first presented on stage to audiences in 2001.  This coming spring, Welcome to the World will be re-introduced with a ground-breaking collaboration of dancers from two very distinct companies: Figures-in-Flight 4 and Figures-in-Flight Released.



These two groups of dancers hail from sharply contrasting demographics.  One company (Figures-in-Flight 4) is made up of over a dozen teenage high school students from the Hudson Valley who have danced with Slotnick since early childhood.  The other is comprised of a small group of men who studied dance while serving time in state prison facilities. Having received intensive dance training under the NYS grant-funded “Rehabilitation through the Arts” program, they have since been released from prison and have continued to dance, forming Figures-in-Flight Released, a new company of their own.



In spite of their obvious differences in race, age, and background, these two groups share something that shines through on stage and in rehearsal: a love of modern dance and a commitment to mutual respect between people of all kinds. Our cause is to promote understanding between diverse groups and bring a message of peace and unity through dance to audiences.



Your help is needed…

 Bringing Welcome to the World to the public will require many hours of rehearsal over the course of six months. Getting these two groups together to rehearse will mean transportation and logistical expenses beyond the financial reach of many of the dancers. We need your support to help make this exciting idea a reality.

Funds are needed for:

  • Transportation (for the two groups to meet together for rehearsal and for travel to performance venues)
  • Promotional materials
  • Small stipends for adult dancers
  • Fees for rehearsal space


We understand that some people just can’t make a financial contribution. But there are many ways to help, including spreading the word…please let your friends know about our campaign!

More about Figures in Flight


Figures-in-Flight 4 is a dance company of young people who have been training with Susan since they were five years old; today they represent some of the Hudson Valley's finest talents. FIF4 has been selected out of many entries to perform for an unprecedented six years in a row at the prestigious Battery Dance Festival in New York. They perform frequently at Mohonk Mountain House during Christmas week and at The National Museum of Dance in Saratoga Springs.

Figures-in-Flight Released is the culmination of Susan Slotnick’s dedication to the rehabilitation of incarcerated men. Figures-in-Flight Released began six years ago at Woodbourne Correctional Facility. As the dancers achieved their freedom they regrouped and created their own “Outside the Walls” Dance Company aptly entitled “Figures-in-Flight Released.” To date they have performed at The National Museum of Dance, Vassar College, John Jay College of Criminal Justice, Fordham University, and Columbia University.


Documentary Film


Filmmaker Indrani Kopal has begun documenting the group's work thus far and plans to make a short documentary centered around this project.


David Gutnick also filmed a documentary about Figures in Flight. See video and photos from it in a feature on FIF that aired on CBC Radio with Michael Enright.

story:
We Need Your Help!!!

Every year my company, Obsidian Media Group Co-produces several projects that illuminate issues that we are seeing in our lives. From Alzheimer's in "Things That Hurt” or oppression in "Flambeaux; A Caribbean Play with Music" as well as other social issues that we approach in the short films. These are the projects that we will be representing in 2014-2015.

We need your help to bring these projects into existence. Your contribution  will benefit all three projects and is tax deductible to the fullest extent of the law. I'd like to tell you a little more about the projects your donations will be supporting.

"Things That Hurt" began as a tribute by me, writer/creator Lawrence Floyd to some of the greatest people  I know My Elders. The play is about some who are dealing with the past and others who are doing what many want to do, forgetting the past. Alzheimer's has an ironic way of doing this. "

After table-reads and many rewrites and private readings for valued critics, “Things That Hurt” came to life. With  award-winning Director Patricia R. Floyd ("Black Man Rising" and "ResurGENTs") at the helm of production once again, we are prepared to entertain and educate once again. 

Taurean Blacque of "Hill Street Blues" Fame will star as Dr. Edward Lewis.

"Flambeaux, a Caribbean Musical" is also back with an updated script and new songs.  Written by Nandi Keyi and Directed by Lawrence Floyd.

We have now expanded into Film and TV and are eagerly anticipating collaborations with Michael Alexis Palmer, Terrance Epps, Valarie Tekosky and "Faces of Darkness" Producer KT Nelson with Cecilia Flagg.

 We need your support!

Our campaign is online at Indiegogo and there are different levels of donation, which will go to support the Production:

                              Salaries for Director, Actors and Crew

                                                    Promotion

                                                   Costumes

                                                   Rehearsals

                                         Festival Submission Fee


We are set to start rehearsal in late December for a run starting January 22, 2015. I know we can  count on your support!

Look to the side and donate:


Or make your check out to:

Obsidian Media Group

And send to:

Obsidian Media Group

c/o Lawrence Floyd

566 W. 159th Street, #62

New York, NY 10032

                                

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Please  get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remember  to use the Indiegogo share tools!

                          Thank you for your support!

story:
WHO WE ARE

Last fall The Princess Academy opened with 7 girls and a BIG vision ~ to be a Christ-centered dance studio where girls learn more than dance. Within 2 months we grew to 40 girls with a wait list for next year!

 

WHAT WE DO

The Princess Academy is a program which introduces the arts through dance to at-risk, low income and interested families who want to see their girls grow in self-control, self-esteem, grace and power!

We focus on how to know Christ and live a life that honors HIM. We believe young girls can be modern yet modest, gentle, yet strong in a post-christian culture.

Being assessable to EVERYONE is our focus! 1/3 of our students are fully supported through scholarships, others receive reduced tuition and the remainder pay only $28 per month for a 1 hour class per week!

Tami Kuenning, the director and lead instructor is an elementary school educator who saw a need to help girls find a fun and healthy outlet to explore the joy of dance in an age-appropriate, supportive and instructive environment.

Our motto at The Princess Academy is: 

"This is a safe place, where girls can be themselves, make new friends and take risks by trying new things without fear of judgment".

OUR NEED

We need a wall of mirrors in our donated studio to help aid in proper instruction. The total cost for the mirrors are $1045.

After completing our first season - we have a long list of eager girls who are returning and more that want to join.

The girls are believing that there are enough people out there to help us achieve this goal! It is my wish that they will not be disappointed! Thanks so much!

Learn more about this ministry on our Facebook page and read our "info" tab!

story:
Hello!

My name is Kate and I am launching a choreography project to be performed in Manhattan. Previously, I have worked as a choreographer for off-Broadway here in New York, but I wanted to try something different. No script, new ideas, and original music. 

By funding rehearsal space, costumes, dancer and musician fees, you will help create a safe place for my choreographic journey to launch. 

UPDATE: Our debut was scheduled for the Steps Lab November 3rd, but it must be moved due to Hurricane Sandy.

What We Need & What You Get

 

A good chunk of funds will go towards rehearsal space. New York renting is costly. Our rehearsal spaces range from $10 - $18 an hour. Our material, and means of creating is the collaboration of ideas in the space. About 35 hours of rehearsal time will go into this performance! 

I have three dancers I need to costume with the help of the lovely Sally Lesser as designer. 

I have at least three musicians and three dancers to pay. And I protest the thought of starving artist! 

 

 

What's in in for you? 

$1 - A shoutout on my website

$10 - Above and a NY postcard

$25 - Above and a haiku from someone on the creative team

$50 - Above, a special production photo sent to your smartphone or email, AND up to a paragraph's worth of space to speak your thoughts about freedom on my website

$100 - Above and a Skype date preshow!

$150 and beyond - Above and special mention on my website as a big time producer

 

The Impact:

New York is the dance capitol of the world. We have just been hit by a storm - my dancers and musicians are ready to go. And we would like to inspire our city to keep moving!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share the video and campaign with family, friends, coworkers, people you meet at a party - anywhere and everywhere. No stress, just love of freedom and dance. 

Thanks!

story:
The First Gentleman is a hilarious new musical comedy, with a completely original book and score.  David Howard (Book and Lyrics) and Bret Simmons' (Composer) created this spectacular that will take you on a behind-the-scenes journey through the White House and into the lives of the most powerful family in the world.

  • Tony Nominated Robert Torti as the title role. Associate Director of the Tony Award winning Newsies and Broadway-Bound Jekyll & Hyde, Richard J. Hinds, will Direct.  Veteran Broadway Musical Director, Phil Reno, will Music Direct.  Gerry Mcintyre to Choreograph, winner of BroadwayWorld 2010 Best Choreographer Award. 

Our Story is set in the not-too-distant future. West Virginia's senator, Kathryn Noel Cassidy, has just been elected the first female President of the United States. Kathryn, her husband Russell, and 15-year-old son Steven, are transplanted into the White House, and life, as they know it, will never be the same.

For Russell and Steven, this is the first time they have ever been given this much attention, especially from the Media. Russell is thrust into a world of intense tradition, as he must now fulfill the duties held by the First Lady, such as hosting the Inaugural Tea, choosing dinnerware and attending an assortment of dedication ceremonies and events. Being an outdoorsman who likes to fish and hunt, Russell must find a way to adapt to his new environment, while maintaining his family's well being in and out of the media's eye. Steven doesn’t have it any easier. Being a regular 15-year-old kid is difficult enough, then add in a couple of secret service agents constantly tailing you.

The family is faced with a potentially devastating media crisis (caused by their son) and Russell rallies his staff to his aid. With the help of his Chief of Staff, Sally Struthers, they embark on a black-ops mission to recover the leaked materials. Ultimately, each member of the family must choose what is most important: Family or Politics.

    • Sally Struthers (Actress) - "The First Gentleman is the best new musical I've worked on in years - - honest, compelling, and hysterically funny!"
    • Robert Torti (Actor) - "I love this!!!! The idea, the Music, everything about it."
    • Lee Martino (Choreographer) - "The First Gentleman soars with music and a story that's sure to get your vote!"
    • Larry Raben (Director) - "David Howard's and Bret Simmons' newest work, The First Gentleman, is a hilarious fish-out-of-water tale. Both funny and touching with an amazing pop score."

Our Goal is to bring this show to an amazing broadway theater in 2013!  We are currently raising funds to hold a Backer's Audition in January.  A Backer's Audition is a preview of the show for major Broadway Investors (kind of like a TV pilot). As you can see, we have already assembled quite an amazing creative staff and cast.  Please help us along our path by donating to this exciting new production! 

Thank You for taking a look at our project! You can help us further by:

    • Liking our Facebook Page
    • Sharing this campaign with your friends and family
    • Every dollar donated gets us one step closer to our Broadway Debut!

Here's a look at some of your rewards!

For Russell and Steven, this is the first time they have ever been given this much attention, especially from the Media. Russell is thrust into a world of intense tradition, as he must now fulfill the duties held by the First Lady, such as hosting the Inaugural Tea, choosing dinnerware and attending an assortment of dedication ceremonies and events. Being an outdoorsman who likes to fish and hunt, Russell must find a way to adapt to his new environment, while maintaining his family's well being in and out of the media's eye. Steven doesn’t have it any easier. Being a regular 15-year-old kid is difficult enough, then add in a couple of secret service agents constantly tailing you.The family is faced with a potentially devastating media crisis (caused by their son) and Russell rallies his staff to his aid. With the help of his Chief of Staff, Sally Struthers, they embark on a black-ops mission to recover the leaked materials. Ultimately, each member of the family must choose what is most important: Family or Politics.




Sally Struthers (Actress) - "The First Gentleman is the best new musical I've worked on in years - - honest, compelling, and hysterically funny!"






Robert Torti (Actor) - "I love this!!!! The idea, the Music, everything about it."






Lee Martino (Choreographer) - "The First Gentleman soars with music and a story that's sure to get your vote!"






Larry Raben (Director) - "David Howard's and Bret Simmons' newest work, The First Gentleman, is a hilarious fish-out-of-water tale. Both funny and touching with an amazing pop score."


Our Goal is to bring this show to an amazing broadway theater in 2013!  We are currently raising funds to hold a Backer's Audition in January.  A Backer's Audition is a preview of the show for major Broadway Investors (kind of like a TV pilot). As you can see, we have already assembled quite an amazing creative staff and cast.  Please help us along our path by donating to this exciting new production! 
Thank You for taking a look at our project! You can help us further by:



Liking our Facebook Page
Sharing this campaign with your friends and family
Every dollar donated gets us one step closer to our Broadway Debut!


Here's a look at some of your rewards!

story:
HEAR the rich sound of the Goddess cry

FEEL the rhythm of feminine spirit united

SEE HERstory as it’s never been seen before  

 

Obeah Opera is a new all female a cappella opera conceived by Nicole Brooks, with music direction by Andrew Craig, based on the Salem witch trials and from the perspective of female slaves accused of practicing “obeah” (magic) in the Puritan town. The ground-breaking opera takes audiences on a spiritually sacred journey like no other seen on Canadian stages.

After only 3 years on Toronto’s theatre circuit, Obeah Opera’s accolades are remarkable, just as the story itself.

2010/2011: workshop presentations received remarkable praise from both critics and audiences crossing cultures and generations.

2012 daringly leaped to a fully staged, critically acclaimed production produced by b current and Theatre Archipelago and nominated for the 2012 Dora Mavor award for Best New Musical - a wonderful recognition of the work!

2013 Nicole and her team are back into development - enhancing the book, re-working the music and rehearsing a new workshop in May 2013.

 

HELP BUILD & SPREAD OBEAH OPERA’S MAGIC

 

Obeah Opera is still growing and needs your support over the next month. The creative heartbeat that exists behind this groundbreaking production is beating loudly, determined to see the work through to its next level.

 

Our goal is to raise $2,000 by May 26, 2013 so we can successfully workshop the piece with music director Andrew Craig and the cast of 15 amazingly talented singers including Neema Bickersteth, Saidah Baba Talibah, Saphire DeMitro, Angelique Lazarus, Nicole Brooks, and calypso queen Macomere Fifi.

 

We have already raised $7,000 from government sources and secured $2,500 from private donors for this portion of the development.  Please help us reach our goal!

 

Spread the word

 

Here are a few additional ways you can help us:

 

1. Facebook

    * Like our Facebook page and invite all your friends:

http://www.facebook.com/

2. Twitter

    * Twitter about the show and follow us at @obeahopera

3. Email:

    * Share our campaign link with friends, family, colleagues & more!

4. Other:

    * Write about us on your blog and/or newsletters.

    * Write to your local and online media about us.



More about Obeah Opera...
THE FOLK TALE NEVER SUNG, UNTIL NOW

 

The first of its kind, Obeah Opera is an a cappella opera sung by an all female cast of 15 (features 5 soloists and a Greek chorus of 10).  The opera includes musical genres found in  Black music including jazz, blues, gospel, R&B, traditional African, Caribbean folk, spirituals etc..

 

An American now turned Caribbean tale, Obeah Opera allows the audience to experience the most famous witch hunt in mankind’s history through the voices of real historical women figures of that time who were ‘silenced’ or ‘dismissed’ as their accounts are barely recognized with a mere few sentences found in the historical books.  

 

The best known slave Tituba (referenced in all historical accounts of the hunt and trials including theatrical works such as the ‘The Crucible’) along with 3 other slave women  (Mary, Candy & Sarah) who were accused of practicing witchcraft, or more accurately Obeah, along with hundreds of other women, were sent to prison.  To aid the 4 women through the actual trials and tribulations is their own fairy Goddess Mother – The Elder (also based on a real historical character named Paula Del Cruz, a powerful healer known in Columbia), comes to their aid and helps them realize who they really are as women – healers. Reminding them the need to find their power regardless of their ‘station’ as a slave and being imprisoned, there is a call to stand up and be empowered.

story:
You Can Still Donate!

While this campaign has ended, you can still donate to The Shelter! Make a tax-deductible donation online at: https://www.fracturedatlas.org/donate/4077

Donating By Check

To donate by check, make payable to FRACTURED ATLAS with "On behalf of The Shelter" in the subject line. Mail checks to: The Shelter, attention: Dave Lankford, 201 E 86th Street 27F, New York, NY 10028

Other Donations Received

We'd also like to recognize all of our donors who have donated by check:

  • Paul & Patricia Donakowski ($300)
  • Patty Kingsbaker ($250)
  • William Kingsbaker ($150)
  • Stephanie & Robert Bell ($125)
  • Robbie Kaller and Kaller Management ($100)
  • Joe Delapa ($50)
  • Cynthia Shaw & David Simonoff ($25)
  • Erica Dorn ($25)
  • Brad Golden ($25)
  • John & Kathleen Collins ($20)

And our SOARWARD HOLIDAY PARTY show and fundraiser was a huge success! Not only did everyone have a great time, but we made $1800 in profits (all of which will support Season 4 productions).

About This Campaign

In 2009, five friends founded The Shelter as a small theatre workshop to support themselves and other artists. In the ensuing years, The Shelter has grown and now houses nine staff members and fourteen resident artists working in several disciplines, including writing, directing, acting, and design. Our Sunday workshop shelters a community of over one hundred members, whose work we have developed into six productions and multiple staged readings over the course of three seasons. We’ve filled over one thousand seats with engaged audience members, and critics have called our work bold, creative, exciting, innovative, engaging, and solidly produced with exceptional production values. In 2011, our production of FAIRY TALE was selected as a Backstage Critic’s Pick.

While our shows have become ever more popular, ticket sales cover only 50% of our producing expenses. To fill the gap, we depend on people like you, who share our belief in the value of producing good theatre and sheltering artists. You’ve supported us in the past, and we’d like to partner with you again. We currently need to raise $10,000 for our fourth season. A donation of $50 pays for a costume, and a gift of $500 pays for one night's rental of a theatre. Your donation, at whatever level, can help us reach this goal.

That $10,000 will enable us to produce three brand new shows in our fourth season, starting in December 2012 with SOARWARD HOLIDAY PARTY: a one-night-only, immersive, ensemble theatre experience built around an office holiday party – and we hope you’ll party with us! We’ll return in early 2013 with GHOST LIGHT, a collection of plays set on a bare stage below a single light. Finally, The Shelter will proudly premiere a piece that’s been over a year in the making at Shelter Sunday workshops: LILY & KOSMO, a comedic space opera for all ages, performed in the style of a 1950s radio drama.

We want you to know how much we appreciate your support. That's why we've come up with some fun donor gifts, including signed original artwork by LILY & KOSMO creator Jonathan Arthur Ashley, free tickets to shows, and even a chance to be in one of our plays! Supplies are limited, so make your donation by December 31, 2012 to secure the gift of your choice.

We hope you'll join us as we continue to expand, shelter artists, serve audiences, and make really awesome theatre!

story:
Hello there, Fellow Theatre Lover,

Thanks so much for considering a donation to Touch Me Philly Productions! 

Amanda (www.AmandaSylvester.com), Penny (http://touchmephilly.wordpress.com/about-penny/) & I (www.AlysonRodriguezOrenstein.com) had such an amazing experience working together to produce fall 2012's  "The Rocky Horror Show"... with Puppets, that we decided to form a theater company to bring exciting original concepts, shows, and ideas to Philadelphia! 

Though the three of us have led very different lives, we all have a love affair with the theater that has brought us to take part on and off of the stage.  We recognized a passion for performance art in eachother and a desire to create theater that challenges audiences and ourselves in the process.  With your help, Touch Me Philly Productions will be bringing you at least 6 amazing events to you this year!

Your dollars will help us get the season going!  Money donated here will go towards every aspect of making the show go on- because it must!

Our 2013 season will include:

  • Main stage production: Charles Busch's "Psycho Beach Party"  in time for Halloween!
  • "Normal...?"  Works from Philly artists/performers/writers on the subject of what it means to be normal. (Submission details are now on our website www.TouchMePhilly.com) May 10th @ The Adrienne Theater
  • "Burlesque Bedtime Stories" Put on your PJ's & Join Us For
     A Night of Story Telling, Improv & more Adults Only "Bedtime" entertainment!  April 18th at The Adrienne Theater
  • Hosting compelling performers from out of the area & bringing their unique talents to you, through improv, story telling, or a host of other exciting platforms!
  • A night of local films!
  • Staged Readings
  • Live music & perhaps even a bit of cabaret!

 

Why should I donate to TMPP?

Between the three of us, we have worked on and off stage in a great many shows in a great many capacities.  We love this business we call show, and we know how important it is to make unique, fun, interesting theatre easily available in our city! 

We strive to create productions that are accessible to people from all walks of life.  We have worked in tandum with GLBT supportive organizations as openess and inclusivity are things we hold very dear in all we do.  We had a fantastic experience having Amercian Sign Language Interpreters during 'Rocky Horror" and will continue doing as much as we can to share with everyone who wants to be shared with.

Touch Me Philly Productions provides you with a unique view.  A view that's not afraid to ask hard questions or to have an over the top good time!  We are starting this company from the ground up, and having financial support from you makes this possible.

We are asking for $2000 to get our season rolling.  This money will go towards:

  • Deposits to secure venue space
  • Lights and sound
  • Rights/licensing fees
  • Payment to performers and technical specialists  
  • Advertising
  • so much more!
There is an enormous amount of hard work, and soul that goes into getting performance art out there, and we know we can do it with your generous donations!  If we exceed our goal through this campaign our productions will get bigger and better!  More on stage exploration of ideas, drama, laughter, eye candy, and things that make you go "Hmmm..."
 
Pretty cool, huh?  But, not *only* will you be helping us bring you some pretty rockin' shows, but you'll also receive some cool perks for your contribution!  Please, feel free to DONATE ANY AMOUNT, but know that if you donate at least as much as the perks you'll get some extra nifty stufff too! You can get tickets to shows or even season passes, Touch Me Philly Productions T shirts, stickers, or hand etched shot glasses!  Look to the right to read more about them!

Other Ways You Can Help

We know it can be tough out there, and not everyone who wants to support Touch Me Philly Productions can afford to make a donation right now.  Rest assured, that doesn't mean you can't get involved in other ways! 

  • Share this page on your facebook, gplus, twitter, or other platforms with your friends who may like to support the arts! The indiegogo share tools below make it easy!
  • "Like" and share our page on facebook- http://www.facebook.com/TouchMePhilly
  • Keep up to date yourself on upcoming shows, audition opportunities, volunteer opportunities, sign up for our newsletter and more on our website: www.TouchMePhilly.com

Questions for us? Info@TouchMePhilly.com

Thanks again, everyone, and we'll see you at the show!

Alyson Rodriguez Orenstein
C.F.O. & Head of P.R. Touch Me Phily Productions

story:
Farm Boys will give men who grew up on farms in rural America the chance to have their voices heard on stage in Central Vermont.  A new stage adaptation of Will Fellows' ground-breaklng book of interviews with farm men ages 24 to 84 will let them tell their stories in their own words.

On Sunday July 20 and Saturday July 26, you can hear these stories in the historic Chandler Music Hall in Randolph, recognized as the region's best music hall by Yankee Magazine in 2013.

This July will mark the fourth season that Vermont Pride Theater's Summer Pride Festival at Chandler brings LGBT voices to a main stage.  The festival offers a unique opportunity for LGBT Vermonters and their families and friends to gather to see thought-provoking theater and participate in post-performance discussion, with the aim of building bridges of understanding among all community members.

Until this season the gay stories we've shared have focused on urban or suburban settings.  Here in Vermont it's past time to share the very different life experiences of rural gay men.

But it costs money to develop new works, $2,785 to be specific.  We need to purchase the rights to the interviews and adapt them for the stage, provide gas money for the Vermont actors (who'll be donating their time) and stipends for the crew, and cover the usual production costs.  Any extra funds raised will subsidize tickets for farm families in the area.

If you can't support the Farm Boys project now, please keep in touch with us on Vermont Pride Theater's Facebook page, and let your friends who contribute to new theater or are advocates of LGBT causes know that we need their help.  You could use the indiegogo share tools to do so.

If you want to make a donation toward Vermont Pride Theater's work to bring Farm Boys to the stage, please use the CONTRIBUTE NOW button below.

Thanks so much for helping us tell this often-overlooked story.

David Zak, Executive Director of Pride Films and Plays, and Sharon Rives, Chandler Pride Producer

story:
Hi, I'm Joy, an independent producer with a project I've believed in since the moment I was mailed the script.
In 2010, I was cast in a reading of a play called Unanswered, We Ride for the Last Frontier Theatre Conference in Valdez, Alaska.
I read the script on the subway on the way to work and cried,
actually laughed through tears.
I had lost my mom ten years before and had been searching for a play to dedicate to her for a decade. I realized in that moment that this was that play.
I felt like she had mailed it to me.
I had never read a story about loss, but more importantly, what it takes to live after loss, that was so raw, honest, funny and inspiring.
It reminded me of why I do theatre in the first place.
It was challenging, it was entertaining, it was healing.
It touched me in a profound way and it felt like it had the power to do that for others. That is why it has been my mission to share it with as many people as possible
ever since.
After meeting the playwright, Jaclyn Villano, in Alaska, we took it to New York, Edinburgh, Boston and Seattle.
Now we have the honor of returning to the conference where it all started.
In 2010, it was a reading and now it will be a featured production.
I couldn't be more proud.
I think my mom would be proud too.

Unanswered, We Ride
by Jaclyn Villano
directed by Elena Araoz
Lighting and set design by Justin Townsend
Sound design by Nathan Leigh
with Joy Barrett, Eric T. Miller and Martha Wollner

What We Need & What You Get

$6500 will help a team from New York take a show over 4000 miles to Valdez, Alaska. Your donations will go toward costumes, set, lighting, sound, actors, director, designers, rehearsal space, and of course, travel.

I can't thank you enough. Touring a show can be expensive, but it is also soooooo worth it!

We hope to give you some fun souvenirs from Alaska in return!

To those of you who have supported us in the past, I couldn't be more grateful. I hope you continue to support the show and if you've seen it, tell your friends!


The Impact

When I first started raising money for the production, it was in my mom's name.
Then I realized the power of people donating in someone's name that they had loved and lost. It suddenly became a project that felt bigger than this production.
It gave our loved ones the chance to live on through the message of the story.
In a small way, we can heal together.
I invite you to do just that. Donate and dedicate. It's pretty powerful.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please help us get the word out by sharing this link or liking our Facebook page https://www.facebook.com/UnansweredWeRide

I realized in that moment that this was that play. I felt like she had mailed it to me. I had never read a story about loss, but more importantly, what it takes to live after loss, that was so raw, honest, funny and inspiring.It reminded me of why I do theatre in the first place. It was challenging, it was entertaining, it was healing.It touched me in a profound way and it felt like it had the power to do that for others. That is why it has been my mission to share it with as many people as possibleever since.After meeting the playwright, Jaclyn Villano, in Alaska, we took it to New York, Edinburgh, Boston and Seattle. Now we have the honor of returning to the conference where it all started.In 2010, it was a reading and now it will be a featured production.I couldn't be more proud. I think my mom would be proud too.Unanswered, We Rideby Jaclyn Villanodirected by Elena AraozLighting and set design by Justin TownsendSound design by Nathan Leighwith Joy Barrett, Eric T. Miller and Martha WollnerWhat We Need & What You Get$6500 will help a team from New York take a show over 4000 miles to Valdez, Alaska. Your donations will go toward costumes, set, lighting, sound, actors, director, designers, rehearsal space, and of course, travel. I can't thank you enough. Touring a show can be expensive, but it is also soooooo worth it!We hope to give you some fun souvenirs from Alaska in return! To those of you who have supported us in the past, I couldn't be more grateful. I hope you continue to support the show and if you've seen it, tell your friends! The ImpactWhen I first started raising money for the production, it was in my 
mom's name. Then I realized the power of people donating in someone's 
name that they had loved and lost. It suddenly became a project that 
felt bigger than this production.It gave our loved ones the chance to live on through the message of the story.In a 
small way, we can heal together.I invite you to do just that. Donate and dedicate. It's pretty powerful. Other Ways You Can HelpPlease help us get the word out by sharing this link or liking our Facebook page https://www.facebook.com/UnansweredWeRide

story:
How did this come about?

Way back in 2009, we set a goal for our 5th season: Faust. We didn't know yet how, but we knew the story. We knew the idea. 

Now, five years later, we are watching this idea slowly evolve into a beautiful new take on a very old story: One very smart man decides to sell his soul to the devil in search of happiness here on earth.   

This past fall, we began to devise our own version of Faust with August Schulenburg leading as our playwright and Marielle Duke as our director. We've assembled an incredibly talented team of actors who have been devising with us over the past year: Matthew Trumbull, Nat Cassidy, Alex Engquist, Rachael Hip Flores, Emily Hartford, Gabby Sherba, Matilde Keizer and Collin McConnell. 

Why We Need Your Help: 

After many months of devising, we are now preparing for a full production this August. 

Adaptive Arts has always provided all of our arts programming free to all audiences in order to encourage non-traditional audience members to attend our shows.  

In conjunction with our productions, we offer free professional development workshops for special education programs here in NY encouraging them to bring the arts into their classrooms as well as free workshops for theater artists on how to create accessible performance spaces and plays for audiences with Autism and Sensory Processing Disorders.  

We want to create accessible theater for all audiences and encourage others do the same! 

However, theater isn't free to produce! Which is why we need your help! 

Plus! Because we are fiscally sponsored through Fractured Atlas, donations made are tax-deductible! 

What your help provides: 

You can help as Adaptive produces it's most ambitious show yet! 

These artists have been working for the past year the devise a new version of Faust that speaks to the struggle to find happiness, the struggle to be good and do good in this world.  

As we move from devising, to rehearsing, to performances, we are watching as one year of work and five years of planning comes to life!  

With your help we can keep developing new projects with artists who deeply believe in creating theater ALL audiences! 


Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to making a donation, you can also help us by spreading the word about our  upcoming production of Faust!   

Share our indiegogo link, find us on facebook, come see the show in August!

story:
Ballet Confessions Project

A live dance, music and art installation about the physical and psychological effects of the ballet world
RSVP:  May 8 & 15th 2014 at 7:00 PM, Judson Memorial Church, New York
Project Updates:  http://balletconfessionsproject.tumblr.com

After being a professional ballet dancer and recently interviewing other dancers, I knew our story needed to be told. In the last two years, I've been developing the choreography, sound design, and an art installation as an artistic expression of their 'confessions.' These dancers who dedicated their lives to the craft of ballet had very different experiences than those depicted in popular media and culture. Ballet Confessions challenges the stereotypes and is an honest portrayal of the professional ballet world. 

My Artistic Intentions

Broadly, this piece is for anyone who's ever felt in love, isolated, betrayed, and in fear of imperfection. Beyond the two live performances in May, I will be sharing a video of the final piece with my friends who do not live in New York. My dream is to expand this solo performance into a full-length production with 30 dancers next year when attending London's Trinity Laban Conservatoire for my M.A. in Choreography. 

Preview Performance: Act 3: Destruction

Ballet Confessions will show the four transformative phases a dancer goes through as a professional ballet dancer: Discovery, Euphoria, Destruction and Renewal. The following video is "Part 3: Destruction" that I performed at The Oxford Artspace and Judson Memorial Church in New York City last summer.  

I need YOU to make this possible!

Good News! Through sponsorships, grants, residences and in-kind donations I have already raised $36,000, 80% of my budget goal! I also have an anonymous matching donor (up to $1,200). Your generous contribution will help me reach my goal to make this performance happen! The remaining budget will go towards paying my amazing collaborators, materials, space rental, promotions and the reception after the performances.

All of the donors will be listed on the Ballet Confessions blog and in the program. If you donate $100, you can take a dance/personal fitness class with me and $500 or higher will get you three workouts. 

If donating isn't possible, please consider sharing my Facebook page and blog as well as helping on the day of the performance!

Thank you SO much for your support! I definitely couldn't have come this far without your encouragement for my career transition from a classical dancer to choreographer. 

See you at the show!

~Mary Ellen, *Mellen*

mebeaudreau@gmail.com


Videos: David Fishel, Photos: Lydia Bittner-Baird, Costume: Jenny Lai

story:
Wild Heart Dance is a contemporary dance company created by Kat Gurley and is based in the front range of Colorado.  The ensemble includes Hallie Bauernschmidt, Mimi Ferrie, Amanda Leise, Tara Rynders and Mollie Wolf. 

Wild Heart uses dance and physical transformation as the sole vehicle for performance.  Their varied experiences and backgrounds are rooted in a passion for and love of dance.  For the intangible beauty and the unspoken truths, they remain true to the source: that the body contains the answers, sensations and the ability to set the mind free.  This ensemble was created in November 2012 and is in its second season of performing.

Wild Heart Dance is currently working on its next performance, which is to be premiered in August 2014, and on its new video project, which was filmed in April 2014.  The new performance, titled "My Mother's Demon and My Father's Burden," delves into the recognition of one's demons and the larger shadows they cast.  Through this recognition and embodiment, the shadows are given the opportunity to come home or in a broader sense laid to rest

Funding a professional show is costly for a small dance company: costumes, lighting design, advertising, promotional video, space rental, etc.  We are asking $3,600 to cover the bare essentials to enable the work to happen. 

We are grateful for any contribution you are willing to give.  If you are unable to send money or attend the show, send your good intentions our way!  We would love for you to be a part of Wild Heart in any way you can.

Wild Heart Performs on August 29th and 30th at 7:30 p.m. at The Dairy Center for the Arts in the Performance Space, 2590 Walnut Street Boulder, CO 80302.

Tickets: 

Buy Tickets Here!

story:
What Is MUNCHED?

After 25 years, Marybeth Paxton has just been released from prison. A disturbing, widely publicized video helped convict her, both in the courthouse and the court of public opinion. But she defiantly maintains her innocence. Her daughter, Katie, now a wise-cracking, Star Trek-loving underachiever, unearths a box of letters which her mother wrote her during the trial. In one, Marybeth pleads, “If you tell them about Flip Wilson, we’ll be together again soon. I promise!” Thus the mystery of “Flip Wilson!?” begins. Katie seeks the gory details--transcripts, interviews, videos--of her famous “sickness," which Marybeth was accused of inducing. The final, terrifying step for Katie is through Marybeth’s front door.

MSBP (Munchausen Syndrome by Proxy) is a psychological disorder in which a caregiver deceives a doctor into treating her ward for an illness that she herself induced (think poisoning, smothering, feces in an open wound...) in an effort to receive the attention, affection, and status of being a hero. 


Production Information

MUNCHED was written by Kim Porter and was last produced in Los Angeles by Buzzworks Theater company where it was nominated for the LA Drama Critics Circle award and the LA Weekly award.

Sugar Valley Theatricals is presenting the east coast premier of MUNCHED for 9 performances at  Manhattan Theatre Source  as part of the Playground Development Series. Performance are November 6-22; Sundays at 3:00, Mondays and Tuesdays at 7:30
Tickets: Sugar Valley Theatricals

  

The production is directed by Petronia Paley and stars Patricia R. Floyd, Althea Alexis, Tanya Everett and Jonathan William.

The set designer is Harlan Penn, the costumes are designed by Ali Turns, lights by James Carter and sound by Norman Anthony Small, Jr.



What We Need 

MUNCHED is one of the most exciting and ambitious works that Sugar Valley Theatricals has developed. Our past productions have include the award winning WHORE WORKS by Juan Michael Porter II, Steve Willis' PASSING CEREMONIES and PEARL CLEAGE'S WOMEN adapted by Lorna Littleway. We need to raise $2000 over the next 30 days to help cover our production costs, including rehearsal space and promotional materials. Your  contributions, no matter how large or small, are vital to our work. Whether you've been with us from the very beginning or even if you've  just now become familiar with Sugar Valley Theatricals, we'd be very grateful for your help in making MUNCHED happen. Please make your donation today. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Come see MUNCHED and bring your friends! Group tickets available for 10 or more, Only $16.50! You can't beat it! Visit our website at SVTheatricals.com

story:
A World Premiere Workshop/Development Season

Facing East is a new musical based on the stirring play by Carol Lynn Pearson that tells the story of an upstanding Mormon couple coming to terms with the suicide of their gay son. When they unexpectedly meet their son's lover, they must face a reality that until then has been ignored, and reconcile their feelings and beliefs.

Facing East: The Musical features a score by David Rigano (The Rigano Songbook), with book and lyrics by Mark Eugene Garcia (The Holy Cows Of Credence, South Dakota) and direction by Andrew Hobgood (Artistic Director of The New Colony in Chicago).


Facing East will receive a World Premiere Workshop/Development season in Chicago, IL, USA during August, 2011


The Impact

Facing East: The Musical brings to light themes of tolerance, acceptance, equality and understanding whilst dealing with the very serious issue of LGBT suicides, which has become somewhat of an epidemic over the last few years. Recently a string of suicides in young adults in the US due to bullying was brought to the attention of the public through the media, which has in turn seen a great outpouring of public support.


In response to this, and the subject matter of the show, all productions of Facing East: The Musical; including this workshop, intend to support The Trevor Project by sharing a portion of our profits with the organisation. The Trevor Project is the USA's leading national organisation providing crisis and suicide prevention services to lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and questioning youth. To find out more about The Trevor Project please visit their website.


What We Need & What You Get

Through this campaign we're raising additional funds to help cover transport and housing costs in Chicago over Summer for some of the artists during the workshop season of Facing East as well as venue rental for the season. Funds raised will also go towards the show's marketing budget, to expand our reach to potential audience members whose feedback and support are crucial to this stage of the show's development.


Ideally we need to raise $10,000USD to assist in covering these costs and really get this workshop/development season up and running, however if we don't reach this target, any amount of money that is raised will be added to our existing production budget and attributed to various production costs. The more money we raise up front to cover costs on the productions, means there will be more profits available at the end of the season to share with The Trevor Project.


We've set up a great perks system that offers some fantastic rewards for helping us get this World Premiere Workshop/Development season off the ground so be sure to have a look at them before making your donation to see what rewards you'll qualify for.


Other Ways You Can Help

Who wants a FREE TRIP TO CHICAGO?


Share our indiegogo campaign for FACING EAST with friends, family, or even the crazy cat lady next door!


If you can raise $1200.00 for FACING EAST: The Musical by getting people you know to donate, we’ll get you a flight into Chicago and one night stay in a hotel to attend the workshop! And we’ll even credit you as an associate producer! A perk normally reserved for $1,000 donators. You don’t even have to donate yourself, if you can raise that money, you’re coming to CHICAGO to be a part of FACING EAST taking its first big step forward!


So how does this work?


First share this campaign with people you know using the share tools, or however you like to share information. Make sure that when your friends/family/cat ladies donate that they put your name in the comments section so we can trace it back to you. (eg: John Smith said I should donate to Facing East!) Your friends donations are also still eligible for any of the equivalent perks they’re donation fulfils- so everyone’s a winner! At the end of the campaign, we’ll tally up all the donations and if you’ve managed to raise a total of $1200+ you’ve earned yourself a free flight and accom!


Get connected by becoming a fan of Facing East on Facebook and following us on Twitter to find out all the latest news about the show. We also have a website and a blog, so be sure to check those out as well.


Don't forget to watch the video of Kevin Duda (from the Xanadu National Tour) singing "Still Standing" from Facing East: The Musical on our gallery page, and feel free to share this video with your friends as well.


And if you happen to be in Chicago come and see the show, because we'll be looking for a fantastic supportive audience come August!


Also please visit and support www.thetrevorproject.org

story:
Summary

Life isn't about waiting for the storm to pass. It’s about learning to dance in the rain. This dance began as a birthday celebration to get- my wonderful VP to  returning to work with my company and help turn all problems (Like Target claiming copyright to my work) to opportunities.
 
Please see a few of the wonderful rewards we are offering to make another trademark of mine, LEGAL LEMONADE®. I wish I could reach a million of you to donate even a dollar each and yes...we Davids CAN fight Goliath. Although I would rather shower them and you with KISSES. Here's a few:
 
 
  "Your dancing leaves much to be desired -- YOU!"

 

 I have 35 years of experience of design, manufacturing social expression cards and gifts, product development for licensing, and designed displays that earn the most per square foot. My art and quotations are like loss leaders for the rest of the items that are displayed - consistently best sellers.
 
 I can help Target get good vendors here in the US and the best in China when we verify no one is exploited. This is a great opportunity. We have to get Target's attention. Ironically Target sponsors the Oprah show, the very essence of learning to dance in the rain.
 
Remember Eckart Tolle? The spiritual teacher whose book Oprah calls the most important she's ever read that launched her podcast? His literary agent is Bill Gladstone, who is my agent to. So is the message of my work which Target even put on the wall between Footsteps and the Serenity Prayer.
 
As Bill Gladstone said "Vivian is on target. Too bad Target is missing the mark. Get it together Target and do the right thing.” 

"I would have gotten you a better present ..  If there was   more money in the kitty."

You can help too. Show with a donation of any amount that you like my work, and want it in Target and other stores so we can spread the love far and wide.

My fans loyalty throughout the years - your comments, healing, and laughter are my greatest reward. But I think we need to show this to Target, and I would love nothing better than to share ALL of the rewards with you. Every donation shows another person who wants to make it right. And I'd like to show that creative people have the ability to create a better world.

 

 "Happy Birthday - You're a real gift in my life."

 Why $2420? It's the magic of   numerology for the numbers in  Linda's birthday, plus the service expense. We really really really want to see what you like and have your support to get TARGET to add many zeroes to these numbers so we can bring you tons of Kisses. Thanks for this opportunity!! Happy Birthday, Linda.

 

If you dont' have money, but you have time, we'll help you make money by sharing our campaign with your freinds.

Just let us know. A portion of all I do is to help others attend my workshops and benefit. Prosperity is free.

story_txt:
Summary
Life isn't about waiting for the storm to pass. It’s about learning to dance in the rain. This dance began as a birthday celebration to get- my wonderful VP to  returning to work with my company and help turn all problems (Like Target claiming copyright to my work) to opportunities.
 
Please see a few of the wonderful rewards we are offering to make another trademark of mine, LEGAL LEMONADE®. I wish I could reach a million of you to donate even a dollar each and yes...we Davids CAN fight Goliath. Although I would rather shower them and you with KISSES. Here's a few:
 

 

  "Your dancing leaves much to be desired -- YOU!"

 

 I have 35 years of experience of design, manufacturing social expression cards and gifts, product development for licensing, and designed displays that earn the most per square foot. My art and quotations are like loss leaders for the rest of the items that are displayed - consistently best sellers.
 
 I can help Target get good vendors here in the US and the best in China when we verify no one is exploited. This is a great opportunity. We have to get Target's attention. Ironically Target sponsors the Oprah show, the very essence of learning to dance in the rain.
 
Remember Eckart Tolle? The spiritual teacher whose book Oprah calls the most important she's ever read that launched her podcast? His literary agent is Bill Gladstone, who is my agent to. So is the message of my work which Target even put on the wall between Footsteps and the Serenity Prayer.
 
As Bill Gladstone said "Vivian is on target. Too bad Target is missing the mark. Get it together Target and do the right thing.” 
"I would have gotten you a better present ..  If there was   more money in the kitty."
You can help too. Show with a donation of any amount that you like my work, and want it in Target and other stores so we can spread the love far and wide.
My fans loyalty throughout the years - your comments, healing, and laughter are my greatest reward. But I think we need to show this to Target, and I would love nothing better than to share ALL of the rewards with you. Every donation shows another person who wants to make it right. And I'd like to show that creative people have the ability to create a better world.

  
 "Happy Birthday - You're a real gift in my life."
 Why $2420? It's the magic of   numerology for the numbers in  Linda's birthday, plus the service expense. We really really really want to see what you like and have your support to get TARGET to add many zeroes to these numbers so we can bring you tons of Kisses. Thanks for this opportunity!! Happy Birthday, Linda.
 
If you dont' have money, but you have time, we'll help you make money by sharing our campaign with your freinds.
Just let us know. A portion of all I do is to help others attend my workshops and benefit. Prosperity is free.

story:
Would you buy a ticket to a performance with no guarantee that it would happen if it was for a good cause?

Enrico Labayen, choreographer based in San Francisco, CA has been diagnosed with Hepatitis C, a serious liver disease. His doctor told him that there is a cure for him but that he needs $84000 for it.

By buying a ticket to "The Performance That Might Never Live" you are donating your money for Enrico's treatment who will direct the show himself, in case he fully recovers.

story:
Miss Marilyn Chen

I am a local Aerialist, Aerial Fitness Instructor, and Performer in Atlanta, Georgia.  I sent in an application to Necca, The New England center for Circus Arts and was accepted!  I will be there for three weeks, training daily in aerial fabrics. I will also be taking their teacher training program, in hopes to further my understanding and experience in teaching aerial arts.

This is a wonderful opportunity and I feel very LUCKY to have been chosen.  I currently teach at Sky Gym, and Perform with Liquid Sky Productions.  I hope to come back with inspired, with new and exciting vocabulary, and a better understanding of teaching.

 

What I Need to Get there

 

  • Plane Ticket ~500
  • Lodging  ~1000
  • Car to get there  ~600
  • Fooooodddd.. lots of foods.
In exchange for helping me, you'll get some tokens of my appreciation, my eternal gratitude , and the biggest smile ever.

The Impact

Necca's boot camp is going to be 7 days a week training in aerial arts, every day , all day.  I hope to come back with a MUCH better understanding of professional training techniques and creative flow.  I hope to SHARE my excitement, inspiration, and knowledge with my peers and students when I return!  This is an amazing opportunity and can help my career in performance. Its all things positive, physically, mentally, and emotionally.

I have had a very hard year but this trip seems to be the light at the end of a very long tunnel. LOL

Other Ways You Can Help

  Get the werrd out, and  Positive thoughts all around.

story:
We've been invited to the Winnipeg Fringe Festival to do our awesome balloon show! But helium costs A LOT OF MONEY... and we cannot ride our bikes to Winnipeg. Especially with the giant balloon. 


The Breakdown

Winnipeg Fringe is willing to give us some assistance, but we still need a lot more:

cost of helium: $3500

cost of travel: $1400

Remember, every donation helps - if we don't raise the money, we won't get to bring our show for all the lovely people to see!

We're offering AMAZING perks for sponsorship/donations including advertising on our amazing balloon and aerial circus lessons.


No Money?

That's okay! Maybe you know some people? We would love for you to pass this on!

story:
Who We Are and Why We're Here

Hello! We are Renegade Theatre Troupe and we are proud to be producing "Bed" at Planet Connections Theatre Festivity in June 2012 alongisde "The Closet," another lovely one act!

We believe in producing fresh, exciting theatre featuring the work and young and up-and-coming theatre artists. Through this mission statement, we believe that we can fund the best, most innovative theatre in New York.

Bed, as a specific project, is our inaugural production. Written by and featuring Dana Sumner-Pritchard and directed by Nicholas Martin, two recent graduates of Drew University, Bed explores universal themes of love, loss, and trying to maintain normalcy in the most uncertain times of life. 

We are young. We are ambitious. We are exciting. We are not rich. Every member of this production team is a current college student or recent graduate. By supporting us, you are supporting a new generation of theatre makers.

When/Where/Who

The dates for "Bed" are: 

Saturday 6/2/12 – 8:00pm = Performance #1
Monday 6/4/12 – 9:30pm = Performance #2
Thursday 6/7/12 – 6:00pm = Performance #3
Wednesday 6/13/12 – 4:00pm = Performance #4
Tuesday 6/19/12 – 6:30pm = Performance #5
Saturday 6/23/12 – 11:00am = Performance #6

Tickets are $18 General Admission. 

Buy your tickets here: https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/pr/911590

All performances are at 45 Bleecker Street, Downstairs Theatre.

 

The Cast and Crew of "Bed" is:

Written by Dana Sumner-Pritchard

Directed by Nick Martin

Stage Managed by Courtney Cooke

Sound Design and Media Relations by Ariel Gitlin

Costume Designed by Anastasia Rutkowski 

Set Designed by Christina Lockerby

Cast:
Man: Matt Brown
Woman: Dana Sumner-Pritchard

 

What We Need

Putting on a show in a festival is expensive!

Here is our dream budget breakdown:

Application fees: $100

Transportation Reimbursements: $100

Space Rentals: $200

Set/Lights: $100

Props/Costumes: $200

Postcard and Poster Printing: $150

Merchandise: $200

Stipends for our AMAZING Team Members: $500

 

Total Dream Budget: $1550

Of course, if we don't make our fundraising goal, stipends are first to go (this team is so incredible, they're working for free!) and merchandise. All diseign budgets would also be cut down significantly.

ALL DONORS GET LOVELY THANK YOUS!

The Impact

This project means a great deal to all of us. This team is a team we trust. They are all exceptional artists. Some of us are greener than others. All of us are young and building our resumes. A project like this helps us. When you support "Bed," you are supporting not only a great play, but a great group of young artists who cannot afford to produce their art (without working three jobs) otherwise. Your help is not only greatly appreciated, but paramount to our development.

Additionally, we are doing this for a good cause. All productions in PCTF support a charity. "Bed," along with it's fellow one-act "The Closet," is supporting Women In Need. We are collecting donations at the door for this incredible charity, so supporting "Bed" means making a real impact in the world! 

 

To learn more about Women in Need, follow this link: http://www.women-in-need.org/

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please come! 

Check out our Festival Website: http://planetconnections.org/bed-and-the-closet/

RSVP on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/events/220129108101122/

Follow us on Twitter: @BedNYC

story:
THE GROUP LAB is an artistic home incubating creative work (theatre and then some). We hope to create, work and share our imaginings in constant, critical conversation with the world we live in.
 
The Party:
Vichet Chum
Kyle Schaefer
Laura Jo Schuster
Paul Kite
Marianne Miller
Jenna Panther
Emily Kitchens
Jessica Watkins
Matt Ellis Murphy
 
We are mounting our first staged reading of Group Lab member, Laura Jo Schuster's play "The Theory of Everything" directed by Kyle Schaefer.  It will take place on Saturday, April 7, 2012 at 6:30 pm at Space on White at 81 White Street off of Canal Street.
 
We ask for your help to fund the Group Lab's inaugural project.  All expenses will go directly to performance space rental, equity member fees, and general logistical costs.  We, humbly and with much gratitude, hope to raise at the very least $500.  

There will certainly be greater fundraising campaigns in the future, but for now any additional funds will be used towards our future creative endeavors.  Please consider donating any amount!  But foremost, check us out @ www.facebook.com/TheGroupLab!
 
Thank you so much for supporting young artists.  Cheers!
 
Vichet Chum
Producer, "The Theory of Everything"
