story:
Short Summary

For five years, RoadKill Productions produced original works at the Psychic Visions Theatre, which has since been bulldozed by corporate greed. 

This show premiered at that space, and was the last show we produced there, in December 2011.

We're bringing it back this Christmas to the Eclectic Theatre in North Hollywood, but we need help. The Eclectic Theatre is an amazing company that promotes the works of artists, especially those trying to produce original works. People like us! However, we do need to come up with a little money up front to secure our time slot. 

You can help us guarantee that we're ready to put down a deposit, and open our show on schedule!

What We Need & What You Get

We need to put down a deposit at the theatre at least two weeks before opening. That's exactly where this money will go. 

It only takes a small contribution to guarantee yourself a seat to this funny holiday show. Another small contribution and you can bring a friend!

With other funky & unique perks, you can contribute to Los Angeles theatre AND get yourself a tasty holiday gift at the same time!

We are doing other fundraising events as well, so even if this campaign doesn't raise the full amount, it will still help us get closer to our goal. 

The Impact

We are excited to work with a company like the Eclectic Company Theatre because they are so in line with our vision - creating fresh, new original works for the Los Angeles arts community. 

It is inherently challenging for playwrights to see their work produced on a stage. The cost of renting a theatre alone is more than most production companies can even dream of. We are in a situation with a lot of potential, and really only need a small amount of money to see this happen.

Your contribution will not only benefit the art and the artists, it could even save the holiday season!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you're broke and can't afford to contribute - and trust us, we know exactly how that feels - it would take you only a moment to share this campaign on Facebook, Tweet it, e-mail it to your rich friends or just tell people about the show.

story:
Why Donate to STAGEright?

STAGEright was founded in 2009 by a group of friends seeking to work in a professional, intimate, and creative environment.  Since the beginning, STAGEright has focused on elevating the unique stories being told within each show produced and the dynamic character relationships found within these stirring stories.  Continually, STAGEright endeavors to take risks, provide opportunity, incite passion, and to produce good theatre.  Floyd Collins fits all of these criteria.

Floyd Collins was a legendary spelunker and true Kentucky county boy. In 1925, Floyd was seeking fame and fortune within an unexplored cavern when a rock wedged his foot against the cave wall and trapped the lone caver.  In this beautifully written musical we explore the ideas of freedom and entrapment, past and present, faith and despair, reality and dream, and finally life and death, all through the lens of a helpless family and a desperate entombed soul.

Your donation enables STAGEright to continue providing opportunities to local actors, musicians, designers, and directors.  Your donation helps fund Floyd Collins and future projects that build and impassion the Seattle arts community.   Your donation to STAGEright ensures the continuation of intimate, story-driven theatre.  

Budget Needs and Perks, oh my!:

While we are only requesting $5,500 for this campaign, it does not cover our total budget for Floyd Collins, but it helps balance out our anticipated return from ticket sales and on-site donations during the run of the show.

Production Budget for Floyd:

  • $2,021 - Rights for Floyd Collins
  • $4,700 - Performance and Reherasal Venues
  • $850 - Actors and Musicians
  • $200 - Director and Designers
  • $400 - Technical Director
  • $1,500 - Marketing and Publicity
  • $1,700 - Costumes, Lighting, Set, and Dramaturg materials

Total: $11,371 - Total production cost to mount Floyd Collins

Awesome Perks:

  • Thanks on-line (unless you don't want recognition - just let us know!)
  • Thanks in the program (again, unless you don't want recognition)
  • STAGEright decal - New for this Indiegogo Campaign!  Patch us to anything you want!  Your laptop, your Nalgene, or your new...
  • STAGEright tote bag - a very bright orange and with a large carrying capacity!  Everyone that already has one wants another.  You should get one, too!
  • Floyd Collins signed show poster - Have a piece of this unique Seattle Premiere!
  • Pair of tickets to any STAGEright show in 2014 - enough said.
  • 2014 Season Membership - You get to see all of STAGEright's 2014 shows, and you get a half-off discount to bring a friend with you to each performance! 

In the event that we don't reach our entire $5,500 goal, the money raised will go to pay the people first.  The actors, designers, musicians, and crew are the life of live theatre.  We need to appreciate and thank them first! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Theatre thrives when people care!  If you cannot contribute financially to this campaign or to STAGEright, we always appreciate volunteer help and donations in kind.  If you'd like to donate your time, your old furniture or clothes, a gift certificate to your business or employment, or anything else you think would be helpful to a fringe, non-profit theatre, let John know at john@seattlestageright.org.  We appreciate you and we'll find a way to thank you in kind!

Want to make our campaign, and our company, a success!  Get out the message!  Don't forget to share this campaign and spread the word!  

Finally, and as always, Thanks!  You make this possible!

story:
THE BOOK OF ANDY follows Andy after he responds “...I don’t know” to a marriage proposal from his long time boyfriend. When he can’t figure out why he couldn’t say yes, Andy decides to visit his ex-boyfriends in an attempt to understand what “went wrong” there, only to find they are thriving without him, leading him to take desperate measures: he tells them he’s dying. A comedy written by CSUB and NYU alum, Michael J. Mejia, the play explores the world of the modern dating through the eyes of a gay man who is suddenly hit with the intensity and surprise of marriage. 
With the recent reintroduction of marriage equality in California, and throughout the Unites States, THE BOOK OF ANDY comes to us at a perfect time when the gay community finds itself in a state of transition, exercising the overdue right to say “I do.” Mejia has written a funny, touching, and honest play that will have people laughing in their seats, as well as pioneer a new chapter of Gay American Theatre that reflects who “we” are today and who “we” will be tomorrow.

When you donate, you will be credited as 'Producer.' The show currently has a $0 budget. Any and all money raised will go directly to purchasing building materials for the set, costumes, set pieces, props, lighting, properties. Every dollar you contribute will be seen on stage. The show is looking to be entered/accepted in either LA or NYC Fringe. You're producing credit will follow the production. 

The Producing Theatre Company, The Empty Space, is a non-profit community theatre. They do not charge admission to there shows. Every show is free! All they ask is for a suggested donation to help keep the lights on and the doors open so they can continue to give the city of Bakersfield an opportunity to see live theatre. 

The Playwright, Michael J. Mejia, has had over a dozen productions in Bakersfield. This will be his second full length play to receive a World Premier in Bakersfield. After receiving his BA in English and BA in Theatre from Cal State Bakersfield, he attended NYU Tisch School of the Arts, Asia, in Singapore, where he received his MFA in Dramatic Writing with a concentration in Playwriting. His plays usually explore themes on the Mexican/American experience, the Gay experience, and Modern Christianity. 

Remember, every dollar helps. Even you can't help financially, spreading the word is just as appreciated. Theatre is a communal experience and it takes a community to produce theatre. The show will be FREE ADMISSION and the production team for The Book of Andy would love to see you there! 

The production runs January 10th, 11th, 17th, and 18th, 2014.
story_txt:
THE BOOK OF ANDY follows Andy after he responds “...I don’t know” to a marriage proposal from his long time boyfriend. When he can’t figure out why he couldn’t say yes, Andy decides to visit his ex-boyfriends in an attempt to understand what “went wrong” there, only to find they are thriving without him, leading him to take desperate measures: he tells them he’s dying. A comedy written by CSUB and NYU alum, Michael J. Mejia, the play explores the world of the modern dating through the eyes of a gay man who is suddenly hit with the intensity and surprise of marriage. With the recent reintroduction of marriage equality in California, and throughout the Unites States, THE BOOK OF ANDY comes to us at a perfect time when the gay community finds itself in a state of transition, exercising the overdue right to say “I do.” Mejia has written a funny, touching, and honest play that will have people laughing in their seats, as well as pioneer a new chapter of Gay American Theatre that reflects who “we” are today and who “we” will be tomorrow.

story:
As theatre artists, we have found a welcoming and warm home here at Bard College, and especially in the student-run theatrical space, The Old Gym. The annual Halloween show was the first piece we were involved in at Bard, and to be producing it now and carrying on this time honored tradition is a true thrill. We have amassed a company of passionate artists, all focused on creating a memorable, meaningful, and fun experience for the Bard community. We are driven and deeply motivated by our desire to produce the highest quality production as possible.

This year, our student directors are devising adaptations of Hansel and Gretel, Snow White, The Little Mermaid, Little Red Riding Hood, Rumpelstiltskin, and Peter Pan and his Shadow. Currently we are raising money to pay for the materials necessary to mount the production.

The money we raise will enable us to buy the following: Curtains (necessary to build the individual rooms which the adaptations will take place in) Costumes. Make-up. Crucial building supplies (nails, tools, paint). Props. All of the money we raise will be spent go towards buying necessary supplies for the show. Without the help of donations, we simply do not have the resources to see this show through.

Any and all donations are extremely appreciated. Please feel free to spread the word about Grimm Haus as well! We will premiere October 27th and 28th in the Old Gym!

story:
The Project

JOHNNY & the DEVIL’S BOX is a folk musical about a brash young square dance fiddler from Georgia who must navigate young love, evade corrupt revenuers and outwit a devilish preacher on his quest to prove himself as the best fiddler that has ever been. But Johnny’s pride may be his downfall, and if he takes his fiddle out of the mountains what music will be left for his town to dance to?  Inspired by myths of fiddlers’ dealing with the Devil, this piece takes a hard look at the association between a virtuoso’s pride and hellish temptation. Told largely through Appalachian inspired myth, music and movement the show is built to stir the audience’s urge to get up and dance.

 

The People

JOHNNY & the DEVIL’S BOX is the dream and passion project of Douglas Waterbury-Tieman, an actor-musician and writer living in New York City who hails from Lexington, Kentucky.  It is his dream to bring a musical to the stage that can bridge the space between the city he calls home and the southern roots he keeps planted in the bluegrass. The rest of the JDB team includes music supervisor Scott Wasserman (Margaritaville, Dear Evan Hansen), director John Hurley, and choreographer Jennifer Jancuska (Hamilton).  

 

The Goal

Our ultimate goal is to secure the funds and artistic support for a premiere production.  This means communicating with people who are trying to envision the world of JOHNNY & the DEVIL’S BOX and all of the potential it holds. Because a live musical is a full sensory experience we are producing a music video as part of a new website that will serve as a digital portal to express the heart and vibrant vision of the JDB team as we communicate with producers and backers.  By supporting the vision of this music video you will be helping to bring this show into reality.

 

The Video

The video will utilize the skill and vision of choreographer Jennifer Jancuska and her company The BringAbout accompanied by Douglas’ original music as performed by Broadway’s premier bluegrass band The Playbillies.  The video will be produced and filmed by the team behind PostModern Jukebox’s award winning one take video of Don’t Stop Believin’.  In order to produce this video we will need to raise at least $5,000.  These funds are needed for:

  • Studio recording fees
  • Space rental
  • Film equipment
  • Director fees
  • Artist stipends

 

The Perks

As thanks for your support we are offering early access to tracks from our recent concert, bluegrass fiddle lessons, free tickets to upcoming events, and your name used in the actual script!

 

The Impact

JOHNNY & the DEVIL’S BOX is a story about the power of music and dance to unite a community.  By supporting this music video you will be helping to celebrate the rich history of Americana folk music and ensure the continuation of the musical theatre art form.

 

The Challenge

We are not so naive as to think that this campaign and video will be easy an easy task.  We are well aware of the challenges faced by all creative projects including lack of funding and fast approaching deadlines.  However, we are a professional and close knit team who are ready to think on our feet and roll with the punches. We have already self produced two concerts at Rockwood Music Hall, multiple table readings and a full staged reading of the script at Belmont University.  Should we come up short or be faced with any other unforeseen challenges we will use our expertise to rise above them.

 

The Song

Even if you are unable to support us financially we can still use your help!  Please share our campaign on social media and by word of mouth. We are not just funding a music video we are launching a project that we hope will fill theaters with song and dance for years to come.  We hope that you will join us and help to sing “That Glorious Song” in whatever way you can!

story:
Short Summary

"Think back to a time which is not very long ago. Last Sunday morning. You wake up. Where are you? What is the weather like? Who do you see? What do you feel? The memory of last Sunday probably comes back very quickly so now we go even further back."

- from MNEMONIC

How reliable are memory and imagination, the most subjective of storytellers, in recapturing the past? Crossing continents and centuries, MNEMONIC's frayed narrative weaves together the discovery of Ötzi the iceman, a woman's search for her absent father and the longing for a love lost. By persistently exploring "how we remember, what we remember, why we remember," MNEMONIC calls us to question not only who we are but where we ultimately come from. 

Red Tape Theatre, now in its 11th Season, is committed to the creation of new and experimental work. Red Tape’s productions invite our audiences to re-imagine their world. Our work serves a vital purpose in our community: to arrest attention and create empathy.

With the Chicago Premiere of MNEMONIC (September 2-October 5, 2014) we'll be re-imagining this devised piece, originally conceived by Complicite.  We want to give this amazing play an equally amazing Chicago run, and we need your help to do it! Besides, look at those prizes.

What We Need & What You Get

We're facing a unique season in our 11th year...the first in a long time where we don't have a place to call home.  With this new situation we face significantly higher production costs.  We are now experiencing expenses such as rehearsal space rental ($1000) and ongoing storage costs for our lighting and set equipment ($150/month).  In addition to these are the expected expenses of producing theatre, such as purchasing producing rights ($1700), paying actor & designer stipends and buying set supplies & materials.  Producing plays on the technically impressive level Red Tape is known for requires funds. 

For all of your amazing generosity, support, and belief in RTT, you'll receive some pretty sweet swag like tickets to MNEMONIC, Segway Tours, Gift Certificates to restaurants in the Loop area so you can enjoy dinner before or after the show, and even an overnight stay at a Loop area hotel so you can make a night of it!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not able to make a monetary donation at this time, consider some of the following ways you can help...

  • Help spread the word to your friends about our Campaign and upcoming performances of MNEMONIC! The best advertising is word-of mouth-help us create buzz by mentioning us on Facebook or Twitter.
  • Volunteer-We can always use a helping hand from hanging posters in your neighborhood to helping with box office or ushering, to helping us load in and build the set. If you'd like to volunteer, feel free to email us at info@redtapetheatre.org.
  • In-Kind Donations-Donations of goods and services are just as valuable as money-if you have anything you think might come in handy feel free to drop us an email at info@redtapetheatre.org.

    Red Tape is a 501c3 not-for-profit and all gifts are tax deductible!

story:
Summary

Boy from small town New Brunswick moves to Ottawa to pursue his dream. Girl from the Anglophone Jewish community of Montreal also moves to Ottawa in search of her destiny. They meet, become best friends and share a common goal.  Who are we?  We are Patrick and Karina (@patrinacrosscan). 

We are going to “knock on the doors” of every professional theatre across Canada and audition for every company that is able to make the time to see us. In addition, we will be creating a web series, and piece of theatre about our journey. 

By showing your support to our campaign, you will be helping us launch our acting careers and inspire others to take risks and put themselves out there!

Expenses
- gas
- car insurance
- accommodations
- tolls and ferries
- headshots and resumes
- CAFF fringe 2015 application fee

5 dollars=what one may spend on a daily coffee
5 dollars for us = one km closer to our goal!
Risks
-some theatres won't be able to see us
-we may get lost
-our car may break down
- we "may get eaten by a bear" (Quote Elaine Wisenthal Milech)

We understand the risks and the challenges we are about to ensure by driving across Canada; however, we are too determined to let bears get in our way!

Other Ways to Help
-Share this link!
-Connect us with a news broadcasting station
-Let us know about theatres we should check out!
-Follow us on Twitter and Facebook

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!!!

story:
Hamlet. In a Haunted House. In Omaha. HUH?.

  • We are producing an adaptation of Hamlet as a ghost possession story--that takes place throughout a haunted house.  We're calling it WALK THE NIGHT.
  • The creative team has been working with a new form of theatre and we'd like to introduce it to the Omaha community. The innovative Blue Barn Theatre is the perfect artistic sponsor.
  • Leading the "madness" are: Spencer Williams (Director/Producer); Wai Yim and Sebastiani Romagnolo (Choreographers); Bill Grennan (Producer); Blue Barn Theatre (Artistic Sponsor).
  • WE NEED YOU! Your contribution will help bring Omaha to the forefront of this new theatrical experience.

HERE'S WHAT WE NEED:

We are looking for $7,500 to help make this something of quality. WALK THE NIGHT  is opening mid-October, regardless.  But there are important things that having this money will do.
Money will help:
  • Compensate our ensemble members for the extensive time they're devoting (something very important to us, for the Omaha theatre community).
  • Cover development of lights and unique sound systems in our historic 4-story Victorian (haunted) house, in a way that won't harm the beautiful period architecture and fixtures. 
The support we receive from you will determine how much we can do! That's why YOU play an important role in this production!

HERE'S WHAT YOU'LL GET:

Want to feel like royalty? We have tons of KINGLY perks listed on the right.

Anything you can give, we will take! As Hamlet said, "Beggar that I am, I am even poor in thanks; but I thank you, and sure, dear friends, my thanks are too dear a halfpenny."

In case you're still nervous...

You've worked hard for your money and why should you give some to us?
  • Spencer has a degree with Honors in Direction from UC Irvine where he studied under Keith Fowler and Bill Rauch (artistic director of Oregon Shakespeare Festival). He has independently directed, produced and worked in feature films, TV, music videos (with the band Milo Greene for Warner Records)--and has already successfully mounted an immersive production in Northern California.
  • Sebastiani has a degree in Drama from NYU's Tisch School of the Arts, has trained at The Royal Academy of Dramatic Arts in London and with Mary Overlie. He's performed in New York (Punchdrunk's Sleep No More) and regionally.
  • Wai works with numberous regional theaters including The Goodman Theatre, The Lookingglass Theatre Company, The McCarter Theatre and The Old Globe. He is a member of Actors' Equity Association and was last seen in Mary Zimmerman's The White Snake. He also serves as the resident choreographer for aetherplough production.
  • Bill is a professional actor, writer, and creative consultant. As a proud member of Actors' Equity Association, he has performed across the country on stage, screen and voice over. His writing has been published by The Reader, KVNO Public Radio, and NET. 
  • Blue Barn Theatre exists to enhance the cultural life of Omaha, Nebraska by producing executed, boundary breaking plays that ignite a passion for the art form. Blue Barn is dedicated to theatre's most important tradition: to provoke thought, emotion, action, and change.

Technical Difficulties 

This is a complicated production to mount.  To create the play as we see it, we need seamless effects, lighting and sound in a 4-story Victorian house. Why? Because the audience is moving! There are NO seats! The house IS the stage! WHAAAA?

  • Fortunately, we've done this before.
  • Your donation IS the key to help us solve these challenges!

If there's something rotten in the state of your bank account & you can't contribute now, you can still help!

  • Come to the show!  
  • Reach out to volunteer!
  • SHARE this campaign with all your friends!

Fortunately, we've done this before.
Your donation IS the key to help us solve these challenges! 
  If there's something rotten in the state of your bank account & you can't contribute now, you can still help! 
Come to the show!  
Reach out to volunteer! SHARE this campaign with all your friends!

story:
Short Summary

When Monty Python announced their surprise reunion show in late 2013, I sadly and excitedly bought tickets on line without much hope that I'd actually get to London. As I begin to spread my excitement, my dear friend Trent Zelazny, and others, instilled in me the courage to be sure I get there somehow including the great suggestion of using crowdfunding. I am part way there but need your help to be able to be away from my place of works and be in pricey lovely London for the week, as I also have tickets on the 15th of July.  We are launching this campaign, pulling from our creative brilliance, to make this more than just please help me take a trip. I will need to eat and sleep outside of the subway or jail.

I intend to leave the 14th thru the 21st so your contributions will make my week all the better.

As you likely know, I have been a HUGE fan/worshipper/devotee of Monty Python since before I can remember. I grew up watching their movies and shows and with their LPS and never really cut back as I age.  When we began our monthly variety show the Julesworks Follies almost 2.5 years ago, it was with both excitement and trepidation (of violating sacred material), that we began to recreate (rip off?) Monty Python sketches and scenes from all their oeuvre. The first two times were such an amazing thrill that we became hooked and the Julesworks Not Monty Python perform each month as a staple of our show.

What We Need & What You Get

The perks will be a combination of creations from great writers and artists such as Trent Zelazny, George RR Martin, Joe Lansdale, Wil S. Hylton, Philip Meyer, Aaron Becker, Martin Reaves and more as well as from Stephen Jules Rubin (a brand new published novella! co-written with PQ Ribber) and Julesworks. I am also whopping up ideas for new material to create during the trip including a diary, in the style of the great Python Diarist Michael Palin with a Jules flare including drawings and pictures.

We have many shows footage in the archive of an array of the sketches we have done and plan to shoot one in a more controlled studio like environment to aim for a higher quality. 

The Impact

The impact on my life will be hard to quantify...we all have live acts and shows that are the tops in our dream concerts to attend and very often we don't get to see those either because the show never happens or because the means to be there don't materialize...in this case the show is happening (unless another Python dies before mid July) and thanks to your help I will be there...so the impact on your life will be the joy in knowing you helped me be there, and in getting some of the nifty perks we are accruing.

Also, this is tied directly into Julesworks, our Santa Fe based film and theatre production company which has existed in some form since the late 90s with our most consistent project being the Julesworks Follies, Santa Fe's Live Monthly Variety Show in the Vaudeville vein.  Seeing my creative (and life heroes - esp Mr. nice guy Michael Palin), muses and heroes perform will surely add fuel to our fire as performers who mix taking ideas and more from the greats with original sketch material. Julesworks will continue to stage our monthly show while hoping to return to making film, at least short material, and perhaps spreading into our dream of doing some shows on the radio.

In short, getting Jules to London for the Python Live Show, especially in a comfortable and safe fashion, will enrich his life and clearly the other great members of Julesworks and the Santa Fe community, and we hope our outreach will continue to grow. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Every dollar will seriously help because Jules loves fish and chips and tea. If you don't have a dollar, even sharing the campaign will be greatly appreciated and surely help to spread the word and surpass our fundraising goal. 

And that's all there is to it.
story_txt: Short Summary When Monty Python announced their surprise reunion show in late 2013, I sadly and excitedly bought tickets on line without much hope that I'd actually get to London. As I begin to spread my excitement, my dear friend Trent Zelazny, and others, instilled in me the courage to be sure I get there somehow including the great suggestion of using crowdfunding. I am part way there but need your help to be able to be away from my place of works and be in pricey lovely London for the week, as I also have tickets on the 15th of July.  We are launching this campaign, pulling from our creative brilliance, to make this more than just please help me take a trip. I will need to eat and sleep outside of the subway or jail.I intend to leave the 14th thru the 21st so your contributions will make my week all the better.As you likely know, I have been a HUGE fan/worshipper/devotee of Monty Python since before I can remember. I grew up watching their movies and shows and with their LPS and never really cut back as I age.  When we began our monthly variety show the Julesworks Follies almost 2.5 years ago, it was with both excitement and trepidation (of violating sacred material), that we began to recreate (rip off?) Monty Python sketches and scenes from all their oeuvre. The first two times were such an amazing thrill that we became hooked and the Julesworks Not Monty Python perform each month as a staple of our show.   What We Need & What You Get The perks will be a combination of creations from great writers and artists such as Trent Zelazny, George RR Martin, Joe Lansdale, Wil S. Hylton, Philip Meyer, Aaron Becker, Martin Reaves and more as well as from Stephen Jules Rubin (a brand new published novella! co-written with PQ Ribber) and Julesworks. I am also whopping up ideas for new material to create during the trip including a diary, in the style of the great Python Diarist Michael Palin with a Jules flare including drawings and pictures.We have many shows footage in the archive of an array of the sketches we have done and plan to shoot one in a more controlled studio like environment to aim for a higher quality. The Impact The impact on my life will be hard to quantify...we all have live acts and shows that are the tops in our dream concerts to attend and very often we don't get to see those either because the show never happens or because the means to be there don't materialize...in this case the show is happening (unless another Python dies before mid July) and thanks to your help I will be there...so the impact on your life will be the joy in knowing you helped me be there, and in getting some of the nifty perks we are accruing.Also, this is tied directly into Julesworks, our Santa Fe based film and theatre production company which has existed in some form since the late 90s with our most consistent project being the Julesworks Follies, Santa Fe's Live Monthly Variety Show in the Vaudeville vein.  Seeing my creative (and life heroes - esp Mr. nice guy Michael Palin), muses and heroes perform will surely add fuel to our fire as performers who mix taking ideas and more from the greats with original sketch material. Julesworks will continue to stage our monthly show while hoping to return to making film, at least short material, and perhaps spreading into our dream of doing some shows on the radio.In short, getting Jules to London for the Python Live Show, especially in a comfortable and safe fashion, will enrich his life and clearly the other great members of Julesworks and the Santa Fe community, and we hope our outreach will continue to grow. Other Ways You Can Help Every dollar will seriously help because Jules loves fish and chips and tea. If you don't have a dollar, even sharing the campaign will be greatly appreciated and surely help to spread the word and surpass our fundraising goal.   And that's all there is to it.

story:
The Mechanical Cat

Writer Janet Goddard and composer Gretchen Hewitt have teamed up and created a dynamic musical and are ready to share it with the world, but they need your help.  Getting a musical produced is no easy task, but Janet and Gretchen have a plan.  Their first goal is to get the story and music to the people! The story is magical, the music is marvelous. 

Your contribution can make that happen.  Their goal this summer is to make a professional audio storybook recording.  This will allow Janet and Gretchen to share the story and music with you and with all story lovers, music lovers, musical theater lovers,  directors, and producers around the world.  

Don't you want to hear a good story through drama and song?  Help Janet and Gretchen share the story of The Mechanical Cat.  

Here's Why We Need You

The name of the game is collaboration in making a musical.  It takes a lot of talent and costs a good deal of money to create such a recording. It's important  to  compensate all of the collaborative talents involved in this project.  Gretchen and Janet need to pay for studio time, a sound recorder/mixer, actors (6 plus), and a musician to make this recording a success.  That's where they need your support.   

Your contributions, large and small, will help pay for this professional recording and will support the arts in a truly hands-on kind of way.  How many people can say that they invested in artists by supporting a totally original, up-and-coming musical?  You can, if you want to.    

If Gretchen and Janet don't reach their goal, they will both have to come up with the money another way, which will not be easy, and which will slow progress for the cat in a big way.  If you want to hear the story by the end of summer, your donation will make the difference.  

The Impact

There is room in this world for all the art we can possibly give it.  Gretchen and Janet have a story that has something for everyone to enjoy, ponder, feel, and hear.  

This musical is completely original.  It is important to continue filling our world with original ideas.  You won't find anything like it.  It isn't a remake of an old story (though many of those are wonderful).  It's completely original.  You will be contributing  to bringing a totally original story into the world. Once you hear it, you'll agree that it is a story worth listening to.  

Gretchen and Janet have already presented the musical to the Women in the Arts Conference at UM-St. Louis in 2011 to good success. They have work-shopped and revised the script and the music.  In other words, it is in strong form and ready for its next step.  

It Isn't All About Money

Gretchen and Janet know that not everyone is in a position to contribute financially (after all, not having the finances themselves is why they need this campaign in the first place),  but that doesn't mean your help is not just as important.  You can help the cause by simply passing along this information and helping Gretchen and Janet get the story and music out and make connections with people who are interested and who care.  Who knows?  Maybe they will support the project. 

Once the recording is made, a whole other kind of support will be needed--sharing the story and music with others.  That should be a pleasure for everyone. 

Give a lot.  Give a little.  Talk it up.  Whatever you do, please support The Mechanical Cat

story:
Hi friends. This is Batty Royale, San Francisco Burlesque performer. Thank you for reading this. I have been performing burlesque since last Summer. It has meant so much to me to be part of an inclusive community where anyone can celebrate their creativity and unique beauty, regardless of age, size, gender or class.

I am raising funds so that I can take Bombshell Betty's Burlesque Intensive II class this Summer. Bombshell Betty was my first teacher, she gave Batty her wings. I love what I do, and I would love to make it more polished, so I have room to bring more of the strange and fun performances you expect from me.

While the funds are technically just for me to take classes, it benefits others. I show people that fat women can be sexual and creative. Which is extremely important to me.

I'm not going to Sarah McLachlan you. (Hell, I'm not even going to google the correct spelling of her name.) These funds don't mean the difference between me having a place to live. But they nurture me creatively. If you choose to help with that, that is a beautiful thing that you are doing.

The classes are $325. Anything I raise over that will go towards costuming, such as fans.

If I do not raise $325, I will use the funds towards costuming, to keep me performing over the next year. I will also use the funds towards train fare to and from gigs.

Big Batty Love to all of you.

story:
The Show

If Jane Goodall were in her 20’s, had just graduated and was 1 part sass, 1 part insatiable curiosity and 1 part feisty redhead – you’ve met Joanie Little. She is making her way through the highest-falutin jungle of all Urbandom - The Coffeeshop. Between the lactose-free lilac lattes and triple shots of espresso, zany customers and useless coworkers, she blazes on through in hopes of making a connection. Between being "clueless, to brainy, to silly, to socially accepted, to deject, wretched and rejected," here's the story of a girl progressing from seeking to please to that of one realizing: finding one's place in the food chain, in the "school of life," also comes down to choosing it for yourself!

Have you ever been on the crux of something? Have you ever felt stuck? We know the feeling well. Have you ever gone back and traced the journey from the fight to the flight? As Bon Iver would say, from the "unlocking to the lift away?" Perhaps you have, perhaps you're there now. This play is for you.

The show is set to premiere in Toronto at the Storefront Theatre June 13th - 16th, 2013. It will also be a part of the Winnipeg Fringe Festival July 18th-28th, and the Edmonton Fringe Fesitval August 15th-25th. 

This is an exciting endevour for all of us, but not one we can do alone. With your help we hope to raise our goal of $1500. This will go towards paying for the cost of production as well as helping to send the show off on its tour out west. Even as little as a $5 contribution will go a long way.


The Playwright

"The 'What now?' headspace can be a trying and frightening one, and it is immediately followed by another question: 'How do I get there?' One we often rush towards answering without really asking or exploring our possibilities. Confessions of a Redheaded Coffeeshop Girl is in many ways inspired my own coming-of-age experience; working in one of the quirkiest coffeeshops of Toronto, the ins and outs of the day, the people I met, the life lessons I learned, but most importantly it's inspired by that gut-feeling I got when I realized that this place - where I was - it was really not where I was supposed to be at all, and THEN asking "Where is that?" And then REALLY questioning "How can I get there." -Rebecca Perry (Playwright, Performer). 

 

The Company

But who are we? 

We're a group of emerging Canadian theatre artists who are dedicated to the development and production of new and exciting Canadian work.

Confessions of a Redheaded Coffeeshop Girl is produced by Seren Lannon in association with Theatre After Secrets and Black Sheep Theatre.

Theatre After Secrets is a not for profit theatre company. By exploring the relationship between text, movement and sound, Theatre After Secrets creates and produces original work as well as adapts existing work; investigating the human condition to reveal truths and subvert assumptions.

Black Sheep Theatre is an independent Ottawa-based theatre company dedicated to producing plays of poetry, plays of beauty, plays with a little bit of an edge to them, but more than anything else, plays which deserve to be seen.

story:
What is a kumrad?

We are! And so are you... "kumrad" = "comrade" in e.e. cummings speak, and we like to think of ourselves as comrades working together to bring this play to life. Over the past three years, it's been developed through numerous workshops, including a much-anticipated reading with Sans A Productions last year. The audience response to this beautiful, intimate play has been overwhelming. Now, kumrads won't is ready for it's world premiere... 

...but we need your help to make it happen.

We're raising money to finance a full production at the New York International Fringe Festival, which features 200 plays and an audience of 75,000. It's an honor to be included in the festival, and we're thrilled! Each of us is only working for a minimal stipend, however, with the majority of our funds going to production costs and administrative fees. It's going to take a lot of support from our fellow kumrads.

 

Who we are

Our production team has a long history of friendship and theater-making that began at the University of Evansville, but life has split us between New York and Chicago. We're delighted to have been brought back together by this brilliant script and our passion for developing new plays.

Playwright: Christina Watkins

Director and Producer: Kristin McCarthy Parker

Associate Producer: Nick Abeel

Marketing and Media Director: Taylor Bailey

See our full bios on the kumrads won't website.

 

What is it about?

"There are many effects of hating one’s self, but the one that I find the most fascinating and have observed again and again is the way in which it acts as a force that doesn’t allow us to let the caring of others enter our worlds."

-Christina Watkins, playwright (Read more here)

kumrads won’t is the story of a young woman, Ponce, and a middle-aged veteran, Walter, finally exploring an ongoing flirtation begun at the diner where they both work. They lead unremarkable lives in an unremarkable city, each lonely and damaged in their own way. Despite the flaws and obstacles between them, however, they strive for a connection. Late one winter night, Ponce braves a snowstorm to meet Walter at his apartment, and the evening quickly becomes much more intimate and complicated than either of them bargained for. Over shared whiskey, cigarettes, and--yes--e.e. cummings, they show us what can happen when two people, who are by all accounts “wrong” for each other, try to come together. It is funny and heartbreaking and utterly human.

 

What goes into our budget?

A lot! Funding a play is not as DIY as it sounds. Here's a general idea of what we'll need...

  • Space Rentals
  • Production: set, props, costumes, trucking
  • Administrative fees: registration and insurace
  • Stipends: 7 production, 2 actors
  • Marketing/Publicity
  • Travel from Chicago-->NYC
  • Printing 

And more! If we don't reach our goal, we'll have to cut back on stipends and marketing materials. If we exceed our goal, however, we'll be able to more fairly compensate our team AND increase our marketing and audience reach, bringing this play to even more people!

 

What's in it for me?

1) Our undying love and devotion. 2) We'll keep you up-to-date with photos and videos from our cast and creative team, in addition to blogging about the play and our production process. 3) With a minimum $20 donation, we'll send you an e.e. cummings poem with original artwork by Jeremy Jacob Schlangen. Here's a look at some of his other creations...

  

...Need we say more?

 

Like us!

Our best friends are social media and word-of-mouth. Follow, like, retweet, and share to your heart's content!

Website: http://www.kumradswont.com/

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/KumradsWont

twitter: @kumradswont

Blog: http://kumradswont.tumblr.com/

 

Thank you

Check out the donation incentives to your right and give today! We appreciate your support.

story:
Did You Have (or still have) an Imaginary Friend?

After many years of blood, sweat and tears , we are excited to say that Imaginary is moving on to its own new phase of existence. The concept for this play came to me one day while I was waiting tables at a restaurant. I can’t say whether it was divine inspiration, or, just my brain trying to find a higher level of activity other than asking what side dish people wanted with their steak. Regardless, it has been an incredible journey ever since. I want to tell a story. I want to take you away from the world you’re currently living in; away from any troubles or worries or constant bombardment of hate and fear and crime from news channels and the internet. Why not follow an eight-year-old as she becomes friends with the most unlikeliest of people? Why not watch a grown man’s heart melt as he learns to love someone he never thought he could love? Why not watch a family come together and fall in love with each other all over again? Imaginary has grown so much since its inception six years ago. Now the creative team and the production team are ready to share it with all of you, and beyond. Please help us to fund this show and bring a little imagination back. Help us to spread a message of love and friendship to a world that needs it. Help everyone who has worked on this project to tell its story.

 

Imaginary Needs and Gives

We need $4500. Why? Expenses a-gogo. We are producing a backers' audition for Imaginary in hopes that we can get some interested folks to back our project. Our ultimate goal is to have a commercial run of Imaginary.

Our budget includes theater rental, rehearsal space rental, and compensation for the Imaginary team.

We will give you, for your lovely donation, the perks to the right. They include buttons, your name in the program, tickets to the reading, a bound and signed script by the team, your name in the script and even an invite to our post-show luncheon.

Now, just because you may not be able to donate right now doesn't mean you can't help. You can post our link via your social media accounts just by using the Indiegogo share tools! We appreciate it and we thank you.

I want to take you away from the world you’re currently living in; away from any troubles or worries or constant bombardment of hate and fear and crime from news channels and the internet. Why not follow an eight-year-old as she becomes friends with the most unlikeliest of people? Why not watch a grown man’s heart melt as he learns to love someone he never thought he could love? Why not watch a family come together and fall in love with each other all over again? Imaginary has grown so much since its inception six years ago. Now the creative team and the production team are ready to share it with all of you, and beyond. Please help us to fund this show and bring a little imagination back. Help us to spread a message of love and friendship to a world that needs it. Help everyone who has worked on this project to tell its story.
 
Imaginary Needs and Gives
We need $4500. Why? Expenses a-gogo. We are producing a backers' audition for Imaginary in hopes that we can get some interested folks to back our project. Our ultimate goal is to have a commercial run of Imaginary.
Our budget includes theater rental, rehearsal space rental, and compensation for the Imaginary team.
We will give you, for your lovely donation, the perks to the right. They include buttons, your name in the program, tickets to the reading, a bound and signed script by the team, your name in the script and even an invite to our post-show luncheon.
Now, just because you may not be able to donate right now doesn't mean you can't help. You can post our link via your social media accounts just by using the Indiegogo share tools! We appreciate it and we thank you.

story:
G. Gebony Productions presents: Me and Caesar Lee!

 

Origins of Me and Caesar Lee

ME AND CAESAR LEE is an all original new musical. 

Pat Holley, life-long musician and singer, wrote the music, lyrics, and book as a response to what she observed in theater: an absence of meaningful roles for African American performers. 

This new musical comedy/drama made its fully staged reading debut at the Tony-winning Crossroads Theater Company in New Brunswick, New Jersey (Outstanding Regional Theater). It starred the legendary, two-time Tony nominee, Ernestine Jackson, as Camille Lambert, and its extensive development throughout the following years was assisted by Julia Miles (Founder, The Women’s Project Theater); Tony Award winner, Lillias White (The Life); AUDELCO Award winner, Billie Allen (Saint Lucy’s Eyes); Brenda Pressley (And The World Goes Round); arranger/ composer, A. Dennis Williams; AUDELCO Award winner, Petronia Paley (Cherry Orchard); acclaimed dramaturge, Sydne Mahone; AUDELCO Award winner, Lynda Gravatt (Crowns); and other prominent actors and theater administrators.

 

The Project

After many self-produced and self-financed readings, staged readings, and performances, including a highly successful 2011 song concert, Divas and Friends Sing Songs from Me and Caesar Lee, at the Triad Theater in NYC, Me and Caesar Lee was invited to participate in the Midtown International Theatre Festival (MITF) in 2013. It was a wonderful opportunity to showcase this inspirational musical and to fulfill the G. Gebony Productions mission- to broaden the scope for African-American women in theatre. The production was postponed, because Ms. Holley needed an emergency eye operation. Me and Caesar Lee is coming to the New York City stage in the summer, 2014.

We need to raise $15,000 to cover the costs of promotions, festival fees, and payment for the cast and crew of the upcoming production. In addition to covering the expenses of a summer production, these funds will put us on track to giving Me and Caesar Lee the off-Broadway run it deserves. These funds will be used solely for the purposes of furthering the production of Me and Caesar Lee, and your donations and support are gratefully received. If we raise more than our intended goal of $15,000, the additional funds will be directed to later productions of Me and Caesar Lee. You can see more about the show at meandcaesarlee.com. 

 

The Story

Me & Caesar Lee begins in 1985 as Camille Lambert, a former recording star and songwriter approaches her 43rd birthday. She lives alone in New York City, is heavily in debt, and hasn’t dated in more than three years.

Hoping to revive her songwriting career, she attends a music industry seminar and meets Caesar Lee, 22-year-old manager of a teenage singing group. She becomes deeply infatuated with him and he and his group become the primary focus of her professional and personal life. 

When these young people betray her, she returns to her hometown, intending to kill herself, as her mother had done twenty-two years prior. After an encounter with an eccentric former midwife, Camille embarks upon a spiritual journey to heal herself. She returns to New York City with a promising new outlook on her life and is finally open to the possibilities of available love.


Listen to select songs and watch select performances from Me and Caesar Lee here.


Our Expenses:

  • Salaries
  • These expenses include payment for 7 actors; the director; the choreographer; designers; technical crew; stage management; light and sound board operators.
  • Materials
  • This includes set materials, costume materials, and props.
  • Promotional Materials Design and Printing
  • This includes poster, flyer, and postcard design and printing costs; bulk mailing costs; advertisements; photographer; publicity; and website design and maintenance
  • Other
  • This includes box office services, audio/video recording, script copying, and ticket and program printing.


How YOU Can Help Us:

Give. We want to share this project with as many people as possible, and we need your help to do that. PLUS, there are some really great perks in it for you. For those who do not want to be credited for their contributions on Facebook, the program, or the website, please include a note with your contribution or give anonymously. We will still greatly appreciate your contribution while respecting your privacy.


What Else You Can Do:

Share this project generously! And then share some more! The more our supporters share this project via email, Facebook, Twitter #CaesarLee2014, phone, and word of mouth, the more support and the greater a base you help us to build. Help us take CaesarLee2014 viral by getting the word out on the web and on the streets! 

The success of this summer’s production will allow us to seek investors for an Off-Broadway run, which, in turn, could attract investors for Broadway. Your donations will be used solely for the purposes stated, and all donations and support are very gratefully received. If we raise more than our intended goal of $15,000, the remainder will be used to enhance this summer’s production or will be directed to later productions of Me And Caesar Lee.


Updates

Performance Dates 

Monday, July 14 at 8 PM

Friday, July 18 at 8 PM

Monday, July 21 at 8 PM

Wednesday, July 23 at 3 PM

Saturday, July 26 at 8 PM

Thursday, July 31 at 8 PM

Wednesday, August 6 at 3 PM

Friday, August 8 at 8 PM

All performances will be held at the Barrow Group's TBG Theatre in the Theater Building at 312 west 36th Street.


Our show is fully cast!

Featuring the wonderful talents of:

*Robyn Payne, *Ernestine Jackson, *Raun Ruffin, Joshua Scarlett, *Amanda Holley, Nick Mara, and Sadat Waddy!

*members of Actors Equity Association

story:
Who We Are

TE San Pedro Rep offers the Southern California community a unique alternative to the typical L.A. theater experience. A wholehearted celebration of empowered artistic innovation - from every background and medium, TESPR strives to reawaken the creative spirit in each of us. 

True to its name, TE San Pedro Rep is an artistic paradise - a caring, dedicated community fully invested in the work of every inspired craftsman. We joyfully embrace the interdisciplinary nature of performance, utilizing every aspect of human experience to delve further and further into the unknown. Through intelligent and fearless exploration, TESPR is committed to reexamining the fundamental works that have defined performance from Ancient Greece to Modern America. We knowingly stand on the shoulders of giants, casting our vision forward into a new era of American performance.

We remain committed to fueling the next generation of American art, creating visionary work that rattles the foundations of modern performance.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Your generous contribution will help "Raise The Curtain" on TE San Pedro Rep's production of HAMLET - opening November 14th, 2013!

The Goal: $1,000 for the show's production budget and marketing efforts!

TESPR is giving all supporters of our production a Supporting Cast, Producer or Executive Producer credit - each with it's own perks and levels of recognition.

 

The Production

Incorporating elements of physical theatre, Commedia, and a powerful command of language, TE San Pedro Rep (TESPR) presents a bold and imaginative retelling of Shakespeare's greatest work, HAMLET, directed by MARTIN JAGO.

TESPR's production of Hamlet will bring an international ensemble of artists together, lead its audience on an unyielding journey of discovery into a sensory exploration of the physical and the elemental and will dare to examine anew the universal themes that lie at the heart of Hamlet, such as Time and its existential narrative that runs like a thread through the fabric of the play.

To play the play is to hold a mirror up to nature in the most literal of senses, since Time itself is at the heart of the theatrical event. It is that shared experience, a breath, a transient moment never to be repeated that is, in a sense, the world of the play as much as it is our own existence.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

The success of this project lies in the sense of community it inspires. We believe in the power of community. It is an ever increasing force, a will that can do things that no single person - no matter their talents - can achieve on their own. Put simply, we are Believers. Optimists. Enthusiasts. We invite you to share in our dream - that together we can build an artistic paradise of devoted, passionate, and FEARLESS artists, boldly pushing the boundaries of performance throughout the world!

story:
Hi everyone. My name is Abby Ellison. I was born and raised in Crystal Lake, IL. I am graduating from Webster University this coming spring with a BFA in dance. Since I began training in dance, my dream has been to perform professionally. The problem these days is that to be able to join a dance company, you need money to travel to auditions. And that is where you can help!

What I Need & What You Get

I am planning on taking four trips to Chicago. I am from Crystal Lake but the auditions are during school days where I will be in St Louis. I normally take Megabus or the Amtrak so train tickets and bus passes can get expensive. I am planning on going to Nashville, Tennessee as well to audition for a company and possibly New York for an audition. You will receive fun personalized perks for helping a young girl's dream come true of becoming a professional dancer!

The Impact

In the dance community, money is sparse. Even dancers who have jobs are working one or two others just to get by. While being in school I am working as much as my schedule allows and teaching when I can but it does get difficult saving money when I am constantly buying tickets to come home for the holidays and for auditions. My father passed away when I was twelve years old, so money has been tight after his passing. Alright enough with the sappy story, any contribution would mean the world to me. I have worked so hard at trying to do this all on my own but I am finally allowing myself to receive help from the outside. Your help will not go unnoticed in the slightest. 

Other Ways You Can Help

I know money is something that is coming and going so at this time if you cannot spare a dime, No worries! You can...

1) Give a donation of any amount. (Each donation has a perk!)

2) Share my campaign on your Facebook page, Twitter, Instagram...you get the idea:)

3) Share my campaign link


Thank you all for your time and support!!

story:
Pointe Shoes Needed!

  • Without the proper shoes a ballerina is in danger of serious injury.
  • Super glue and acrylic shellac to help stiffen the toe box and the shank of the shoe that provide ankle support.
  • Glues and Shellac cannot fix a worn shoe, it only prolongs the shoe's life for a very short amount of time.

                                                                  

This fund will support the purchase:

  •  Pointe Shoes 
  • Toe pads - Prevent the uneven pressure that cause: blackened toe nails, bruising, and blisters
  • Ribbons- The ribbons that tie around the ankle of the dancer are sold separately from the shoe and sewn on by the dancer.
  • Elastics- A wide length of elastic holds the shoe in place keeping the arch and ankle supported. This is sold separately from the shoe and sewn on by the dancer.

                           

                    

**Please note that we have two indie go gocampaigns running with the same end date. Both support Coral's dance training but totals are calculated separately.

Without new shoes:

Dancers attempt to lengthen the life of the shoe beyond its limits causing injury:

  • Tremendous force is placed on the foot when dancing on point and pointe shoes are specially designed to protect the foot from these forces but will only last for approx. 8 hours of strenuous dancing.
  • Injury to the feet from ill-fitted and improper shoes are the number one cause of dance injury.
  • Injury can take upwards of a year to heal, greatly impacting if not derailing a career in dance.

              

    The Math:

  • $100 per pair of point shoes with toe pads ribbon and elastic

  • x 10 pairs = $1,000 (the need)

  • + 9% (to cost the of Indie Go Go fees)

  •  = $1,075

     Why I need your support?

My mom is losing her job right about Christmas this year. She will officially be laid off and her location closed. After nine years of dedicated dance training I need help with costs to cover this next year. Doing so will keep my years of dedication from going to waste. Please give, the holiday cards are very nice and were printed specifically for the campaign. I can't do it alone but I know that with your support I'm going to make it through and continue on to realize my goal to become a professional dancer. 


I want to send a special Thank you to director Galen Summer for creating the amazing and informative vimeo video, and allowing me to use it for my campaign. Thank you Galen! 



Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Ask to have family and friends give in your name!

story:
Short Summary

The Wapsipinicon Theatre Festival is a week long theatre experience(experiment) We create a work in rural Iowa (Independence Iowa) in a week and show it to the local community. This is not a community that has arts and theatre coming to it's doorstep often.

I am a theatre artist, deviser, clown, and amateur aerialist. I am trying to bring my skills and enthusiasm to this community. Like many artists, I am poor. Like many festivals for audiences outside of large urban centers Wapsi is under funded. This campaign is to help me travel to and eat in Iowa.

What We Need & What You Get

I just need a little bit of funding to help cover airfare, busfare, and food. I cannot offer a lot of cool prizes,but ill try to offer some goofy incentives. Even a couple of bucks will help me fly over the Wapsipinicon River as people travel down it by canoe and experience their own arts odyssey.

Here is the breakdown of the fundage

$400- Airfare

$40 - Busfare

$52- Indiegogo fees

$108- food and miscellany

The Impact

The main goal of the festival is to bring cutting edge theatrical and circus arts to a community that doesn't have a large arts scene. The town is mostly farmers. They help fill our bellies. We want to feed their spirit.

http://www.wapsifest.com/about-wapsifest.html for more information about the festival

Other Ways You Can Help

ways to help

1) donate

2) tell friends about this campaign

3) think of applying as an artist next summer and bring your bad-ass skills to this town.

story:
A longstanding tradition at ASU

Barren Mind Improv has been performing at Arizona State University since the mid 90s. Alumni of the troupe have gone on to perform at Second City, The Annoyance, The Upright Citizens Brigade Theatre, and iO West. 

Barren Mind is known for strong character choices, fast play, and running a sweet Armando long form. 

Since it began in 2007, Barren Mind has competed in every NATIONAL COLLEGE IMPROV TOURNAMENT's Western Regional. They've won the regional 3 out of the last four years. 

ASU will not fund our trip to NATIONALS in CHICAGO and that's why we need all of you, OUR FANS, to help! 

What We Need & What You Get

Although we'll be representing Arizona State University, the administration doesn't provide monetary support for our trip. We are solely responsible for the cost of the trip and it is our goal to raise enough money to send our cast to nationals in Chicago on March 1st.

A rundown of what you're supporting:

Airline fare =6 tickets x $200 per ticket = $1,200

Hotel = 2 Rooms x 2 nights x $200 each = $800

Food = $80 per person (For two days full of meals) x 6 people = $480

Transportation - $20 x 6 = $120

9% fee to Indiegogo = $234

For a grand total of $2,834!  

All the money will go towards funding this trip. Barren Mind is a nationally recognized college improv troupe, seriously though click this link12 GREAT COLLEGE IMPROV TROUPES. We perform all over the state of Arizona and California. Any money not used towards this troupe will be used to fund more improv trips and shows.

SWEET PERKS! 

More of our perks are listed below but basically we want to reward your support! For your help we have perks like personalized thank you notes from Barren Mind, a thank you Snapchat from the cast, the chance to be in a Barren Mind show, and much more!  

The Impact

Why help a bunch of college improvisers? Because you will be helping a group of best friends who are more than passionate about comedy make their dreams become a reality. Also, because Barren Mind is truly one of THE premiere teams of SUN DEVIL Nation; and great teams should be supported! Name another ASU team that's been ranked in the top twelve in the country three consecutive years. Name another ASU team that has been to the finals of a national tournament three out of the last four years. YOUR support will help us continue to represent Arizona State University in the world of COLLEGE IMPROV!

Other Ways You Can Help

The most important characteristics of a great improv troupe are support and trust. Coincidentally those characteristics are just as important to this campaign. We want you to trust our mission because we are passionate about achieving our goal. We understand support comes in a lot of ways and funds may be low so please spread the word of our campaign through social media. Please use Indiegogo share tools and help spread our story to the world!
story_txt:
A longstanding tradition at ASU
Barren
Mind Improv has been performing at Arizona State University since the mid 90s.
Alumni of the troupe have gone on to perform at Second City, The Annoyance, The
Upright Citizens Brigade Theatre, and iO West. 
Barren
Mind is known for strong character choices, fast play, and running a sweet
Armando long form. 
Since
it began in 2007, Barren Mind has competed in every NATIONAL COLLEGE IMPROV TOURNAMENT's
Western Regional. They've won the regional 3 out of the last four years. 
ASU
will not fund our trip to NATIONALS in CHICAGO and that's why we need all of
you, OUR FANS, to help! 
What We Need & What You Get
Although
we'll be representing Arizona State University, the administration doesn't
provide monetary support for our trip. We are solely responsible for the cost
of the trip and it is our goal to raise enough money to send our cast to
nationals in Chicago on March 1st.
A
rundown of what you're supporting:
Airline
fare =6 tickets x $200 per ticket = $1,200
Hotel
= 2 Rooms x 2 nights x $200 each = $800
Food
= $80 per person (For two days full of meals) x 6 people = $480
Transportation
- $20 x 6 = $1209% fee to Indiegogo = $234
For
a grand total of $2,834!  
All the money will go towards funding this
trip. Barren Mind is a nationally recognized college improv troupe, seriously
though click this link12
GREAT COLLEGE IMPROV TROUPES. We perform all over the state of Arizona and California.
Any money not used towards this troupe will be used to fund more improv trips
and shows.
SWEET PERKS! 
More of our perks are listed below but
basically we want to reward your support! For your help we have perks like
personalized thank you notes from Barren Mind, a thank you Snapchat from the
cast, the chance to be in a Barren Mind show, and much more!  
The Impact
Why
help a bunch of college improvisers? Because you will be helping a group of
best friends who are more than passionate about comedy make their dreams become
a reality. Also, because Barren Mind is truly one of THE premiere teams of
SUN DEVIL Nation; and great teams should be supported! Name another ASU team
that's been ranked in the top twelve in the country three consecutive years. Name another ASU
team that has been to the finals of a national tournament three out of the last
four years. YOUR support will help us continue to
represent Arizona State University in the world of COLLEGE IMPROV!
Other Ways You Can Help
The
most important characteristics of a great improv troupe are support and trust. Coincidentally
those characteristics are just as important to this campaign. We want you to
trust our mission because we are passionate about achieving our goal. We
understand support comes in a lot of ways and funds may be low so please spread
the word of our campaign through social media. Please use Indiegogo share tools
and help spread our story to the world!

story:
What is The Helen Project?

The Helen Project zooms in and out of the myth and the mind of the most beautiful woman in the world. Images of Helen of Troy from Homer and Marlowe, from modern poetry, from the golden age of Hollywood, and even ripped from the headlines of our contemporary tabloids, turn in a kaleidoscope of original and found text. We glimpse fleeting portraits of this mythic woman as each performance twists the mirrors to reflect a new Helen.

Like the text, Helen herself is fragmented. Five women – all Helen – crowd a bedroom, each making a decision that will change her life. Along a mythic timeline, each Helen grapples with the choices that have led to her present moment. Five Helens look into a mirror, asking, “Is this the face that launched a thousand ships?”

There's so much more about the project on Amy's website.

The Helen Project was created by Megan Cohen and Amy Clare Tasker. After a successful workshop in San Francisco in 2013, we're on the road to a premiere production in London. Our first step: Helen has been invited to perform at the Lost Theatre's Face to Face Festival of solo theatre this July.

We are so excited to partner with director Sharon Burrell, actor/producer Angela Bull, and an immensely talented team of performers Rachel Handshaw, Pearl Mackie, Anna Martine, and Georgina Panton.


What We Need Now

As with many theatre projects, in order to find support for a full production, we must first invest in early developmental performances. 

We are so grateful for the support of the cast and creative team in signing on for this early phase of the project as volunteers, for lending Helen their time and talents. 

Your support at this early stage will help us to find safe, clean, creative rehearsal space to work towards our July performances.


    Why Does It Matter?

    The Helen Project  has been years in the making, and with each passing day, it seems to become more and more relevant. The piece critiques beauty standards, victim-blaming, female agency within patriarchy, and even the way we create myth. 

    Called “provocative and intriguing” in The San Francisco Chronicle, The Helen Project has the potential to make a huge splash in London as it continues its development, riding the wave of feminist theatre that is currently bringing Blurred Lines and other gender-conscious work to the stage.

    For more about the representation of women in theatre, check out the GAP Salon (Gender and Performance) website, where you can find data, articles, events, and links to other groups of artists and advocates working for gender equality.


    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you'd like to help beyond a financial contribution, here are some more ways to get involved with The Helen Project:

    • Join the #helenproject conversation on Twitter.
    • RSVP to the Facebook event.
    • Get tickets for the performances at the Lost Theatre. (July 11 and 13)
    • Share the link to this campaign using Indiegogo's share tools.

    Thank you!
